GAME: Magic: The Gathering
RANK: 156
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
One of the best games ever. 

Almost all of the criticism I hear about Magic is that it costs too much. But really, it only costs what you want you want to spend on it. You can get a longbox of commons for $10 and be set... if you have discipline - and if you don't, that's your problem not the game's. 

----
(bought)

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: N/A
2008: My FLGS gave me two 10th Edition Core Sets for free. They felt very much like 'beginner sets' but I enjoyed my first three games with the 'Cho-Manno's Resolve' deck. 

2010: Bought a selection of "Thematic" ready to play decks. But I suspect I will need more cards to really get the best from this game. Great game, but to me the collectability aspect is just bothersome and plainly stupid.

2013: Got into Magic again. This time during the release of M14 and the Theros set. Got into limited and drafting formats and really found a new love for the game. Expensive but still a lovely game.

RATING: 10
A world and a lifestyle rather than a game, it could be argued. I am more into games that aren't quite as much of a project nowadays, though, but I have to give Magic a 10 for the 20+ years of fun it's meant for me, for being so extremely innovative (people bring their own game pieces and sometimes you might not even have seen some of the cards in your opponents deck) and vast (aproaching 20 000 cards now, I'd guess) and immersive.

RATING: 6

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: N/A
I really don't know what to rate this game. I've played it for many years now, and loved it all that time, except that, for the past few months, I have stopped buying cards and playing it. Now it almost disgusts me to see my giant drawer full of all my cards. It is truly terrible that whoever spends the most money on cards usually wins. I have had  recurring lapses of this feeling before, but it never really has hit me like it has now. However, anyone who likes playing the game in general, should try playing in a sealed deck tournament, which is really the only fair way to play, and it can be a lot of fun. 
The main reason I stopped playing (which isn't neccessarily a permanent decision) is that whenever I played, I would just get in a big argument with my friend who was playing with me about what certain cards could and couldn't do, making the game just no fun anymore. Also, I felt the new cards were spinning out of control a bit in terms of how radically unfair they were. Some of my friends feel the newest expansions destroyed the game. I don't quite think that, but that it probably because I found the Japanese theme intruiging.
I am not rating the game, because I would not rate it too highly, as that would be promoting the almost criminal way Wizards of the Coast can keep printing more and more good cards so fast (couldn't they stop at some point?), but I wouldn't rate it too badly, because, after all, I really like the general idea of the game, and it has given me tons of hours of fun.

6% luck

RATING: 9
Started playing in 1994, gave up collecting sometime after Urza's block and got back into it right before New Phyrexia hit.
Loads of depth and many game types to choose from, but expect to pay to play as crafting competitive decks can get pricy fast. Very few games retain their value like M:tG though and acquiring certain cards could even be seen as an investment.

RATING: 10
I've put off rating this for...I dunno, forever.  I'm not sure why.  It is the game--THE game--that defined most of my early gaming life.  Magic and role-playing games.  Reapproaching Magic after several years of absence, and teaching Mickie, reminds me again of how brilliant the game is.  Why play something like Lost Cities when you could play Magic?  I don't understand why this isn't universally considered one of the best 2-player hobby games ever made.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
I recently started playing MTG again. I love doing booster drafts and playing Limited format. I use the cards I get to build my Constructed format decks. 
I think MTG is a lot of fun and has a high level of strategy, but it is not for most board gamers. MTG is almost an exclusive hobby and I find when I am playing MTG and buying cards I don't think about board games as much, and vice versa.
To anyong interested in trying this game I would recommend starting out getting a pre-made deck and learning the rules, and then doing booster drafts. That will supply you with a lot of cards for much cheaper than retail and you will increase in skill far more quickly.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8.5
A great classic game I used to play. The rules are simple, easy, and intuitive and the game is very deep, but it was too expensive to keep up with other players. If you and your opponent are on the same level though, it's a blast.

I want to try different casual drafting formats using my cards. I've already tried some and had a great time. I have 4 common sets and nearly 4 uncommon sets, all from 10th edition, plus a bunch of land. Got it all on eBay for around $20 (including shipping).

The newer sets are better in just about every way than the older ones. The cards are more balanced, the art is better, and the variety of cards is more interesting.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
An excellent, flexible, ever-changing game; the key to the longevity and popularity of the game is that the rules follow from the cards, and not the cards from the rules, as well as an excellent resource-limiting system. The game had serious development issues around the time I temporarily stopped playing (Urza's Saga, due to lack of time), but since the Invasion block, the game has been (for the most part) carefully designed and balanced. One should take care and do some research if they want to get into it now, because the addictive nature of the game can ruin the overall experience. 

The game has a steep learning curve which plateaus a few times, so it usually takes some time to get a hold on the theory involved with the game, both in deckbuilding and in actual play. Stick to casual play unless you have a good gaming group to test decks with and borrow cards from. Otherwise you'll quickly find yourself frustrated with the game (in other words, you'll spend more money at the game but won't improve in play skill or deck construction). I simply haven't seen anybody grasp higher-level play without a few months of practice.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 8
2011-01-13 (rating 8):

I decreased the rating as I go more and more into games with tiny to non randomness.

2010-04-14 (rating 8.5):

The game is great and rich. It has countless ways of winning (through countless decks, numerous general tactics and so on). Also it has very good rules, precise and clear even thou there are lots of cards (or at least so it was around 8th edition).

Now I am not that much into CCGs and being a CCG is the main problem (for me) in this game.

Except for that it is simply brilliant although somewhat random. But a better player will generally win with worse one even if some games may be lost due to unlucky cards.

RATING: 9
While I no longer actively play this highly addicting game, I still have all my cards AND I WILL NEVER GET RID OF THEM.  They are a part of me now, and will never go away.

I started playing back in middle school, when a found a Sengir Vampire tucked into a Thieve's World book as a bookmark at the public library.  I was intrigued.  What game was this?  It is not surprising that I mainly play black.  However, I like mixed decks - so it is usually black plus another color.  Black and red is my favorite for a quick death, black and blue to taunt my opponent, black and green for some overpowered creatures, and black and white for some unholy rampaging.

I actively played all through high school, fading a little through college, until now, when my decks sit unused on my shelves.  (Though I still can't help but by a new pack every now and then, mostly to ogle the gorgeous artwork.)

RATING: 6
What can I say? It's magic. Personally I think the way land is tapped for mana is a serious flaw of the game because you sometimes (too often) just get unlucky and can't get enough land because of the way your deck is shuffled. I also have a fundamental objection to games where you are able to 'pay to win' to any extent. Games should be 'PLAY to win'. Having said that, I have a lot of cards, and it is a very flexible game which works with almost any number of players and has many different variants! Also, if you learn to play Magic, you will be able to pick up almost any game and learn to play it quickly.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
This game means so many different things to so many different people, it is almost impossible to give an accurate rating... It's a behemoth in the industry, and practically a society unto itself. Not only are there numerous formats for both constructed and limited play, there are variant and unofficial formats that wax and wane in popularity, local metagames, unofficial bannings and impromptu nerfs; to use a cliche term, there are millions of people who play Magic, and there is probably that many different ways to play the game.

I don't know if one can separate the game from the culture, media, and shared memories surrounding it. Some use the game as a way to experience the world that they read about in the books and comics, while others go to tournaments as an outlet for competition. For many it sparked that initial creative spark that led them to game design, not only through creating interesting decks, but also by making custom cards and formats.

My rating reflects both my genuine enjoyment with the core game itself, regardless of the ups and downs with whatever meta for a particular format, and the local community that I became a part of.

As a final note, the game is not "pay to win". A deck that just jams all of the most expensive cards will be trounced by a deck that has been tested and well-tuned. Hell, what is considered the best deck is often not even the most expensive, as seen in Legacy and Vintage. It does however require a substantial initial investment if you want to be tournament ready, so it can be called "Pay to compete". That initial investment can be maintained through aggressive buying, selling, and trading cards like stocks, but at that point you have to treat the game like a second part-time job. It is fine if people don't want to deal with he money/time investment to be competitive, but again, the game is not "P2W".
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 7
I played Magic as a life-style game for 4 years and I also used to do tournaments a lot. I even made it twice in Top8 at PTQs, but at some point I realised that I wasn't enjoying the game anymore. I was just competing and that sucked all the fun out of the hobby. At that point I stopped playing it and moved on to other things.

Now I see that Magic is a good game. It was absolutely innovative when it came out and we all have to be very grateful for what it did for our hobby. At this point instead I think it has too much luck involved and there are games that do the same thing better... also the business behind Magic is just sick. Good game, but thank God I'm over it.

RATING: 7
Better than San Juan, but not as cheap.  Not as good a game, really, as RftG, Jambo, Glory to Rome, or Blue Moon.

Why?  It's not that, with knowledge of the rules and good decks, Magic is a bad game -- it's a quite extraordinary game, in that case.  The investment to become a competent Magic player, however, is massive, in both time and money.  I was up for that as an undergraduate, but didn't play any in grad school, and my wife isn't much on the game (though she thinks Lhurgoyf is cute).  So, the game has to suffer some ratings punishment for requiring (1) complete understanding of a rule-set that is almost ASL league, if you want to really do it right (and makes War of the Ring look like Hey, That's My Fish) and (2) a pretty huge money investment to produce variety and keep it going.

That said, people who think they can attain the fun of making your own decks by playing Dominion are deluding themselves.  These are not the same thing, at all.

RATING: 8
I hate the collectable nature of the game but if you can get a good set of cards and ignore all the expansions and the collectability, it makes a wonderful game. It's fast, fairly easy to play and teach and offers plenty of decisions. I'm torn between really liking the game but not wanting to collect lots of cards and climbing the learning curve of learning all the cards. That's my biggest problem with the game. There are just waaayyyyyy too many cards. To get a handle on effective deck building you need to have and really understand thousands of cards. I enjoy playing other peoples decks when not playing my small set of cards or pregenerated decks. But actually building a deck is something I'll probably never bother with. But I can certainly see the appeal.

RATING: 10
One of the funnest, most versatile and excitingly customizable card games I've ever played. The fantasy theme is enthralling; the mechanics are fluid and ever-changing; the skill, strategy and challenge involved in building decks remains one of my most favourite aspects of the game. Not to mention the card art is, very often, outstanding.
It does get very expensive though, so I've found most enjoyment in playing with close friend groups who agree to spend around $50 or less on each deck.
A longtime favourite of mine and will be forever.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 4
Garfield has a mathematics PhD, but despite this, chose to make a game with some of the simplest and most easily solved core mechanics. This isn't surprising as he was inspired by poker in large part. While MtG is the first TCG, that doesn't automatically make it the best (or the worst). Numbers in the game aren't very good comparison percentages, which is surprising given Garfield's combinatorial mathematics degree. What I mean is Power 5 and Power 6 are great ratios (5 is ~83% of 6) and therefore represents good granularity, but the mana system forces both players to be approximately at the same level of "ramp" to experience this creature power ratio. This is entirely a byproduct of western TCG number systems where single-digit integers are favored. 

The ramp itself is a pure travesty. Yet another single-digit integer, but now with flavors (Black, Red etc) which are poorly compared ratios to each other. If you fall behind in ramp, almost always due to chance and rarely ever due to skill/deck at this point in the game, you pretty much just lose as you can't carry a midgame. If you open with mana screw (16.5%) or flood (~6% with standard land). Meaning you have a NON-overlapping hard probability of 22.5% to just be screwed. Depending on which flavor and if your opponent is too (~5% of total games), you may or may not be able to still win. If your opponent is not when you are screwed/flooded, which is the most probable, you take an auto loss. Not a problem for casual players but a huge and insurmountable problem for veterns who play in tournaments. 

Consider than Pro Tour qualified players automatically gain 3 bys to shove them past the opening three games of chaos and random chance because they know this and refuse to fix it. Mulligan in this game forces a -1 each time, which simply punishes the player who was unlucky. So ramp is the most important aspect of the game and yet is one hundred percent entirely chance based. Almost every single game based on MtG gets rid of this garbage (Force of Will lets you pick "land" and Epic Card Game gives you 1 gold to spend each player's turn, with all the best cards costing exactly 1 gold). 

Creatures themselves overpower the game dauntingly. Without constant tempo cards like kill spells and board wipes, creatures simply always win as is evidenced by every tournament ever. Most games that choose a creature-dominant meta simply get rid of non-creatures (Cardfight Vanguard) or make spells/events more powerful and flexible (Epic Card Game, WIXOSS). Top players all agree this game is played with your opening hand and whether you actually draw land at a 1/3 ratio for the next four-five turns. The battle system is so awful it devolves into a game of Chicken (see: Game Theory, something Garfield should've been familiar with) even as early as the original Alpha set. This problem has never gone away and creature battles quickly turn into a cold war until someone breaks or plays removal/lock. 

The stack is a horribly confusing concept most modern games have gotten rid of entirely in favor if a proper initial design and more conservative card effects (EPIC again, Star Realms, Vanguard, Netrunner—his second game, etc). The continued inclusion of overly-inflated complexity in magic detracts from its long-term viability as a good game. 

The eternal formats are frozen forever in time, with legacy never changing, modern changing mildly about once a year and then you have standard which invalidates all your card purchases every so often just to kick you in the teeth. Despite this fact, Wizards refuses to reprint popular and necessary cards for their eternal formats, causing interest to steadily decline over the last decade due to inflated and unobtainable prices. Even their more approachable formats like EDH (or their marketing rebrand "Commander") are dressed up as casual fun times to get together with friends, when really it's almost as bad as legacy due to having no proper ban list. Which wouldn't be important if it were a casual format except Commander has TOURNAMENTS. 

Richard's failure on every level to deliver a mathematically sound or satisfying game is only trumped by Wizard's complete failure to understand its fans and deliver a good product without destroying wallets.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
Own a starter deck of the revised edition, and some cards from some early edition.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
Rating is for game design, quality of components, depth of play.  Is NOT commentary on tournament scene, "net decks," or individual sets or cards.

My first introduction to "real" gaming, back in 94.  Revolutionary concept.  I loved the game, played it daily, spent hours deck building every week, etc.  I blissfully ignored the money-grubbing tactics of WotC (Type 2?  You mean, I HAVE to buy new cards to play in tourneys?), played T1 games with my friends, etc.  I even bought several boxes of each set, although I only played with MAYBE 5% of the cards.

Then, WotC went one step too far, and lost a customer.  I sold my 15,000 card collection (Alpha through Urza's Saga or whatever).  Why?  

FOIL CARDS.




A few years later, I acquired a few collections, and have ~25,000 cards now.  I rarely play with them, and have no intention of buying any new cards.  The gameplay, artwork, and just game design is just too good, I wanted to at least have the option of playing in the future...especially with my kids.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8.5
One of the few games that actually supports the concept of "strategy", by allowing you to decide exactly how you want to go about fighting. It allows an immense range of creativity and planning, while still leaving your eventual fate up to a bit of luck and tactical skill.

Possibly, among all the clones and competitors there is a better game, but I have not played any of them.

Personally, I'm happy to build decks out of a static pool of a few hundred cards. I don't see any value in constantly purchasing booster packs and new sets. The financial complaint that many have against the game seems to be more an issue of them, than the game. Getting into an arms race of finding bigger and better cards is a pointless exercise. The game is fun when you have two decks that are competitive with one another, not when you have a deck that can wallop all other decks, and you can make paired decks with any starting set of cards to choose from.

The principal issue with the game is really one that there's an intrinsic issue with a game that allows creativity, comboing, and synergies. In one deck, a card might be worth 1 mana. In another deck, that same card might be worth 10 mana. In actuality, it might be priced as 4 mana. It's fundamentally impossible to assign an accurate price to any card, and this makes it impossible to compare decks to one another through any other means than dueling a few dozen times. And, of course, it drives the engine that propels people on the spending frenzy to find cards which are underpriced in mana compared to their strength in game.

I doubt that this problem has been solved by any other Magic-like game, except by making cards with powers that are non-creative and purely additive. And that's just not interesting. But so I don't feel like there's value in trying other games of the same type. You may as well stick to Magic as it has the most variety available, and the largest player base.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
I started playing in Alpha. Took a break after The Dark. Finally got back into it a few years ago with 8th Edition. Great filler. I don't do serious deck construction, mostly use the pre-built decks and some random boosters in mock drafts. Without qualification, the best gameplay of any CCG I've ever played.

RATING: 10

I owe so much to this game that I can honestly say it changed my life, not something you can say often about anything. 

The deckbulding is deep (albeit a bit killed by the internetas far as i'm concerned), limited play requires so much skill and the actual playing requires another set of skills. A fantastic game that I regret pratically not playing any longer due to a lack of time for the investment it requires.

Hours dicussing picks in a draft, slot in a deck or a card potential in general, good times.

I turned to the boardgames to replace it when I no longer had the time to play it (oddly enough it coincides with the arrival of the children, maybe there's a link?).

Forever special to me.

PLaying again, got back thanks to cubedrafting.

RATING: 9
A game so deep it intimidates me a little, especially in a format like extended or (God forbid) vintage. Playing with a group that only uses a pre-constructed deck plus a single booster draft is a fun and cheap way to keep the field fairly level. If you can find a circle of friends that don't want to powergame you to death by sinking huge piles of cash into their deck, this game can be a lot of fun. Don't go to any tournaments, though. It will ruin you.

RATING: 6.5
Well, what can I say. This game has entertained me for the last 6 years, and only recently my interest in it is disappearing. Much money went in to it, and much entertainment has come out of it.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9.5
I played from Revised up through Shards. The game is incredible, and the community that has risen up around it is great. You could always play a net deck if you were feeling uninspired, but nothing to me was more satisfying than coming up with your own deck and crushing your friends, especially in some janky way. So if it is so great, why did I get rid of it? Honestly it was the money sink, which is a hazard with any CCG (or hobby in general I suppose). I found myself paying more and more and playing less and less. As IRL people kept falling off the wayside of playing this game, I turned to Magic Online, but I would continually find myself playing jerks - they either taunt you when they are winning or they gripe continually of you being a "lucksack" if they were losing and then timing out their connection. I just found myself having no fun playing anymore, so I had to let it go. Every once in a while I check in on the state of the game, and it makes me want to start playing again, but that ship has sailed.  
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

Stopped playing in high school and thought I'd never touch it again. Got the itch to play again after looking at some old cards my fiancee had stashed at her parents' place. Still pretty much as I remember it and I seem to enjoy it as much as last time. Just going to try and avoid the obsessive collecting side of the game.

RATING: 9
Well, back when this first came out I picked up two starter decks (for me and my sister) to have a bash at. Bugger me if we did not get about 10 of our friends in to this game as a result. I have never played club or tournament games. This is a game among friends. It is a blast, easy to learn but hard to master game that can last up to about 20 minutes or so. 

The collectible aspect is appealing to me since I enjoy that sort of thing. But for many folks, the randomness of the boosters is a pain in the tail. Having said that, this game is worth playing and worth investing in providing you have a the very least 1 or 2 friends to play with :)

RATING: 9
Peasant/pauper formats are where it's AT!

Update: For under $50 (including shipping), I netted complete common sets for Lorwyn, Morningtide, Shadowmoor, and Eventide. In eliminating the collectible aspect and balance issues between sets by purchasing a whole block's worth of cards to use as a common card pool for all players, I've fallen head over heels for Magic again. I like the Lorwyn/Shadowmoor block best, too, with its storybook fantasy setting and the tribal nature of the cards - you get Faerie decks, Goblins, Giants, Treefolk, Merfolk, Elves, Elementals, etc., so the theme even feels a lot more cohesive. 

By the way, my black Rogues deck will destroy you.

RATING: 6.5
[ESP] Magic, que nostalgia.
Cuando comencé a salir con mi esposo descubrimos Magic y nos encantó. Nos pusimos medio adictos y cada cierto tiempo comprabamos nuevas cartas.
Es un gran juego, está bien diseñado. En esa época claramente le habría puesto un 9 o 10. Pero con el pasar del tiempo, el crecimiento de mi ludoteca y los años que tengo encima ha bajado su nota ya que prefiero otros juegos. Creo que mi esposo en cambio seguirá pensando en él como un 9 o 10.
Siempre le tendré cariño, razón por la cual aún conservamos los mazos y las miles de cartas adicionales en carpetas.

RATING: 10
It's hard to say anything new or interesting about the game that has changed gaming so fundamentally, in terms of new audiences, mechanics, and business model. M:TG is simply a revolutionary game, a landmark in gaming history that  will affect how we play games for decades to come. I can't think of another game as innovative *and* successful as this one.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
I first played this game almost two decades ago. It was easily the most eye opening gaming experiences in my life. Over time I got involved in competitive play and then eventually stopped playing when I came to realize competitive Magic was about the cards (aka the money) rather than the player (a problem all TGCs will always suffer from to some extent) to an extreme level. It was never designed for tournament level competition. I've played other quality TGC's since then, but eventually they die off. I tried Magic again a little over a year ago and found my enthusiasm for it rekindled. The many years of developing the game for professional level competition has done it a world of good. It's much better balanced for competitive play and yet still retains the "magic" it had as an underground indie card game.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
I had a negative review of this game for some time, but I think a more moderate one is more accurate.  The mechanics are not difficult to learn, and the gameplay is generally smooth.  The collectible aspect (and the frequency of new sets) makes serious play pretty restrictive price-wise.

I don't find constructed play terribly fun these days, especially with competitive players who spend a lot more money on the game than I have any inclination to do, but I LOVE drafts.  I think every Magic player (even casual) should give them a try.  A TREMENDOUS amount of fun, and generally not expensive (friends can do it for the cost of a few packs).

Lately, I've discovered Commander.  Let me tell you- that alone is worth playing this game for :)

RATING: 6
I never really got into CCGs because of the price barrier. Earl brought in some theme decks today and taught me 10th edition. It was fun, even if I got slaughtered three games out of four. I'd be more than willing to play again, but I still don't really want to get into spending money for it.

RATING: 7.5
This is a very clever game. More strategy, and options for different strategies in this game than probably any other game that I can think of. Lot of fun too. The artwork and themes are cool. 

There are enormous cons to this game though. One, it's way too expensive and some cards are just way too good. Basically whomever has the best cards will probably win. Thus I'm not sure how much this game really rewards skill. I probably won't play this game anymore because of these negatives.

RATING: 8.75

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9.5
Was quite obsessed with the game in my early through mid 20s, spent thousands upon thousands of dollars on collecting the cards. These days, I only have a few starter decks and try not to fall into the old habit, but it is truly a tremendous game...in fact it's the best card game ever, not only for the artwork, concept, influence and collectible elements but also for the supremely intuitive and adaptable gameplay. Haters gonna hate it, or whine because they weren't able to collect it all, and yeah over the years there are some really broken combos (always happens in a game with this durability), but on a design/theme level it is typically flawless.

Booster Boxes: Shadows Over Innistrad x1, Eldritch Moon x1, Kaladesh x1, Aether Revolt x1, Amonkhet x1, Hour of Devastation x1

Various Starter Decks, Intro Decks, Duel Decks (listed elsewhere), Archenemy: Nicol Bolas, Planechase Anthology.

Thousands of other cards, bulk lots, etc.

RATING: 8

To jump on the 2 year rotation circus is stupid and no basis to rate the fun of this game.

RATING: 9

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
I used to own my own gaming store, so I have over 100,000 cards and ran several tournaments a week for about 5 years.  I have been playing since I was 11 (4th Edition had just come out in 1995) and still love the game today.

Only major downside is it does require all players involved to have their own collection.  The game is very well balanced as long as both players have cards from similar sets and play within certain formats.  Can be a bit unfair when one player only has cards from most recent set and the other player plays with cards from older sets (thus not playing within one of the regular formats).  One of the best collectible card games out there!

Note: I am looking to trade off or sell most of my collection.  I have from Innistrad and forward up to Khans of Tarkir.  Lots of decent stuff for Modern.  Message me if you are interested.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

A note to people looking to trade:

I only played the old format fronts (The formatting for the cards changed somewhere around 5th/6th edition). I'm missing more cards as we approach the later part, but towards revised I have every card if not nearly every card (Basically, from The Dark to the Rath Cycle I have several complete sets). I have lots of extras from this time and have zero interest in the newer cards.

Thank you!

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
Probably my favorite table top game because these were some of my best memories from college.  We didn't have the best cards but I had the most fun making crazy decks built around random (ie. available) cards.  I don't play competitively anymore due to a lack of players but I will leaf through a box or deck and think of something new to tweak.  I'll still buy singles every now and then either for the decks or just for the cool artwork.  Second to chess, this game has the longest shelf-life for me.  Only reason I didn't give this a 10 is because of the CCG aspect, but the game is flexible enough that you don't need the latest/greatest to have fun.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
Despite it's players' reputation of being male huge geeks with absolutely no life and/or social skills (which, sadly, has a basis but I am none of these) the game itself is awesome! As a very flexible game it has several different ways to play called 'formats' and one could play it casually at home very easily. Recommend to everyone who loves fantasy and strategy and the freedom of building your own deck. The downside is that it can get costly, but for a player buying a booster (15 extra cards randomly from the set) it always feels like opening a gift. If it makes you happy, the cost of anything isn't a problem that is what I think.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
Brilliant game. The grand daddy of the ccg genre and, in my humble opinion, still the best.

I used to play in tourneys but simply don't have the time anymore - the game has an immense amount of depth for the truly dedicated to explore.

For general gamers looking to get a taste I'd suggest grabbing a few theme (pre-generated boxed) decks for your collection to try it out. You can then expand your collection and options by buying additional cards as and when you can afford/the whim takes you, which opens up whole new strategies and options depending on the cards you purchase.

Excellent value for money - only a money sink if you choose to compete at a high level or wish to have complete collections.

If you see it purely as a fun game to play every now and again then it can be a lot of fun for very little outlay.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 5
A rather addictive Collectible Card Game which I definitely do not recommend due to its compulsive nature. The game itself is fun and definitely deserves a higher rating, but the fact that it is nearly impossible to actually play a satisfying game of M:tG as opposed to just constantly improve your deck ad nauseam without anyone to pit it against makes me wonder if I should rate it even lower. If you are eager to try it out, I suggest buying huge collections of old cards available cheap from eBay, constructing balanced decks, enjoying casual play with those and ignoring the newer editions, otherwise prepare yourself for throwing a LOT of money down the drain.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 3
Ignoring the business-model of MTG, I find it mildly entertaining at best. But unfortunately, that CCG-business-model really turns the game into something different. For one, it dilutes the quality/integrity of the game. But it also turns the game into some lottery where booster packs are tickets for a different type of "currency." And that gambling-aspect is something that really hooks people, especially adolescents who can't participate in a traditional lottery.

RATING: 6
Nagyon rég szemezgettem már ezzel a játékkal, figyelemfelkeltő volt a BGG-listában szereplő kép róla. Csak nemrég tudtam meg, hogy ez a kép egy kártya hátlapja, merthogy ez egy kártyajáték. A játszós barátok óva is intettek: vigyázz, ez gyüjtögetős kártya, el ne kezdd gyűjteni:) Nos nem akarom gyűjteni (állítólag a 17 év alatt 20-30 ezer féle kártya jelent meg:), de egy kipróbálást megért).
60 lapos paklit kell összeállítanunk, tetszésünk, és pénztárcánk szerint, az eddig megjelent sok ezer lapból. A saját paklinkkal bárki ellen leülhetünk, és megmérkőzhetünk az ő 60 lapos paklijával. 5 féle szín van, minden szín más képességekben erős, a paklinkban ezek a színek keveredhetnek. Van lepakolási feltétele (költsége) a lapoknak, van támadó/védőerő...
Egész jó játék, egy bonyolultabb támadásnál elég sok agyalás szükséges, ez már a próbajáték során kiderült.
Összességében tetszett! Játszani szeretnék még vele. 
Több agyon ajnározott játék meg se közelítette ezt élményben (rftg, dominion)... Erről ennyit:)
Nyelvfüggő a játék, de talán még az én angolom is elég hozzá.

RATING: 7
I enjoy the gameplay and mechanics of MtG a lot. It's clearly one of the best two player card games ever designed. Too bad that I don't enjoy the deck construction aspect of the game at all. I don't want to be thinking about the composition of my deck when I'm not playing the game. And I don't like the "buy yet another Deck of the Month" aspect of the more competitive side of the game.

It's always fun to play the game for a while with friends until someone (usually me) will start upgrading their deck with more powerful cards and decimating the opposition, and subsequently sucking the fun out of the game. Just give me two equally balanced duel decks and I'll be happy.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
I would like the game a lot more if it wasn't such a money sink.

For little money, you can get a Deck builder's toolkit, a few boosters, and/or a starter deck or two. This will give you a great game on its own, with friends, maybe with a few guys you meet at your college. It'll give you endless fun, and little more in the gaming world beats the thrill of buying a few boosters, ripping them open, and tweaking your decks with your new cards. I have a few hundred cards and I always love a game of MtG with newfound and old friends. For this, I'll give it at least a 7. But...

If you want to play casually with your local MtG community, you're gonna need $30-70 for a single deck to remain competitive. In about 6 months, you're going to need to pay 30-70 more dollars to rebuild your new deck as the new mechanics and power creep will render your old deck noncompetitive. Then you'll probably want another $20 for deck building toolkit (as apposed to your competitive deck) to give you more variety when playing relatively more casual players. For this, I can't give it anything more than a 7.

Note, I'm using the word competitive as in, "it can keep pace with with the other decks played by your local MtG community," not "to be used in competitions, tournaments, etc." Maybe your local MtG will be more casual than mine, but at least where I lived (a very affluent community, admittedly), MtG players would scoff when you say you're not ready to put $50 down on a new deck.

If you want to be more serious, expect to spend *at least* $100 or more ($300 for "competition ready") per deck.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
Magic is the only single thing that has been with me from early high school, to college, to a wife and two children and beyond. While there have been plenty of peaks and valleys in my year-to-year involvement with the game, my overall love and enjoyment of the game has never left me. From every issue of the Duelist to every weekly update of the website, I have followed the evolution of Magic with unfailing appreciation, dedication, and marvel. The game of Magic is indeed excellent, but it is the Metagame by Wizards of the Coast and others that I enjoy more to observe, track, analyze, and yes, even be a part of. Magic is a world unto itself, a creation much larger than either its parts or its creator. This world would not exist were it not for the vast talent, foresight, and thoughtfulness of Richard Garfield and the game's other creators, be they from original days or of current times. The game is an ocean of riches, sometimes undulating slowly and methodically while other times pulling everything and everyone that it touches into a torrential hurricane. But either way, I have for many years been swept into its current and happily enjoying the ride.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 1
A horrible, clunky game with few redeeming features.  This is another game that has a huge following that simply can't be justified by any rationale.  The rules in the rulebook are overly complicated, and then each card has its own complex and often inscrutable rules, making the whole Magic experience one of chaos and frustration.  In my view the fact that this game has so many devotees should be the subject of a psychology treatise.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Too commercial but the game IS very very good in standard play with (only) the last two expansions allowed.
Certainly a card wargame. The cards get recycled every two years. So if playing on an "extended basis" (allowing older cards from earlier editions), the game is no longer fun as too powerful combinations ruin the game play. So keep in mind: you are investing an awful lot of money (200 - 500 $) in a card set that's obsolete in 20 months time.
On the other hand, most PC games these days have a life time of 12 months or less.
I downgraded mtg with 1.5 points to a score of 8. The reason is that after coming back to this game after a few years, your old cards are worthless for standard or even extended play.

And if you still want to play with your 3+ year old cards, you fall into an unplayable game where card combos are simply so powerful it isn't even funny anymore. I played 2 games like that with the few cards I still had with magic on line and the only thing I could do is watch after the 3rd turn for ... 5 minutes to see me slaughtered without even having a 4rd turn.

So in this way the game is terrible. It is an unbalanced piece of 13.000 cards monster.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 9
[i]Posted: 5/15/06, Rated: 9[/i]

I love this game.  I fear this game.

Over ten years ago, I was really into [i]M:tG,[/i] at least by my own standards.  I loved collecting the cards.  I obsessed over tuning my decks.  I never played in tournaments, but I held my own in pick-up games.  I constantly found ways to spend more money.  Collectible Card Games (CCG's) are universally evil in this regard.

Looking past its insidious nature, the game itself is awesome.  The mechanics are clean, the objectives simple.  I love the artwork on the cards, and they have withstood the test of time well.  I am sure that it would be a blast to go back and revisit this game.

Yet I am concerned about sharing it with my two sons.  The last thing I need to do is foster another CCG addiction.  I am already trying to rein in their collecting of [i][thing=2165]Pokémon[/thing][/i] and [i][thing=4154]Yu-Gi-Oh![/thing][/i] cards, when they don't even know how to [i]play[/i] those games.

Ultimately, I will share [i]M:tG[/i] with them, without regard to which cards are currently legal, or how many can be included in a deck, etc.  After kicking the habit once, hopefully I can spike that vein again without succumbing to the temptation of buying more.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

Still, a timeless and classic game (if you can avoid its downfalls).

RATING: 8
If I ever get caught buying another pack someone should beat me with a wrench.

I first played MTG in 1998-ish. I played casually up until the middle of the Kamigawa block. After that it was random draft tournaments every few years. In college we did several. That was more than enough for me.
In the middle of 2016 I tried jumping back in after a move to a city were MTG was the only thing the locals played. Modern, Commander, and Standard were just a bit too much $$ for the enjoyment. Cut my losses and have decided to move on, I'd rather buy a good euro or an expansion or Legendary than more MTG cards.

RATING: 7
Used to collect when I was younger and had a big group of friends that would come together in up to 6 player games of MTG with special rules.

Right now it's more nostalgia then anything and if you wanted a great deck  in the current edition you had to pay a great deal of money to get the cards. As things are now magic has a very active second hand market and while old cards might still be expensive to buy seperatly you can easily get lucky at ebay or other trading websites and buy cards in stock at a very low cost. 

Right now I own around 3000 magic cards and 99% from the older series. That's where the fun is for me but since the game is so hugely diverse everyone can find a way to enjoy it with their friends. If you are new a good way to start is by buying inexpensive preconstructed decks.

While some cards go for ridiculous sums of money you can still make great decks with inexpensive and more common ones.

Best played casually with friends
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 5
MTG was my gateway drug, if you will, into the wider world of gaming; it was my first taste of collecting something and playing with friends in a truly competitive atmosphere.  Because of those fateful lunch sessions sitting in cafeteria quickly devouring our food to maximize the time we could play a few games before going back to class, MTG will always have a special place in my heart *fights back tears* ;).

What I've come to realize, though, and the reason for my "5" rating is this: I think that good games (card/board/dice/etc) need to have one key component, accessibility, which is severely lacking from MTG.  Whereas in my younger years I thought that the randomization of cards in boosters was novel and exciting and the potential to find a super-awesome card that would be worth tons of money and could give me an edge in game play worth the risk of getting nothing, I now see these two factors as unnecessary hype that's little more than a ploy to make more money.  

I spent so much money on the meager collection that I had amassed (a few thousand cards, mind you), and what did that do for me?  It still left me with holes in my collections because those few cards I really wanted seemed ever elusive and there were always other cards that I had just learned about that "would make my deck so much better."

So ... I think MTG was one of the best games I ever played ... and it pains me a little to give it a low rating ... but because at the end of the day it ends up being a game best suited for the rich or foolish, it no longer does it for me.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7.5
I would mostly suggest Pauper, Commander, and Cube Draft. It can be a truly addicting lifestyle game and I am prone to relapsing into it but trying to recover through growing my board game collection (because buying a lot of games will save me money). Try not to slip into paying far too much for decks, but worth picking up some cards for cheap (you can get boxes of commons from card stores for less than most games) and building some casual decks.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7.5
I really feel like Magic has grown so large, that it is really a hobby unto itself now. A lifestyle game. If I was actively playing still, the rating would be higher.

Started when Unlimited and Arabian Nights were still for sale. Won AL State Championship and Top 8 at SE Regionals for a trip to Nationals. Stopped buying around 2002 with Judgement. There is not a game that I've played more or that has given me as much joy. Still think fondly of, but do not purchase any longer. One problem was the amount of money it cost to stay competitive as you have to continue to buy the new expansions. Another problem is a new player has very little chance vs. an experienced player. It remains a favorite that I play some casually. I have a few of my tournament decks from 2000 - 2002 ready to play. As fun as it is to play, it may be more fun to create decks prior to playing. I would still be playing in tournaments if not for obligations to wife and daughters.

RATING: 10
10/10. Review forthcoming.

NOTE: This review does [u][b]not[/b][/u] take into account the cost of playing the game competitively. If you are heavily interested in Magic -- whether as a collectable, a game, a competitive outlet, or all of the above -- the cost is well within reason (a competitive Modern deck can be had for between $300 and $800, and can subsequently be sold for a good portion of that cost), and of course budget concessions and smart purchasing (making do with substitutes until cards rotate out of Standard or are reprinted, etc.) can offset a lot of the cost.

RATING: 4
I played this back in 3rd edition, just before Ice Age came out, and...  just kinda got tired of it.  I found making a flying blue and white deck was just too easy to win.

Flying is normally a weaker-per-manna cost, but white protection spells make them almost invincible.

Which, this was ok and everything, but it seemed like playing with anything else other than a 70% win ratio, once you knew how to get it, was like purposefully handicapping yourself to make the game interesting. At which point, you could make-up a lot of rules to purposefully make things difficult.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
[b]Luck:[/b] While it is true that the luck factor can easily swing a game of Magic, good deck building, mulliganing and multiple games (best 2 of 3 or 3 of 5) can largely mitigate a lot of this luck. Even so it is still frustrating to loose a game due to being mana short or mana flooded.

[b]Tactics/Strategy:[/b] While the kind of deck you are playing does affect this, Magic is chock full of tactical and strategic decisions, even going as far as the type of deck you play and your choice of sideboard cards.

[b]Weight:[/b] For casual Magic i would put it in the Light/Medium category, but at a professional level this is definitely a Medium/Heavy game.

[b]Fun:[/b] Like a lot of games the fun of Magic depends on the people you are playing against. Tournament caliber decks used against casual players can ruin the fun for everyone.

[b]Conclusion:[/b] Despite it's flaws Magic is a game which has managed to stay fresh and fun for many years and i don't expect this to change anytime soon.

RATING: 6
The most cost effective way to play is to find 7 other friends and do a booster draft.  So far its been great.  Everyone has limited resources (cards) and you do what you can with what you got.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
I have gone through sporadic levels of interest with this game, which was probably as high as a 10 and as low as a 6 at various points in time.  It is incredibly well designed with cool artwork, cohesive rules that were made more accessible over the years, and constantly changing gameplay.

Of course, the constantly changing gameplay comes from the constantly changing cards, which in CCG terms means a constantly empty pocket.  Every 4 months, Wizard releases a new set, and if you want to play competitively you need to buy buy buy.  Don't listen to anyone who tells you "you only need a starter to play"; if you want to get any sort of real enjoyment out of this game you need to spend money.  The people who invest can field decks that are competitive and fun; the people who can't, well, don't.  An alternative is a booster draft, which means buying three packs ($9-15) for a one-time play.  The advantage is if you have a group who all play magic, you can turn this into a mini-tournament and get enough enjoyment out of it for a few hours to a days worth of play.

I managed to work myself into the top 0.2% of players worldwide online based on my ELO-sytle rating.  The online game is a cash cow but I was at a good enough skill level that I could "go infinite"; that is, my winnings in prizes were of greater value than my losses, so I didn't need to pay anything to play.

However, even thought I was playing for free, I eventually decided to sell all my product and quit.  The game stagnates after awhile, and you just have to stay too in-tuned with the current landscape of cards and metagame.  The whole thing was just way too time consuming for what I was getting out of it.

So, this game was certainly a companion to my gaming for a long time.  While I don't think I would ever suggest a game to anyone (my friends nowadays are not magic fans), I have to admit if a bunch of people asked me to booster draft, or I wandered across a sealed tournament, I would probably jump at the opportunity to join.  MTG is a very fun game; just be prepared to put a lot of time and money into it if you want to reap enjoyment from it.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

This is how Wizards of the Coast prints money.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
Will play occasionally if in the right mood.

There are two things that I really dislike about MTG and it is dampening my enthusiasm for the game:

1. Pay to Win. If your opponent has a much better deck than you - then the majority of the time, you are going to lose. No matter what you try to do, you will be obliterated. This can be mitigated by different formats, say by building a balanced cube, and drafting from that.

2. Mana flood/starve. Those totally miserable games when you can't do anything as either you just keep drawing mana or the opposite, where you can't get any.

Due to these balance issues MTG has just become a casual, filler game for me, where I am happy to knock out a couple of games before playing something else.

RATING: 8
The best CCG with tons of variety and fun stuff, but since it's a CCG:

1) Very unbalanced since all decks are made before the game.
2) Overpriced.
3) Pay-to-win.
4) Not many choices are made during the game, 
5) The metagame is already somewhat well-known.
6) Building a deck from scratch ("limited" mode) takes forever.

But again, tons of variety and fun stuff, so it's worth dabbling in in one way or another. The players generally agree it has these problems, but it still has so much stuff.

UPDATE Aug. 2nd 2011: Started playing Cube Draft slightly more often, and love it as a format! I have built cubes (which is half the fun now) from various complete blocks (Ice Age, Ravnica, Shards of Alara) and lots of my old crap cards. Having a lot of fun experimenting with different card sets and drafting methods.

UPDATE Mar. 6th 2012: Playing more regularly with old friends that are all ex-players. We're playing a variety of formats, from Cube, to sealed, to pre-cons, and both 1 vs. 1 and multi-player. I'd forgotten just how much I liked this game, but eliminating one of the major sore spots for me (collectible format) has brought back the shine.

RATING: 9
Perhaps the best game system ever invented?

I played this for many years, went to PTQs, Nationals, even a couple Pro-tours.
Mana-screw and trying to keep up with all the sets eventually killed it for me.

I would still probably play this if I could (cheaply) have access to all the cards in the current rotation so I could easily build any deck.  Then again, even the time commitment to keep up with current deck technology is prohibitive.  Its kindof nice learning about totally different games here on the geek rather than trying to keep up with each new deck style.

Limited formats were interesting, however I would get tired of mana-screw.  And yes I did use 17 lands in a 40 card deck, usually with alternate mana-sources as well, and I still would get mana-screwed sometimes.  Quite often (say at least 25% of the time) a match would be decided by who got mana-screwed the least.

Ah well its still a very fun game, sometimes I miss it.

Edit: I started playing again :)

RATING: 10
I've played Magic for over 15 years now, and I doubt that I will ever tire of it.  In fact, I become more involved with it each year.

This is a game with fairly straightforward premise (one can get the gist of the rules by watching a single game) expands so deeply with its rulebreaking nature.  It leads to a near infinite depth of exploration, such that I doubt any other game will match it.

I think Bruno Faidutti said it best, "In Magic, Richard Garfield didn't simply create a game, he created a myriad of possible games for players to explore."

The game itself is amazing. I love the wide variety of decks one can come against, draft & sealed are very engaging, and the art is second-to-none. Honestly, the downsides to this game are simple - cost & community. 

It is *the* premiere CCG and so costs a tonne to get into. Individual slips of cardboard you would like to use are easily sold for ~$60. There are, no kidding, cards that sell for sums in excess $30,000. It is, without doubt, the most expensive game I've ever played.

With the above in mind, the community is *highly* competitive. This may be your thing, but if it isn't - you'll find if hard to locate a group of people who are just casual players. After all, it is hard not to be "serious" about a game that you (over time) spend in thousands of dollars on.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
Battle box and sealed!
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8.5
What to say about this game? The "card-board crack" description sounds like a throw away line but there is more truth to it than I like to admit (having heavily succumbed to its lure at one time in my life).

Truth is, it is an amazingly clever game - seemingly simple on the surface and very accessible but with astonishing depth. Deck building is just the beginning. The game is truly innovative and brilliantly conceived.

But, after a period of absolute immersion, I finally had to completely turn my back on the game. As brilliant as it is, in the end it is just a money suck as all CCGs are at heart. M:tG will continue to outlast all the others simply on the strength of the game design itself which is sheer genius. But, as a CCG, it ultimately betrays the people who love it the most. Tragic really...

Imagine if in Agricola you could just spend more money to buy some personal booster packs, and one card you could buy is an Occupation card that gives you 5 of every resource and 5 food every round, as soon as you are able to play it. That's what this felt like. Like, why bother playing?

   Longevity.  Magic defines it.  I played dozens of games as a youth, and now have played dozens as a parent.

   The primary lure for me continues to be the artwork.  Few games can hold a light to Magic.  There are just so many beautiful cards...

   Gameplay is often frustratingly mixed though with too much land - or too little, too many cards with high casting cost, or poorly matched decks.  You have to play through those tough draws for memorable matches.

RATING: 10

If it was not a money sink, this game would be a 10.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
Rating for booster draft and Cube draft only.

I never liked constructed play in Magic. I tried to like it, but I hate that pay-to-win aspect of it. Even with the money issue set aside, I find that playing with constructed decks tends to be boring, as you end up playing the same decks over and over again. Unless you happen to have two very balanced decks, one deck will  win consistently, with the exception of bad draws. The deckbuilding can be fun, but you need a huge card pool to build something interesting. And at a competitive level, especially in formats such as Vintage or Legacy, the game can become degenerated (first turn wins) as a result of broken cards and combos.

In contrast to that, Limited play has become my one of my all-time favorite and most played games. In a draft all the good comes together and all the bad is eliminated: Everybody has access to the same limited card pool; deckbuilding in the form of drafting is part of the game which is immense fun on its own; playing relatively weak draft decks is actually more fun than playing optimized constructed decks; you only play the same deck for a few matches; and with the steady release of new blocks, there is always variety in booster drafts; and last but not least it's affordable.

The only thing better than a booster draft is a Cube draft. A Cube is a collection of the best magic cards, usually singleton, rarity doesn't matter, from which you create random "boosters" to do a draft. Incredible powerful cards from all sets, interesting synergies and classic combos all come together, but the decks are still not brokenly good like constructed legacy decks and fun to play. In a singleton format you can even play with the most powerful and broken cards, as any deck will only feature a few of them. 

About the gameplay: the worst part is bad draws, typically in the form of mana screw (not drawing enough lands). This can be reduced by building better decks with a low mana curve and/or enough mana fixers and mana ramp, but it will still happen every so often. The key to have fun despite this is to play quickly, forfeit if necessary, and move on to the next game.

It takes a lot of skill to play well. In our draft mini-tournaments there is one player who consistently wins more than anybody else, first because he often drafts better decks and, more importantly, because he makes less playing mistakes. Knowing the cards, knowing what to play and *when* to play a card makes all the difference.

Besides 1-on-1, there exist also many fun multiplayer variants, like Two-headed Giant. A downside with multiplayer variants is that they usually take much longer and therefore bad draws are more annoying.

[microbadge=14][microbadge=29032]

# of players: [bgcolor=#00CC00] 2 [/bgcolor][bgcolor=#99FFFF] 3 [/bgcolor][bgcolor=#00CC00] 4 [/bgcolor][bgcolor=#99FFFF] 5 [/bgcolor][bgcolor=#00CC00] 6 [bgcolor=#99FFFF] 7 [/bgcolor] [b]8[/b] [/bgcolor]
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 7
Fun game with complicated rules.  The only way to get the rules is online.

Deck building is a meta-game that can be more time consuming than playing the game itself.  You first need to build a deck, and collecting the cards can be expensive.  You can avoid this by buying pre-constructed decks, but the preconstructed decks are usually flawed.  Sometimes people will not want to play with you if you have older cards.

Dueling can be fun.  Multiplayer games do not scale as well and usually end up in drawn out stand offs.

RATING: 9
THE CCG! Forget your pokemon or your Lot5R, this is the original and the best. They didn't call it cardboard crack for nothing. The depth of the game mechanics is awe inspiring and the theme is nicely balanced with playability so that neither overwhelms the other. To keep the whole thing working while regularly expanding, adding and subtracting from the set is a balancing act that boggles the mind. Yes there are too many expansions and the need to keep up is a pain, but that doesn't mean you can't find your level or come and go as you like (and can afford). Don't know if you can call yourself a gamer unless you've "chased the cardboard dragon" for at least one expansion.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

I am not a fan of speed decks or denial decks, which suck the fun out of the room.

Scored higher than I might otherwise for originality.

RATING: 5
Sequence: (1) Pre-built decks -- for learning. (2) Winston draft with loose cards. Note: I think the way a Winston draft works is each player ends up with 45 cards from the initial 90-card draw pile; THEN each player constructs a deck of 40-60 cards, using a SUBSET of the 45 cards drawn (so you don't use ALL of them), plus a bunch of land cards -- for 40, it's typically 23 spells 17 lands.

VERY good explanations of cubes: [thread=555781][/thread]
[article=6125329][/article]
[thread=587144][/thread]
[thread=382910][/thread]

Winston:
http://www.ehow.com/how_2278204_hold-winston-draft-magic-gathering.html
http://card-games.suite101.com/article.cfm/magic_the_gathering_winston_draft

Zeddemore: [thread=524572][/thread]

RATING: 8
Causal player from Mirage to Kamigawa (plus a little Lorwyn and Alara).  I regrettably don't play as often as I used to.  As a game designer, I am forever indebted to the thousand lessons MTG has taught me.

The range of strategic options is staggering.  One can lose himself in the galactic scope of things, either trying to take the whole thing in or obsessing over tiny details.  Magic is all that it is because of rigorous playtesting, and it shows.

I'm adding my collection to Colnect so that I can swap individual cards.  You should, too.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
Great game, although there are some rather obvious issues with the number of cards available ... I liked playing in the Mirage-Visions-Weatherlight environment, but that&#039;s a bit old now. The history of Magic really breaks down into two parts, pre-Ice Age and Ice Age and later. Pre Ice-Age is a lousy game, centered around a handful of rediculously powerful cards (original Icy Manipulator, anyone?), an environment that is eminantly avoidable. The more modern sets (starting with Alliances, the first truly great set) are much more balanced and interesting, striking just the right balance between power and balance, with a much wider variety of successful deck archytypes, at least for casual play. However, at the end of the day, this game is really about the deck building. I recently did some pre-constructed deck play, and as good as the deck-building is, the underlying game does not have enough control or tactical depth to be interesting on it&#039;s own.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

Am FINALLY learning to play this with nephews. So much fun strategizing but I fall into the trap of choosing cards based on artwork...(see comment on Masterpiece below.)

Would not recommend to anyone who does not have a great deal of time and money, as the game can become horribly addictive.  Still, one of the most interesting, surprising and fun games I have played.

RATING: 1.6
Bought two decks when it first came out. Didn't see what the fuss was about.

Then I watched, incredulous, as people walked into my local game shop and bought entire boxes of decks and boosters. Didn't want any part of it.

I want to give it both a 1 and a 6 to try and give it its due because it's both simultaneously okay and downright awful.

As a game its decent - with workable preconstructed decks it can be okay, although I think deck construction and draw significantly outweighs decision making in importance. Playing a 1993 starter deck was really tedious, but the money sink alternative was even less attractive.

As a meta-game system and economic model, it's a horrendous ever-growing mess.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Conflicted rating this game.  I enjoy it in a limited way.

Once your deck is created, you follow the direction of the cards.  You make obvious choices, like following a script.

Initially there are more difficult choices, but only if you have land cards--no land cards, no choices.  While in the middle of the game, you played your hand so you draw a card and play a card.  Again it seems like I am merely following a script that I wrote.

Deck building, the "script writing" is marvelous.  You have all this options to create the ultimate combos and test it and play it to fine tune it.  But alas, you need lots of money to have access to lots of cards, to make an interesting deck.

I now understand what Garfield meant, by ."..cards play you."

Not interested enough to spend a small fortune to play.  Playing the MTG Forge AI now and perhaps I will buy a prebuilt deck from someday.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 6
[6/11/2007]
I WAS ASKED THE FOLLOWING:
M:tg isn't for everyone. You give it a 6. Fair enough. What is the highlight of M:tg for you?

MY ANSWER:

No real highlights. I played it and then asked being quite disappointed: "Is that it?!? That's what all the fuss was about...?"

Don't get me wrong. I don't dislike it. It gets a 6. That's above my average, albeit only very slightly. I could have fun with it and enjoy further intricacies unfolding themselves as you get more into it.

But the whole idea of deck construction (El Grande's very limited K&I deck "construction" is probably my limit in that respect!) and the collectible nature of the game, is a major turn-off for me! Collectible means "perpetually deficient" to me. I can't stand that. I want a HOLISTIC gaming experience!

[OLD COMMENT]This is the game all the fuss was made about? The collectible nature certainly is not for me (I want a complete game!), but the game's fun enough nonetheless.

I think sealed/draft is one of the best ways to play the game anyways as it keeps players on the same playing field and rewards deck building skills.

RATING: 2
Ability to have fun (whether your fun is building cool decks or winning) is proportional to the amount of money you spend. This is why the rating is so low for the game as written.

However, I do own the game as I play Silverblack with my partner from the same pool of cards. This keeps the game affordable (cheaper than an LCG) because Silverblack playsets are subsidised by people chasing rares/mythics and because we can avoid purchasing singles. This way fun can be had and the winner isn't determined by pocket depth.

In the future we intend to try out the coöp enemy-decks as well as the horde variant (which I will print out using artscow or some such, I will certainly not build the decks through the singles market).

OWNED

Amonkhet Silverblack playset

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
The artwork and the,e are both amazing and the gameplay is varied. It is also fun to sit around and read cards and imagine deck builds. 


My criterion for rating games

http://boardgamegeek.com/geeklist/147053/item/2300390#item2300390


1) Sense of wonder: A large part of the variety and wonder in this game comes from the deck building and metagame analysis. The game outside the game. In the game itself you are biting your nails as you hope you draw the right card. Land, please? Pretty please? NO more lands please? This can be frustrating at times. However, there is also a great number of ways to play magic from Stack to EDH, 2-headed giant, cube drafting, booster drafting, free for all multiplayer, etc. this keeps the game exciting and fun with friends.

2) Meaningful/fun decisions. There are so many ways to go about playing your cards. there are times when you are stuck without decision throughout the game, but for the most part you have to agonize over which cards to play when, which creatures should attack, and which creatures should block.

3) Player interaction:  Lots of interaction through instants, direct damage, monster attacking and blocking, discards, and many other types of cards

4) Game length/complexity: Perfect length game (except multiplayer EDH!) Can play a game very quickly. When using simple prebuilt decks this game is not hard to teach and we can get in 5-10 ga,es in one evening. 

5) Components/artwork  The artwork and theme is fantastic. Cards are great quality 
 
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: N/A
CCG / Quick
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
I don't play competitively any more but I still try out the latest cards every couple years to see how it's changed. It never disappoints.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
Haven't played in many years, but WotC decided to send out some free "starter" decks to get people interested again.  Well, it was fun to play again for the first time in a long time.

I still think that this particular game was as groundbreaking to games in general, and card games in particular, that Monopoly was 75 years ago.  And it is still an outstanding game to this day.  Despite its age, it still breaks new ground with improved mechanics and ease of play.

It is my understanding that a "Fat Pack" will provide enough cards to allow 2 people to build and play viable decks.  So really, each time a new set hits the market, it's easy to grab some new cards and improve on previously designed decks.  And all for a rather low investment.  It probably won't win you any FNM events to PTQ's, but I imagine it will still be fun.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: N/A
Played countless times in the past. Obviously this is a great game, it's just such a lifestyle game that I don't really feel like being a part of it anymore.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
(thousands of plays)
Although it IS possible to play this game cheaply, it's hard.  The best way to start is to buy a pre-constructed deck for each player. (about $15 where I come from)  Ideally you will have at least one player who knows how to play already, or your FLGS will usually have someone who can teach you.  Once you start playing though, one of two things will probably happen:
1. You'll like the game and you'll want to buy more cards.  It's hard to stop and it can get out of hand.
2. You'll dislike the game and won't play it again.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 5
A clarification of why this is a 5.  I originally played Magic: The Gathering before they banned certain cards, like the Black Lotus and the Mox gems, but after these cards were not available unless you were willing to pay a ton of money for.  The game just was not all that fun when your opponent could whip out that much power that fast.

Since those days I know they have worked to stop this from happening.  Still, I don't really see the need to dump in huge amounts of money to get what is probably a mediocre deck at best.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
First played this in 1994 and 95 back in college. Then totally rediscovered this recently. It can be an absolute money pit, and it doesn't help that they market it directly toward your wallet. However, the incredible diversity of ways to invent your personal style is totally admirable. 

They've done a lot to standardize the rules since 1995! However, playing this game demands a willingness to continue to learn the evolving ruleset, and that's not for everyone. Plus, some people take it too seriously.

I'd like to try this again, with a limited card set and the right people. You know, the people that wouldn't treat it like a way of life.

Update: played 5+ games with a good friend using our various decks from different series. This is really a wonderful game... the only problem is the disparity in deck building. It's just not fun if someone is forced to work from a shallow pool of cards and then pit themselves against a deck that's a highly tuned, efficient, maximized-player-killing-machine. Balance is the key... similar card pool, similar interest level, similar budget. 

I am, however, very proud of my zombie deck. :)

Update: Oh, who am I kidding? I updated this to a "7." I could easily get talked into a booster draft. I don't ever see myself spending the same amount of money that I did in my "early exhuberance," but I'm still willing to play this compelling game.

RATING: 8
Mostly play Commander. My cube list: http://www.cubetutor.com/viewcube/71686

This is a game that I always feel conflicted about: 
You pay a lot in terms of game balance and actual money in order to have a highly customizable and vast card pool.

When the game is at its best, it's one of the most interactive and engaging games out there. When it is at its worst, it's a dull chore to finish a game. But I can't deny I've spent a lot of time playing it, and the moments when it is off are worth the times when it is on.

ADDENDUM: Picked up a second Duel Deck (Blessed vs. Cursed), and what a difference the overarching theme/story makes in personal enjoyment. The gothic horror premise of the Shadows Over Innistrad  setting really does make the most recent set stand out.

RATING: N/A
Unfortunately, this is a collectible card game, which means some of the nicer cards, combinations and/or strategies cost way too much money. To me (a starving college student at the time I actively played this game), many of the prices seemed ridiculous for mere cardboard and ink. I was also unhappy with the idea of banned cards - WotC should have playtested and balanced the cards BEFORE releasing them, instead of banning them from tournament play after players had already paid ridiculous prices for them. By the time I left this game behind, the rules and card abilities were becoming more convoluted and conflict-ridden. However, once you get past the price and the collectible aspects of this game, the original rules and 'classic' decks are not bad.

RATING: 6
What an odd game.  There's an odd sort of thing about this game that's both endearing and awful.  You can play it with nothing but a couple of pre-made decks, which is fine, but you miss out on the fascination of creation, which is really cool.

As long as you don't mind A: Spending the money, or b: making up a few proxies for cards you like.  Because frankly, to play it well against other people who do either of these things, you HAVE to do one of those things.

But honestly, I'm not sure how much more can be said about the game and meta-game here - It's fun in the right doses to me, even though it's clear that cards are more ridiculously powerful than ever.  So I'll probably keep playing, and even maybe buy some more.  Because it's there.

RATING: 5
The collectible aspect of my-set-of-cards-I-spent-$X-on-vs-your-set-of-cards-you-spent-less-than-$X-on isn't appealing to me. 

I thought that, if one plays within the confines of a finite, previously established collection of cards from which all players may build their decks, then the game play could be very thematic and the mechanics could be quite fun. 

However, I now judge a CCG based on whether it's fun or not even if you didn't build the deck at all. In other words, if you were just handed a deck to use, would you still have interesting choices within a game or would there not really be any significant decisions? Magic, unfortunately, doesn't offer that (at least not enough for me).
