=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
I love Magic. I've played it on and off (mostly on) since I first played it in 1995. I started the game playing casually 1 vs. 1 with my Mom, went on to multi-player at our local store, to competitive local tournaments in Extended and Type II (now Standard), then back to casual cubing with a friend, on to EDH (now Commander) and now multi-player of all-sorts with a mixed group that includes many players I've played with for years and my girlfriend who is new to the game. I play paper and some online, though online is mostly Pauper and Cube when it is offered as I have no interest in breaking the bank for virtual cards.

I hate the economic model of Magic, it is easily the most expensive game in the world to play if you truly love it and want to have the ability to play what you want, or even the format you want (as sealed / draft is my favourite, but cubing isn't quite the same and new product is expensive as heck, doubly so if you do it online). That said, it is also one of the most varied and richly rewarding games ever made. No other game has sustained itself for such prolonged periods of play for me, or has weathered as many storms. Yes, I know the pure abstracts have gone on for millennia and likely will continue as such, but those are always the same game from outing to outing. The beauty of Magic and its unending releases is that as things rotate into and out of the game the strategies can evolve and change. The game today is not the same as the game with a different pool of cards 2 years from now.

Strip away all of the annoyances with the economic model and what remains is one of the most deliciously subtle and varied games ever made. The game is both strategic and tactical and is full of subtle timing nuances and tricky decision trees. That all goes double when you play Limited (sealed formats) as you have to effectively build your deck on the fly and also pilot it effectively. My rating probably shifts a bit based on what version of Magic we're talking about, as Limited (of any sort) is probably an easy 10 whereas Commander with 4+ players, my least favourite format, is more like a 6. That said, on an overall scale, it's hard to give this anything less than a 10 as it is one of my all-time favourite games and I am always interested in playing several different versions of it.

I will simply close by saying that after 20 years+ of playing Magic I still find it fascinating and still enjoy shuffling up a new deck. I expect I will still enjoy this another 20 years from now. Fantastic design.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 3.5
In retrospect the money I spent on this CCG would have been better spent just about any where else.

The CCG model can be seen as exploitative (board game crack for the gaming addict - that definitely incudes me) and can lead to pay to win mentality.  Its wasteful (boxes of unwanted cards) and after a while insulting (anyone up for a puse deck to go with the red, white, black, green and blue decks also what cards for a ninja snail deck to go with your robot dwarf deck) just so they can carry on taking your money. 

CCG and other collectible systems tarnish a company's long term reputation (I think less of them) and as a business model does not encourage a company to be lean, efficient or inovative (why cut overheads and offer value if the suckers keep spending their money on the same old product).  A company can end up fixated on exploiting an ever diminishing core clientele and can use up all the customer good will which most hobby companys accumulate effortlessly.

The DNA of this model can be seen in minature games that keep changing the rules, army sizes etc in hope that they can essentially keep selling you the same product over and over again.  This often means that older players become disenfranchised (due to the incompatibility of their existing investment in the game) and they depend on fresh batches of youngsters to exploit.  I would also argue that role playing games on the 3, 4 and 5th editions are probably exploiting their customers (depending on how compatible older adventures are).

The DNA is just below the surface of LCG games and cynical core set games with limited content hoping to sell you more product later.  I would, however, argue that they are usually a lot less wasteful and you can often work out how much money they will cost you by looking at the release schedule.  

It could also be argued that wargame companys release many products that have barely been played tested to an aging audience that can no longer find the time to play them. There is a trend towards quicker and simpler games that I think needs to be focused on if wargamers and the companys that service them have a future. This hobby has never been mass participation in the UK and never will be if they keep selling product that realistically will remain unplayed.

Exploitation of customers can ultimately be self distructive.  I have failed to buy some FFG products since I fully expect that after buying the initial game along will come additional content, additional minitures etc and finally an incompatible second edition (although they do often produce a conversion kit).  I know I will often complete a set of games in a compulsive manner, this piece of self knowledge has made me stay clear of FFG products that I am not sure I would like Runebound.

I am a fully paid up member of the adult world and can usually make good decisions about spending my money etc and I would say most gamers are the same.  At the same time they know what they are doing by engaging our collectors compulsion. Exploitation diminishes everyone involved. What appears initially to be a perfect business model can cause a customer to fully disengage from a product line, a company or the whole hobby.  

I would ask a company when they are releasing yet more content to sure that it represents value for money, offers something genuinely new and above all will not make the customer feel foolish for spend their time or money on your product.

RATING: 6
I no longer play the game, but I think it's impossible (even irresponsible)as a gamer to neglect, deny, or downplay the significance that this game represents- for better or worse- in regards to our hobby.  When it was released, it was absolutely revolutionary for its time and nothing will ever come close to beating that sense of exploration and discovery in opening the first packs of alpha, beta or unlimited and playing with those early, clumsy decks that relied on Giant Growths or Howls from Beyond.  However, I do think the collectible racket turned out to be quite harmful to gaming in general and I think it's a shame that what is really a clever game system had to be saddled with such a horrifying (yet absolutely brilliant) marketing scheme.  The game is marketed directly at human greed and lust for power over their peers.  I'll likely never pick the game up again, but I respect its importance and I'll always have fond memories of playing 1993-1998.

RATING: 9.5
I think this is the best two player game. 

People have said that Magic is a contest about who can spend the most money. That's a little like saying baseball is a contest about who can spend the most money. Yes, your rec league team is going to lose to George Steinbrenner's team -- but that doesn't mean that baseball is bad. It just means that you can't play against the Yankees.

You can't play Magic at tournaments without spending a large amount of money, but that doesn't mean you can't play Magic without spending a large amount of money. Spending $40 on 12 packs -- perhaps from 3 different sets -- plus another $10 on basic lands, gives you a collection that's large enough to play a variety of formats with 4. 

Spend another $12 every 4 months -- that's no worse than Dominion -- to add more variety.

RATING: 10
Own a few thousand cards.  This may be the game I've played the most.  I've mostly played draft or commander.  I prefer the latter format to the usual 60 card decks, primarily because it evens the playing field (although you'll still needs some good cards!), and because the variety of play is much greater.  Your deck is no longer just a one-trick pony.  Once you've built up a solid collection you can just pick up the odd card for deck-building, and with highlander you only need one of each, so that's easy.  The artwork can be a bit grotesque (the black cards), and the magic universe has some strange elements to it, but in terms of gameplay this is one of the deepest games I've played.

RATING: 10

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 2
There was a time when I was sensitive to the lure of Magic, but the lack of people to play against soon led to a faded interest. Many years later, I took an opportunity at a fair to play with a specially designed starter kit, and liked the simple mechanics. However, upon arriving home and opening up the pack of 60 or so cards, I got extremely frustrated about the lack of clear summarised rules, and the finickiness of the complete ones. I threw away the sets (to the chagrin of my girlfriend, she liked the artwork) and focused on other things. A game which doesn't come with good, clear rules, and requires a number of expansion kits for things to become interesting is broken by definition.

Yes, I know that nowadays you can get cheap decks which are not current anymore. Yes, I know it is your choice to allow yourself to become trapped in the money pit. Yes, I know you can agree with others to only play with a particular set, so the emphasis shifts from Ccg to cCG. Yes, I know the sight of countless slender adolescent boys with the occasional tomboy girl (model 'Homo sapiens geekis') thumbing through the dime-a-dozen binders hunting for a misplaced rare one, are not representative of the actual game. But since I don't know the 'actual' game as there are no clear rules provided with a deck, the game remains put at a rating of 2.

[b]Update[/b]   The above all said, even if I was able to shell out some cash to purchase a complete set of cards of older editions so I could experience the activity of deck building, I highly doubt I would find Magic an appealing game. Recently I have played a number of Magic-equivalents: games where am I asked to create combos from a few to many separate cards drawn from either common or personal decks or anything in between. I've come to dislike such designs with passion as they violate a gaming principle I hold dear: that richness in gameplay should arise from simple rules. Magic breaks that principle with flair by allowing the cards to be played to more or less be rules in themselves. In a way you could say that I would probably find Magic too complex for the resulting game patterns which arise from such a design, and thus I still feel comfortable with the ranking I gave.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Have a few decks - Slither, Vampire, Angel. Very casual player.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
I used to realy love this game!

I don't play it anymore ... Somehow the über-ambitious people destroyed the game for me. But still: I consider M:TG as the most genius game invention, I know of! (therefor I will still vote 10) In the beginning, the tournaments really had the athmosphere of all this different wizzards gathering together - each one with some special mixes and combos in their spellbooks - and they played against each other to find out, which ideas and combos worked best.

Until the über-ambitious players destroyed it by simply copying succesful decks they read about in the internet ... and then suddenly you went to a tournament to play several times against the same deck of cards ...

RATING: 10
IMPORTANT NOTE:  
Whomever says that the only way to play or be good at this game is to spend a ton of money is truly mislead.  There are a ton of ways to play Magic very cheaply.  Cube, repack, and individual card drafting to name a few.  Only the obsessed play this game in tournaments and/or constantly purchase the newest cards.  You don't have to do that, to enjoy this game.  Simply pool your cards together with your friends and let the drafting begin.

Option 1:
http://www.boardgamegeek.com/thread/359860/magic-as-an-affordable-way-to-have-fun-with-a-fami

Option 2:
http://www.boardgamegeek.com/thread/382910/magic-as-an-affordable-way-to-have-fun-with-a-fami


MY RATING:
For all the love I've given and received from this game, it will probably be my only 10, ever.  The endless combinations and mechanics possible in this game make it a true winner that I will never tire of.

I've played many of the "stand alone" two player card games here on the Geek, but none of them can compare to the depth and variety that this game has.

True, the game can be expensive to collect if COLLECTING is your goal.  But, if PLAYING the game is your motivation, then you can easily build up your collection slowly for very reasonable costs while getting hours of fun/play out of them.

My collection is now close to 30,000 cards that I have built up since 1995.  I'm an addict who knows it and loves it.  However, I don't feel one bit scammed by the manufacturer nor do I feel any resentment/remorse for purchasing my cards.  In fact, the great part of Magic is that it continues to expand and improve.  This seemingly never-ending growth will ensure that I never get board of it.  You just have to go into MTG thinking you don't have to have every card nor the most powerful ones unless you wish to compete in tournaments.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 2
It may have ushered in CCGs, but it's a lousy game based totally around "best cards win" strategy.  It's newer incarnations are sad in that they are strictly for profit and it's painfully obvious.

RATING: 8
[COLOR=#990000]**[Español** ¿Para qué negarlo? cuando uno se pone a diseñar un juego siempre está pensado en este juego.

La mayoría de los CCG se resumen en robar, descartar y comprar; lo bueno del Magic es que fue el primero.

Ya no lo juego así que actualmente no lo recomiendo jugar ni comprar. Se está quedando anticuado, debido a los siempre problemas de mana, precios de las cartas, expansiones infinitas y que los colores cada día se parecen más los unos a los otros.

Cualquier nota dada a este juego es válida, yo tal vez le deje un 10 por motivos nostálgicos y otros que no vienen al caso.[/COLOR]

RATING: 10
This is my favorite game ever. I have played it since 1997 and it was my only non-PC game I had played for a long time.
It feels more like a life style than just a game. It has so many layers and options that you can enjoy it from many possible angles - being competitive player, casual one with the regular group, collector, buyer/seller, or anything between.
My MtG game life was developing from time to time but now I play almost solely EDH (Commander). And from time to time I spice it with some limited event (Draft with friends or prerelease sealed).
I have 14 EDH decks (almost fully foiled-altered) and I would say quite huge collection of other cards as I don't enjoy trading (or selling) much.

What I like:
- number of cards due to the age of the game (endless opportunities for building decks)
- variable formats where everybody can find what he likes
- EDH (commander) is the best gaming experience for me, I spent hundreds of hours playing it. And tens of hours building my decks, which is maybe even more funny
- I like the collection aspect of the game (introducing foil cards is a great move)

What I dislike:
- the price of the cards is very high in general, it is very expensive hobby to play MtG on some level. (although especially foil cards hold their value and maybe even grow in it in time so it can be seen as investment)
- I don't enjoy much the competitive environment - the guys who takes it too much seriously. There is too much competition among them and unhealthy atmosphere. I prefer local gatherings with group of friends and semi-casual games.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
Quite enjoyable and easy to play. Strategy mostly comes from deck building. But still lots of in-game strategy about guessing opponent strategy and if cards are complicated. Pros of CCG over the LCG model: 1) excitement of opening boosters, 2) adjust deck based on what you actually own, 3) unlimited cards and deck ideas, 4) build casual decks is less expensive than LCG. Pros of the game: 1) level of complexity is adjustable for new players, 2) epic battle and strategy depth is possible with more complicated cards, 3) crazy combos, 4) many ways to play for multiplayer too.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 1
The principle "whoever spends the most real money wins" is pretty much the very definition of something which "defies description of a game" and is "clearly broken" to me. Too bad that many gamers still fall for this kind of scam! Probably because if it weren't a contemptible CCG, the Magic card game would actually be a good game.
Playing "limited" formats (Booster Draft or Sealed Deck), which some people have brought up in response to this criticism, isn't a suitable solution for me as I definitely don't want to buy new boosters for each time I play.

However, I find it really fascinating how Magic manages to offer widespread tournaments with attractive prizes. I just wish other popular games would learn a lesson from this and offer (more) organized tournaments. I realize they can't offer prizes as large because they don't scam so many gamers to finance that, but they could still implement a more organized tournament scene. Some promo items as prizes don't cost much but can still be a sizeable incentive to compete for. I think FFG Organized Play is a promising development in this area.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: N/A
Played a lot back in the day, but haven't touched it in over a decade. Deckbuilding was always more than half the fun for me. Great rulebending game, though a victim of its own pioneering (absurdly complicated rulings required). The dynamic of having lands as a mana source is kind of sub-optimal, but baked into the design.

2011: I've started playing occasional EDH. Fun! And nostalgic.

2013: Nope, not anymore. I might like it with a more casual crowd, but the group I played with used decks high-powered enough that I had to spend too much time on deck building/tuning in order to be remotely competitive.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8.5
 The Lego of gaming.  Tons of crazy situations, adaptation, player interaction, and creative thinking.

Unfortunately, there is the mana screw: a random occurrence that you don't draw your resources so you effectively can't play the game and you choke no matter how skilled you are. Mulligans and good land ratios reduce the chance of this happening, but don't eliminate it.  

I also strongly dislike the collectible nature of the game, where you don't know if what you are buying is what you want, and better collections make stronger decks.

Even with these flaws, Magic has some serious strengths, and I spend more time on it than any other game that I own.  If Richard Garfield made a non-collectible version of Magic that solves the mana screw and other random annoyances, I would probably finally have a game I would rate a 10. (Here's hoping that Netrunner lives up to the hype.  Fantasy Flight did a good job on the Lord of the Rings LCG, but with all its coolness, its mission based structure reduces the replay value.)
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
I no longer play competitively, but I do have 5 Commander decks, Planechase, and Archenemy.

RATING: 5
Production: Nice graphics, and nice layout, though the essential information on each card (cost, strength, etc.) is difficult to read from across a table.  Play: Some interesting decisions, but basically if I had a land I played it, if I could afford to summon a creature I did, and if I could do some damage I did that too.  At any point, given the powers available, the game could have swung drastically either way; I think it becomes satisfying only when players each have deep familiarity with each deck in play. RATING: 10
Just being the original CCG game gives this game huge bonus points. Everyone else who came after could work off the basics of this game, but for the first go round at this sort of thing, they did a fantastic job. The only downside of the game is the cost involved and the rules can get tricky with some cards causing problems with others.  If you just booster draft now and then, its still pretty fun and cheap. Cool artwork, revolutionzed gaming ( D&D in 30 minute game? no Dungeon master needed? too cool!) Im sorry, you cannot have played this game and give it a rating of 3 or less. The people here who did so, obviously had some sort of traumatic events happen to them at a tournament or something.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
Magic isn't just an addiction, it's a disease, like malaria or Ross River fever: once it's in your system, you'll never be free of it. Sure, you'll have times when you say you can't afford the time or the money, so you put it away, maybe sell your cards. But you'll be back, cursing yourself for dumping all those great rares at knock-down prices.

Of course, as well as being an addictive (and possibly psychoactive) drug, Magic is hugely successful. It is probably only rivalled among gamers' games by Settlers of Catan in terms of reach: Settlers has sold approximately 10 million copies, Magic has had a similar estimated number of players. I suspect that Wizards of the Coast has made the greater amount of money out of Magic, though.
It is as collectible as you want it to be, as demanding of your time as you allow it to be and, thanks to the expansion release schedule, constantly refreshing in its challenges.
That said, once you know the basics, you can pick up and play (or draft) just about any set.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

I don't really keep up with this game too much.  I collected the starter decks for Ravnica and Theros and will break them out from time to time.

[Updated 3/9/09]: I moved Magic to a 10, following two glorious weeks of playing with my children via Winston Drafting thanks to this exceptional posting by Ender Wiggins, whose practices I have essentially duplicated -- just a great example once again of how the Internet connects you with people who lead you toward a better experience or destiny than you would have found on your own -- if you have any interest at all in Magic, read Ender's posting:

http://www.boardgamegeek.com/thread/382910

RATING: 7
I think the game is brilliant, but having played it religiously as a kid, I don't feel the need to ever really play it in real life. (I do occasionally play computer implementations of it.)  

This reflects my ambivalence about the game. It's immersive, customizable, and fun, but it's also a greedy marketing strategy.  

In my view, the best way to enjoy MTG is to play it on your computer or your Xbox.  Or, if you have friends around who'd agree, play a style that limits what cards can be used so there's no arms race to spend the most money.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
The rating for this is at odds for several reasons, and I'm not tracking plays for MTG as I've played this far more than anything else. I returned to tabletop gaming in general thanks to my former housemate who introduced it to me before I moved in with him, so if it wasn't for him and the friends I have met through him I most likely wouldn't have been lead to redeveloping my board game hobby. I have met a lot of other friends and people whose company I enjoy because of playing MTG competitively. I bypassed Standard and went straight into Modern, followed by Legacy. I enjoy Commander and still keep quite a fair number of casual decks. I have spent somewhere within the vicinity of $15,000 to $20,000 on MTG and I regret very little of that.

The almost absolute freeform creativity in building decks is still unmatched by anything. The plays can be potentially massive and can fall apart to a single response. The widely immense variety of game strategies thanks to a card pool spanning decades allows for highly amusing games. Two of my favourite casual decks that I own are a mono-blue suicide aggro deck and a mono-green control deck, both of those revolving heavily around cards that have not been seen in Standard for a decade or longer and are way out of touch for what the MTG colour pie represents now. The game at its core is simply amazing, even with the massive design mistake of having mana in the same deck as your main cards. Force of Will fixes this crucial flaw, at the expense of not being able to do ridiculous mana ramping.

However, I cannot give MTG a 10, ever. Why? You'd think the fact that cards are officially distributed in booster packs would reduce my rating, but that doesn't affect me. Apart from drafting and having excess store credit, I have not bought a booster pack in two years. Even when I was, I would only buy a fat pack of each set and nothing more. Cracking boosters isn't addictive to me. What really bothers me is Wizards of the Coast themselves, and how they're developing and promoting the game. Their overall strategy now appears to be to subtly push enfranchised players away from their game in the interest of profiting as much as possible. This can be most blatantly seen with their current "super mythic rare" alternate art card shtick that they're really enthusiastic about pushing, but (as of April 2017) their Amonkhet alternate art frame is by far one of the most horribly designed frames I've seen from Wizards. It's intentionally difficult to read as admitted by Wizards, and it's a massive execution failure as a result. It is a very blatant attempt to jump the shark and they've done this numerous times with regards to attempting to appeal to their Tumblr crowd, who aren't even their core players.

Another clutch that is really troublesome is their attempts to tightly control how Standard is played is detrimental to the overall long-term enjoyment of the game from a competitive angle. Granted I don't play Standard at all, but I know a lot of people who do and those who I've spoken to about it are generally displeased with the current state of Standard. There's also a noticeable trend towards dumbing down the interactions available in Standard in an attempt to broaden interest and appeal, but that just produces an increasingly stale environment. The fact that there's three cards currently banned in Standard and the format is still in a miserably unfun state is extremely concerning.

Still, as much as I want to get rid of my MTG collection, I simply cannot at this point in time. I've made way too many friends because of it and although there are times where I hate it, in the end I will enjoy it more often than I hate it. Having a good network of people to play with contributes a lot, especially with my local Legacy scene.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
A classic game- flexibility with card design and functionality. Sleek and competitive to casual and fun with friends. It's easy to learn and play (can be played in as little as 5 mins)- while still being very deep with clear concise rules at all levels.

RATING: 3
Outside the fact that i hate the CCG business model, the game itself is more about the deck construction, then testing to see if your constructed deck works by "playing" it.

There are not a lot of possible decisions to make during a game. Play a land card if you can and with the mana available to you, pay for whatever card you have in your hand that can be played. Most of the time, there are no reasons to play differently. Mexican Train plays the same way to an extent... draw a tile and play whatever you can on the table.

Also too much luck-of-the-draw-based. Too many games are over before they even started because you drew too little mana or not enough monsters or other cards.

Almost every other games i played were more interesting than this. I believe i'd even play Monopoly over this.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
'nuff said about this fantastic game! Just wanna add one thing that bothers me! You're forced to buy new cards over and over again to be able to compete with the new cards of your friends since new cards often have new abilities which you can't counter with your old cards! This game deserves a 10-rating in "Drawing money out of your pockets"!! But in spite of that one negative point it's still a fantastic game! I kept a few decks and sold the rest of my 2thousand cards 'cause I don't want to take part in that arms race anymore!

RATING: 10
Owned in the sense that I have enough cards to play...not be competitive.  This would get a 10 if it weren't for the fact you need to spend a fortune to be competitive with this game. RATING: 6
This game has the usual "card game issue" of requiring you to count cards, but it saves itself in that you can make your own deck out of quite alot of available cards.  Another problem is that in order to make a "fun competitive" deck it is going to cost you $100 or so.  In order to make a tournament deck, expect to pay much more.  When I play these games tha provide thousands of units/cards/etc options that you can buy, i just end up feeling ripped off in the end.  This game is no exception.  The concept of a huge number of options is great, but it is usually blunted by the sheer cost of "making something cool".

RATING: 10
Really, with so many alternate rules and so much variation between format and number of players, it seems silly to call this a single game. 

Constructed is a bit rubbish - a fun game in principle, deckbuilding being half the game, but due to the method of card distribution, with players lacking most the cards they'd want to insert into their decks, it just feels like you're crippled.

Booster draft is fun but you need to devote an entire evening (4/5hrs) and you need a large number of people to make the time spent making decks worth it in terms of how many games you can play, seeing how your deck performs.

My 10/10 is for Zeddmore: a format recently explained in the forums. Allowing for drafting decisions whilst playing, allowing you to see a high variance of cards in different games, playable with a 'cube' of commons (in my case mostly Shadowmoor/Eventide I'd picked up drafting) and reducing the luck factor somewhat.

If Jungle Speed had new cards released periodically, I'd be buying them and playing that a lot more. It's the constant mutation of the game that makes playing this such a varied experience. Though you could get 'sucked into' this if playing standard competitively, I think that for Zeddemore, buying a bunch of commons every 1/2 years would keep the cube fresh. Since I'll still want to draft occasionally, that'll probably be my main source of cards.

RATING: 7
Rates a 10 if you avoid tournaments and tournament rules and just want to have some quick fun with your friends. Rates a 5 for tournament play when one factors in the costs, an ever-changing and confused rulebook, endless errata, at least one broken card per set and the horrible sportsmanship typically exhibited by tournament (i.e. 12-year-old) players.

WotC's refusal to compartmentalize the sets led to some really wonky errata so that cards from Alpha will interact with cards from modern sets better. You can't manage a game that way, there are too many cards, it's just dumb. Fortunately, you can ignore such things if you're just playing at home.

The multitude of card interactions is amazing. The designers of Magic: The Gathering had a fresh and original idea and they capitalized on it big time.

RATING: 6
This is a great game that is hopelessly marred by the endless flow of cash needed to play it. Building the decks is fun. Playing the game is fun. But losing the game because your opponent spent $1000+ on their deck? Not fun at all.

This is truly a shame, as the game is genre-defining and has transcended generations. Many FLGS wouldn't even exist if not for the rabid MTG fans and endless tournaments. MTG's influence on board game design cannot be overstated, yet its also cursed many with anti-consumer practices such as essentially gambling on booster packs, high second-hand prices due to forced scarcity, and an almost insurmountable competitive scene that either scares of newcomer or drains their wallets dry.

I traded all my cards away after finally coming to terms with just how much money was needed to keep playing.

RATING: 5
This game can't have an honest rating because it is so many different games.  As a normal CCG, it blows.  Solid deck construction, but brain dead play.  Not as brain dead as WoW, but there is still always a right card.  But the depth of the card mechanics make this the best possible Booster Draft game.  You need to know the set you are playing with, watch what cards are going to other people, and focus on a plan on your feet.  Open your last pack and see one of the set's uber cards in a color you don't have?  Take it, and then just casually lay it down face up.  Suck it, green players.  5 for the CCG, 8 for the Booster Draft.  I'll round to 6 since I'm not actually good enough to play it the right way.

Agricola effect: -1

RATING: 9.5
I've been playing on and off for 17 years and think the design is very innovative and clever, and the strategy required is often deep, but it also has nostalgic value too.  I go in phases where I am either playing addictively or get completely out of the loop.  The one issue that frustrates me a lot is the financially exploitative pace of new releases and the high cost of dual lands and other utility cards often needed for multiple decks.  I also really hate the frequent marketing gimmicks like foils, mythic rares, etc.  Luckily these issues are more of a metagame problem, not really a problem with the gameplay itself, so they can be ignored while playing.  As such, I haven't factored this into my rating much.

RATING: 7.5

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 4
It's awful hard to rate this game, as many have said: on the one hand, the initial set had so many great things going for it. Sitting down and playing the actual games was actually fun in itself. But the deck construction was the real meat. How much of your deck did you devote to resources? Did you focus on defense and have a larger stack in order to outlast your opponent [viable back in the early days]? How much to focus on speed, fast-playing cards vs. card economy of powerful ones? And biggest of all, how many of the five colors did you choose to include? 
 
That initial set was likely the best release. The vast asymmetries were great. Green had its powerful global effects, like tranquility and stream of life. Blue had counterspells, card-drawing, and strange card manipulations that could lock cards. Red had cards like fireballs, and mana barbs to damage anyone who used their lands. The creative possibilities were spectacular.

Those days are long gone. Now the game has devolved to a bit of a ratrace, wherein every month or two yet another set is released, and more credit cards come out to buy cases of cards chasing the few game-winning combos. At least it is well-supported, more-or-less balanced, and creates a community. But I must give credit where credit is due; this forever changed the face of the gaming hobby, probably for the better.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 5
I don't tend to like deck/army building games. Making an initial call based on some sort of Nash equilibrium on what you expect others to play is not my idea of a good time.

So, to use Magic psychographics, my Spike side isn't interested in the game at all, and I don't have much of a Timmy side. How does the Johnny side stack up?

Very well, it turns out. Magic is the only game I know of where you can assemble a combo that causes another player to lose an infinite number of times. With all the cards in the game, you have almost limitless options, ranging from simple-type switching and resource infinite combos to weird and wacky stuff with tokens and deck manipulation.

All of this is primarily an out-of-round, deck construction decision. Skill during actual piloting is less important. I'm fine with that; I don't like games where you've played well, but a decision you made days before means that you've lost the match before you start. If those out-of-round decisions are all there is to it, that's fine.

So Magic is probably the best constructable game from my standpoint. I'm still not a huge fan, and the pricing is a large hurdle. The game is still alright, and worth looking at if your preferences lie along those lines.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 5
What magic was and is are 2 diffrent things. Magic around 4th edition/ ice age. Well it was exciting and cool and everything you could want from a card game it was card crack.... until it wasn't. When format almost started getting solved instantly in standard and the cost of cards if you didn't magicly open them in a pack were bonkers because they were meta or they bought in planeswalkers which broke the game and didn't scale back with older cards. Magic has showed us cards games arn't meant to be expanded infinitly it just isn't healthy for the game. Hearthstone is currently undergoing similar issues. There will always be something awesome about the game having cards that bend the rules in such a way that you get to do things that combo out. However i think the peak of this game is behind us.

RATING: 5
(Played 1994-1995) Hugely innovative for its time; the whole idea of customized card decks was brilliant (possibly inspired by miniatures games?).  Great idea of using resource land cards to play other cards.  But these great ideas were combined with marketing ideas of collectibility (the very worst form of it: rarity combined with blind purchase), which made it seem like much more of a collector’s product than a game (but from a marketing/profit perspective, this was also brilliant).  The game itself, using mostly non-rare cards, was addictive and fun, but ultimately a bit too repetitive and limited.  80% of the game’s strategy seems to go into deckbuilding (pre-game strategy) rather than gameplay (tactics), so that in-game decisions seemed mostly trivial, which to me is not as compelling--but is obviously a way to get players to buy more cards since that’s the main way to get more options and strategy from game to game.  For example, gameplay is very limited since players cant replenish played cards very fast and so have few options in the mid- to late game.  Another poor design feature is the randomness of drawing land, which is the essential resource in every game.  The game may have improved since those early years.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 8.25
Magic: The Gathering CCG is a very good card game. 

It`s just a bit expensive for the wallet, just like another CCG. Especially if you want to play type II tournaments. You need to keep to date with what expansions are in type II since they change from time to time. After a while, some of the older expansions go into type I. Type I is any expansions are welcome. Some cards are banned in Type I.

Compared to other CCG's, Magic: The Gathering seems to be still popular and expansions are still coming out today. Lots of CCG's go out of flavor with time. They last a couple of years before you never hear from them again. Depends on what's popular. I stopped playing Magic: The Gathering CCG in 1998. 

I had fun when I did play Magic: The Gathering CCG. My decks were very good though I didn't have any Alpha, Beta, Unlimited cards. Started with the revised edition basic set.

My favorite colors to play were black and blue. I had a black only deck, a black/red and a white/green/blue deck.

I started playing Magic: The Gathering CCG when Revised was out. My favorite color of the 5 was Black.

SOLD MY CARDS.
2 plays since recording games played.

RATING: 4
Good.  I went through several phases of buying tons of cards, playing a lot, getting sick of not being able to keep up with Mr. Suitcase, and selling or giving away all my cards.  Then I discovered the secret: play with friends who are really into the game.  They'll have tons of decks that they'll happily loan you.  Borrow, play, return.

Granted, you lose the fun of deck-building, but for me that's a small price to pay for not having to spend money on cards.

Really though, it's a great game, and a brilliant one.  Richard Garfield contributed something genuinely new to gaming and entertainment, and he gets massive props for that.  I just wish it wasn't so expensive and time-consuming to stay abreast of the game.  Would be superb if it wasn't collectible, but then it wouldn't be the same game.

RATING: 10
The basic design for Magic is an incredibly flexible and deep game system. The fantasy flavor is also integrated into the mechanics of the game quite well, particularly for the five different colors of magic and the different themes they are each associated with. The difference between, say, black and blue is essentially undefined by the cards that produce the resource, but the way in which the spell cards define their respective color is quite impressive. 

Most of my experience playing Magic has been with constructed decks rather than limited formats. I've tried sealed deck a few times, as well as strange, homemade formats such as "Everyday is Christmas," but I've always preferred constructed when given the choice. For me half the fun of the game is building a deck and testing it out before running against my friends and their creations. When we first started playing (back in the days of Revised and Fallen Empires, so many years ago!) we generally limited ourselves to building decks based around the artwork or creature types of cards, but over time we shifted our philosophy toward different strategies and card interaction. We've never been truly competitive (I myself have never played in a tournament of any kind), but our game is stronger than it used to be. 

In my opinion Magic's golden age was Mirage block. Back then no one really called it a "block," since Magic community lingo had not yet developed, but those three sets (Mirage, Visions and Weatherlight) took the game to new heights to which the designers have, in my opinion, never returned. A lot of the mechanics of contemporary Magic can be found in these sets, such as the emphasis on shared cycles across all five colors, but those sorts of things were done in moderation back then, and the sets were designed around a theme or flavor rather than a game mechanic (such as 'Affinity' from Mirrodin or 'Madness' from Torment). Visions in particular strikes me as an incredibly well designed set, filled with innovative, balanced cards that promote diverse strategies and player interaction. Who doesn't love Man O War?

The biggest flaw in the game is the expense. Magic is an incredibly expensive game. Part of it is the "arms race" that develops in playing groups, where the acquisition of powerful cards by one player encourages others to seek out new cards for themselves. The near-constant release of new cards also encourages unhealthy spending habits, and the new-ish rarity system only aggravates this further. There are some pre-made decks you can buy, but if you enjoy deck-building that kind of defeats half of the fun. The shift to designing sets around a specific mechanic (Affinity or Madness) has also hurt the individuality of deck design by basically insisting on specific, linear card interactions. 

All that being said, I still think this is the best game ever made. I only play "pre-modern" cards, and in many cases stick to pre-Tempest as a way of keeping myself from buying new cards (the new card face being hideous helps out a bit). 
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 6
The 800 pound gorilla of CCG's. Interesting rules and ever-changing decks make this interesting. Collecting frenzy and really expensive "power cards" make it not as fun. On the other hand, if I ever came across a big box of cards for ultra-cheap (like "here, take these"), I'd grab it in a minute.

RATING: 4

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
This is the game that started the whole collectability in card games, for better or for worse.  It also introduced a new breed of card game with many variations of key words/abilities and multiple victory conditions which is great.  This technically deserves a 10 but other games have improved upon what this one started. For instance, the resources can be an issue with this game compared to new games such as The Spoils and WoW TCG, heck the term mana-screwed was coined by Magic.  Yes, there were numerous types of dual lands that help consistency in multi-colored decks but it doesn't fix issues on whether you actually get those lands in your hand or not.  I've downgraded this from a 9 to an 7 after learning they now have 4 levels of rarity like WoW TCG.  The collectible aspect is still not as crazy as WoW but Magic's gone one step close towards that direction which is not good.

History of Magic:  

I started when revised/fallen empires was released and enjoyed it but couldn't afford to spend the money to make competitive decks.  We mainly just played for fun.  When Mercadian Masques was released was when I got back into magic seriously.  I collected Tempest - Invasion with major focus on Urza and MM Blocks.  I played competitively on a local scale and did well.  In the end I sold my collection for about $1200 CAN which was a nice recoup even though I'm sure it was worth more and I put more money into it.  I'm glad I sold when I did even though I truly do love the game.

Favorite Decks:

Ankh-Tide:  This was a type 2 deck (Masques/Urza) which I created after reading about the ankh tide combo.  I originally tried to make the Rishadan Pirates work with the combo but it didn't.  What did work was: Rishadan Port/Tangle Wire/Boomerang for early slow down, Anhk of Mishra + Parallax Tide for the combo, and Umbilicus/Tinker+Random Artiacts (ie Phyrexian Processor for control, Masticore for weenies, and other fun things) for abuse.  I think it was the only local blue deck ever made without Counterspell, hahaha.  I believe it had a few Misdirections though.  This was by far the greatest thing in Magic for me because it was something I created and it was decently competitive locally.

Suicide Black: This was a fun deck with the Phyrexian Negators and Tangle Wires, but it could do poorly sometimes.  I also liked trying black recursion decks with Hidden Horror/Exhume

G/W Rebelgeddon: This was MM Rebels + Blastoderms + Elves + Armageddon.  Fun times.

RATING: 8
I'll be honest: I'm not a very good Magic player. I don't even play very often! But I love the game for its complexities, its interactions, and its flavor. I read design and flavor articles daily on the Wizards of the Coast website, and I get all hyped up about new releases.

I won't lie: this game is a money sink. Luckily it's easy to avoid if you know how. Most of my time spent playing is game is either a) at prerelease and launch party events for new sets, or b) with a casual group of friends playing the "Elder Dragon Highlander" variant that encourages wacky play with low-value cards.

For some reason I've never logged my plays of Magic. I'm not sure why.

RATING: 6
I have a hard time rating this. Back in 1993-1995, I really enjoyed this game. I played it multiple times per week and in local tournaments. I had friends & acquaintances who worked for WotC and every reason to love it. However, the collectible card aspect quickly turned it into a money sink where having the power cards made all the difference. Even though I had some of the Power 9 and won a few tournaments, the "spend more, win more" concept got old. I put it away and probably won't touch it again. I want to give it a 10 for its longevity, how much I enjoyed it, and the thousands of dollars I made by selling a few of my old cards. I want to give it a 2 for too many sets, too many rule variants, too bloated, too expensive, and the whole CCG aspect. My rating reflects both sides. Purchased from various FLGS, OLGS, and gifted from friends.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
I created several decks about 20+ years ago because of friends, but I never really got into playing the game on a truly serious level. Most of my play oriented around occasional get-together games with friends where you took pride in defeating those who you grew up with. I believe my cards mostly consist of 3rd (revised), 4th, and 5th editions; plus, some 2nd (unlimited) and select cards from the limited Alpha and Beta releases as well as some expansion cards (Arabian Nights, Antiquities, Legends, The Dark, Fallen Empire, Ice Age, etc.). I gave away probably a thousand or more cards to friends at different points after I stopped personally collecting and playing, but still kept several of my favorite decks and some of my favorite cards. Unfortunately, some of my best and rarest cards I foolishly borrowed to a few (past) friends who played in tournaments and had asked if I could help them improve their competitive decks. As I grew older I lost contact with them so I probably will never see those cards ever again. I may have interest in trading some of my cards away, but before I do I'd like to see what kind of value they may hold -- I just haven't gotten around to investigating that yet.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
A great game - but experiences may vary... There are problems.  Many people criticize the game from the standpoint of tournament play - I view the game as a game, first and foremost, like every other game, and view the tournaments as something else entirely.  My biggest problem with it is that, over the years, the plethora of cards has made it such that it's hard to build balanced casual decks, due to card interactions, and we don't want to just arbitrarily ban otherwise innocuous cards in casual play due to how they interact in specific circumstances (some cards don't play well with others).  Another problem is that, while it is a very deep game, and experience at the game radically changes the way one sees it, it's hard to get to the point where one can appreciate how much is going on in the game.  New players don't always 'get it', and don't enjoy it as a result.  It can be a chore to learn.

Nonetheless, I think it's probably one of the most awesome recreational activies I've come across.  Nice job, WotC.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 9
The granddaddy of card games and I was there at the beginning:  Ice Age, Arabian Nights, Antiquities, Mox and Lotus.  I had tons of cards, cards that now could buy my daughter a year or two in college if they still were in my possession, but alas, I traded them in to a comic store back in the late 1990's and used the credit to buy DnD material.  I'm still playing that game, so I can't say I wasted my money, but I still cringe when I look at how much Moxes and Black Lotuses (Loti?) go for now.  Alas, the past.  It's the only thing guaranteed to grow the longer you live.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Magic has an enormous depth of strategy, which is what makes it so engrossing.  The wealth of cards and their interactions means that there is always something to think about.  What is more, since the majority of the strategy is in the deckbuilding, most of that thinking can be done in between plays.  Given its complexity its also surprisingly well balanced.  

Magic has its downsides, of course, including the luck inherent in a card game and the fact that it is more expensive than most board games.  Don't let the people who complain that they have wasted $10,000 on it scare you, though - as long as you have a little bit of self-control the expense can be kept quite reasonable.  I have played Magic casually for over 10 years and spent probably $200-$300 on it, which is not too bad considering the hundreds of hours of enjoyment I have gotten.  Granted, people who spend more money will tend to have somewhat better decks, but money actually isn't as significant a determinant of victory as is skill level, at least for casual play.    

So anyways, Magic has some downsides, but in my opinion these are more than overweighted by its good qualities: the depth of strategy, the beautiful theme, and the game's fantastic playability.  It's portable, has no set up time, plays relatively quickly, scales well to most any number of players, and is widely played so it isn't hard to find an opponent: no wonder it is the #1 most often played game on the Geek.  

Update 1/5/2012:  Now that I haven't bought any new cards for a few years, and don't have a steady stream of new opponents, I am finding that I rarely play this.  This makes me realize that it is even more dependent on novelty (either my new cards or my opponents') than I had realized, which lessens my respect for it.  That said, I am still more than willing to play if someone else asks.  Downgraded from a 9 to a 7.5 
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 7
Used to play this quite a bit, but nothing compared to the crazy, CCGers who think that a game isn't a game unless it's a collectible card game (i.e. Yu Gi Oh, Pokemon, MtG, etc).  Mechanics so essentially simple that it's another one of those "now why didn't *I* think of that?!" concepts.  As daunting as the downloadable rules seem to the novice, it really is an easy to learn and (can be) quick to play, strategy card game.  Enjoyed it, but have moved on.  Also, not a fan of the whole "I have more money than you so I can afford more cards" sort of approach.  Matches with fresh sets are fun.  But the "nuclear proliferation" part of the mechanic is BS IMHO.

RATING: 10

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
The most popular CCG, and with good reason - I'm nearly always up for playing a game!  I have about 20 pre-constructed [url=http://www.boardgamegeek.com/thread/359860]theme decks[/url], which are a great way for learning the game or playing straight from the box.  Drafting is one of the best formats to play once you are familiar with the game, and you can [url=http://www.boardgamegeek.com/thread/382910]make your own draft set[/url] with a playset of commons and uncommons (I have draft pools for 9E, TSP, and LRW blocks).  Elder Dragon Highlander is also a fun format (I have a RG Beast deck, and a UW flying deck), and can be particularly enjoyable in a 2 Headed Giant Format where you have partners playing each other.  Playing on Magic the Gathering Online enables playing with people around the world at any time of the day, and the Momir BASIC avatar gives you access to a casual format using every card in the game.  Unfortunately some of the artwork and themes of the black cards are distasteful.  There are so many different ways to play this game, that it's always fun.

See my reviews:
#1 https://www.boardgamegeek.com/thread/359860/magic-affordable-way-have-fun-family-affordable-op
#2 https://www.boardgamegeek.com/thread/382910/magic-affordable-way-have-fun-family-affordable-op

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
Magic is something unique in the world of fads and disposable games...a CCG that defies the criticism of jaded tools like me. Say what you want, but almost all of us play or have played it and we all have the scars to prove it.

Many adults still fly too close to the sun spending time with other people's kids at distances that border on inappropriate touching gleefully discussing card effects and rarity values with passion that resembles obsessive sports fandom.

Is it wrong? How would I know? I'm on the inside laughing at a subset of my own hobby. Yes I think it is stupid to constantly repurchase sets of cards because of the MtG tournament regulations, just like it is stupid to buy a new army with each revised WH codex. been there done that.

In the end is it harmful? No! It serves as an effective means of birth control by regulating the social habits of people that probably should not reproduce - ever. How else are you gonna keep these kids penned on Fridays and Saturday's without violating their rights. I say let 'em buy more cards and boost the economy while at the same time not muddying the gene pool with more kids with OCD.

Then again, there may also be a side benefit to all this...the next evolution of math geniuses may come from the ranks of the Magic players...could it be a covert op to unlock the next Einstein or Mandelbrot? Only J. Edgar Hoover's disembodied head knows for sure.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

I'm not a collector of Magic and I'm not "in to it". Occasionally I like to play, but not with real Magic players. Because then it is for neither of us fun. I can't rate the game play weight, I think the combining of your cards to a special deck can be extremely heavy while the way I play it, it would be light medium or medium.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
M:tG is like my dad's friend's line about New York City: "it's a great idea that got out of hand".

Back when I started playing, there were two types of power players in my group:

Those who build clever, effective decks
Those who used only the most powerful and expensive (to buy) cards

(I would have also said "those whose decks were loaded with proxies", but they're lower than human, so they don't count.)

Once I went to college where everyone was handed a laptop and broadband connection (unusual for 1998 - go SHU!), I discovered a third and most loathsome variety of player: the Netdecker.

Suddenly, the game wasn't about deckbuilding any more. It was just about collecting the cards to build someone else's deck.

Additionally, my group wasn't interested in 1-on-1 games. They only wanted to play 3-hour 10-player free-for-all marathons that were more about diplomacy than what's in your deck. (Exception: I designed a deck filled with mass destruction as a protest to these games. Much to my surprise, this deck never lost in a massive game, even when they were all against me.)

Finally, the game itself seemed to collapse under its own weight. Too many expansions, too many varieties of the same card and too much money spent wore me down.

I moved on to booster draft, which, to me, was the purest form of Magic. Problem was, it cost $10 a night and I'd get to play 3 matches max. That's not very cost effective in my opinion.

Thankfully, with the advent of the Planechase and Archenemy formats, WotC hasn't forgotten the casual player. At this point, I prefer the preconstructed decks for balance. Constructed formats otherwise just don't bring the fun for me anymore.

This sounds like I'm slamming the game time and time again, but I do love it. Nearly all of my closest friends I know because of M:tG even if we haven't played in years. I just find it hard to find people who want to play it like I do.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
There's nothing a goober like me can say about Magic that hasn't already been said.  There might be card games that I prefer to Magic, but it remains the industry gold standard, and for good reason.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
The game that started it all, and drafting is one of the best gaming experiences ever. Just wish it wasn't so expensive, otherwise I'd do it 24/7!!! Thankfully, newer deck construction games are replacing this for me. Regardless, I can't deny the impact this had on me and the gaming community overall. It's an evolution in game design! To this day I still enjoy dreaming up/ building decks for it even though I'm not really playing it anymore.

Ultimately, having to stuff half your deck with land cards is what keeps me away from this game. There's nothing worse than untimely mana floods or mana screws. Also, newer card game designs have been playing real well with multiple players right out of the box while still offering an insane amount of replay value. That and games with cards that offer multiple functions have made the options in a Magic: The Gathering duel feel dull.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9.5
I've been playing since 1997 and I think it's the greatest tabletop game ever conceived. The only flaw the game has is that its monetary expense is inescapable. New sets come out too often and card rarity is a sleazy marketing tactic which results in owning thousands of useless cards. The game's expense chases people away and keeps it from being little more than a cult classic. In fact, most non-gamers have never even heard of it, yet they all know what Monopoly and Yahtzee are!?!      Despite all of this, I'm still a fan and a game is always welcome.

Update 9/9/2011: Mythic rares are becoming too powerful and game changing. This isn't a good sign for the game's longevity.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
What an amazing concept - and how fortunate for R. Garfield! :-)  Very strategic on many fronts: PLAY of your deck, BUILDING your deck, TIMING of play.  Discretionary income does give an edge - but no deck is perfect and the playing field is level if you focus on draft play.  Of all games I've played, this ranks among one of the highest for replay value.  Grade: A+

Addendum:  Since Garfield left, the quality isn't what it used to be.  The cards are too powerful causing duels to end much too quickly.  The end result feels like who gets the luckiest draw instead of a satisfying battle of wits.  What a shame as this was once an oustanding game.  On a positive note, it is still incredibly deep, and remains the "grandfather" of CCG type games though.  Current Grade: B

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Rating history: 10...for years|9...for years|8 


230th playing: :star::star::star::star::nostar: - BattleCON is cheaper and even more my style.

Played 200+ times. Yes, yes -- I finally got around to playing this (June 2005 for the first time). And I enjoy it tremendously. I found ways to play it without spending horrific amounts of money on it: play online and only buy singles from trading 'bots; and for paper, draft for rares and uncommons, and trade your money rares for lots of cheaper rares. I love the variety of gameplay and I am a deck-building addict. I will say this though, I think my interest in Magic peaked with Ravnica block because I love the two-color pairings. Now that Colsnap is out and Time Spiral on the way, and it is becoming clear that two color cards are not going to be prevalent, my interest in buying new sets in waning. Good things I made about 40 decks from my Ravnica cards. =)

Aug 2014 (approx. 300th play): 9. Taught this (with very simple decks) to a friend hoping to have a casual Magic buddy. He enjoyed it decently, so maybe I'll be able to start playing again.

RATING: 6.78
Listed 7/7/08

[url=http://www.boardgamegeek.com/geekbuddy.php3?action=doanalyze&groupid=4204&B1=Analyze&gameid=463]Ratings[/url]
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
I prefer playing PC versions and with friends' sets rather than getting onto the CCG treadmill that ends in poverty, but I can understand the addictive nature of this game.

Revisiting it, I'm disappointed by the randomness, dependence on having the right cards, and in-game shallowness of play. I like the fluff though.

A lot of the strategy is played out before you even meet your opponent in battle, in creating your deck. Getting the cards in the first place is a far greater challenge.

Newer card games have improved on the mechanical issues that Magic suffers from:
* inability to control your draws, resulting in mana screw
* stagnation and threshold behaviour in combat
* unstructured timing and stacked interrupts that spike complexity
* major mechanics being incredibly complicated (eg protection)
* having few decisions in-game, with a single way to play a deck and thus being decks being one-note
* not being geared for more than 2 players
* the lottery nature of booster purchases with a high financial commitment required
* placing most of the complexity on the cards with weak base mechanics
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Classic old CCG
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 6.5

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
[Collectible Card Game, Hand Management, Deckbuilding, Metagame, Fantasy, Best Game Ever] {2P:10, 4P Ettins:10, 3+P Mass Melee:8, Limited Booster Draft:10, Limited Sealed Deck:5, Limited Solomon Draft:10, Limited Rochester Draft:7} {Thousands of cards, beginning with Beta and ending with Weatherlight} 

The most brilliant game ever created. 

Don't confuse the game with the tournament environment / collector's market. Judge it on what it is: the creator of a genre, the savior of many a game store, and, perhaps, the true gamer's gateway game in more ways than Settlers of Catan ever was. Too many people believe that you need to have current tournament-class decks to play the game. That's pure and unadulterated hogwash. You don't need a Black Lotus or an Ancestral Recall to play Magic or have fun. You don't need to buy the latest expansion if you don't want to. An investment of $10 on a few thousand assorted commons and uncommons is enough for hours and hours of enjoyment. The land cards can probably be had for free! Make that your pool of cards. Everyone drafts from that pool, or just divvy up the cards by color and start building decks! If you want to get into the competition scene, you do so with open eyes and an empty wallet. Blaming the game, the game designer, and the company (Wizards of the Coast) is just plain stupid. What, they *forced* you to buy the game? They made it so that you can no longer play with the cards you have? Of course not. What's driving that desire, if you have it, is yourself and your lack of self-control. How do I know? I played MtG a lot years ago, when still engaged in competitive play. Gave it up, sold the big value cards, but still own thousands of them. I got out by choice, due to constraints on time, primarily, but the money saved was nice too. No regrets about playing at competition level. Fifteen years later, will happily play a pick up game when asked. MtG remains one of the most remarkable feats of game design and commercialization in the history of games. If there was ever a game that deserved a '10', unclouded by the prejudice of needing to have the latest greatest and priciest deck in order to have fun, then MtG is it. The game is one of the greatest in history; it not only defined a new category of games (and how many games can claim that?), it also singlehandedly got millions of people playing games face-to-face again. This is a '10' if there ever was one. For me, that will never change. ***UPDATE: Just played with the new Ravnika set, booster draft format. 10. If there was an 11 I'd give MtG that rating. Really hard to see how any other game can measure up in comparison.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7.5
The fact that it is such a money sink really kills my rating for it. It could be a pretty neat game if there wasn't so much incentive to buy ultra-rare cards in order to beat people who have hundreds of dollars to put into a single deck.
However, my rating is pretty strictly based on "kitchen-table Magic" experiences. Fun game, and with enough cards, you can make some pretty fun decks that can get really creative.

RATING: 5
The grandfather of CCGs.  It gets my respect, but not my love. There's a large disconnect between casual and tournament level play that makes switching from one to the other too big an investment of time and resources for me to make the jump from casual to tournament.  
As such, I've dropped out of play altogether as I did not want to try and keep up with the enormous card pool and constantly morphing errata.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 5
Over the years I've played this more than ANYTHING (not limited to board games) except possibly Diablo 2 during one particularly boring high-school Summer. Magic gets a lot of things right, but it's definitely coasting on its classic status. The resource screw problems are worse here than in any modern customizable card game and you will never feel so enslaved by your deck as you do in Magic. But the value of Magic cards is too well cemented in the minds of folks who grew up in the heyday. Valuable Legacy cards have a sort of mythic glow.

What Magic gets right: stack interaction and depth of card pool. The former is a pretty incredible bit of game design and the latter is obviously just a consequence of having been the only survivor of the CCG golden age.

RATING: N/A

RATING: 7
PRO - Great game playing experience. Fun to create your own decks. Color themes were each unique and engaging. Mechanics were simple, fun, and innovative (I got out after Ice Age). Had a ton of fun playing in groups. Probably will never play again, but rate it based on my past experience.

CON - Expensive habit.  I got out of collecting because WotC started releasing sets too rapidly and introducing new rules just for the sake of adding something new to the mix. The early sets of rules were fine and made for a great gaming experience.

RATING: 10
Without a doubt the best (card)game I have ever played.

Getting to know the numerous cards, designing your own deck with combinations which you thought would work well and then testing your new deck against a deck of a friend.

A very tactical cardgame which required knowledge of the cards, quick thinking and (occasionally) a good poker face.

I have played this game for many years before I parted with my cards (with exception of one deck). 

Why did I stop playing? In order to keep up with the game you had to keep on buying new additional cards.

RATING: 8
Like a lot of other folks, I succumbed to the Magic craze in the early 90s and played the hell out of the game from the Beta release through Legends, at which point I sold off virtually all of my cards.  Since then I've been off the wagon and I recently got my 10 year chit from MtGA.  Ahem.  In retrospect I should have held out to sell some of those cards later in life - yes, I had a Black Lotus - but I can't say I regret it.  I still have a few cards left, including most of an Ice Age starter deck that I picked up for a release tournament ages ago, but that's about it.  Recently a friend and I sat down with my remaining Unlimited cards, where I have just enough to make two functional five color decks, and had one hell of a great time playing with them for a couple of hours.  It was nostalgic as all hell and reminded me of the very early days of the game, but I can't say it's driving me to go back to playing on a regular basis.

RATING: 7.4
2016
====

I was snobbish towards MtG for a long time and missed out on a very fun time as a result. While my older son and I like the game very much, we don't play to compete. Instead, our MtG play is limited to Duel Decks (Monsters vs. Heroes is great), budget 93/94, "story decks", and pauper drafts. MtG is reviled by many for its nature as a money sink, but we spend very little money on it and have at our disposal an incredibly deep gaming experience.

2014
====

I came to MtG very late after a somewhat snobbish attitude earlier in life.  I'm eating a ton of humble pie because this is an amazing and incredibly rich game.  That said, I am not at all interested in the collectable aspects.  Around my house, we tend to play as follows:

 - Grab a few boosters whenever a new set comes out
 - Draft from the 1500+ commons that I bought for $15
 - Use proxies for the exceedingly rare cards

I am also a dealer so will consider buying collections and singles.

-=-=-
FUN: :star::star::star::star::halfstar:
RULES: :star::star::star::star::star:
ART: :star::star::star::star::star:
COMPONENTS: :star::star::star::nostar::nostar:
THEME: :star::star::star::star::nostar:
LONGETIVITY: :star::star::star::star::halfstar:

+ I was able to get up to speed quickly. I last played the tabletop game back in the mid 1990s and played Duel  of the Planeswalkers on Xbox 360 a couple of years ago.
It was also easy (less the 10 minutes, maybe even 5 minutes) to teach to my kid (who plays Pokemon).
+ The art is fantastic.
+ The game is a classic
- Cards wear down quite easily and will need to be sleeved if you want to see a lot of play out of them
-/+ Collectability can be a negative for many. However, there are many ways to play without breaking the bank: theme decks, all commons and/or uncommons decks, cubebuilding and cubedrafting  

[i]Dec 2012:[/i] Just can't get enough. MtG (especially MtG Online) has consumed most of my gaming time. Upgrading Rating from 8 to 9.
[i]Nov 2012:[/i] Started playing again with M12 booster battle packs. M:tG is a much better game than I remembered. Changed rating from 5 to 8.

RATING: 9
Have played for many years. I still love the game but recently began budgeting more of my entertainment dollar away from Magic and towards other board/card games. Wish I could find opponents. Quick, portable, engaging. I've easily spent more hours playing this than any other game or any other hobby for that matter. I've gotten many, many, many more times the pleasure and joy from my cards compared to their cost (admittedly, not cheap however). I'm a little surprised it's not rated higher on BGG. I've been lucky enough to live in several places around the world and wherever I've lived, my Magic cards have made me new friends. As just a casual player, I've probably taught at least 50 people to play. I don't know if that's alot but it seems like alot to me.

RATING: 8
A really, really good game.  Every once in a while, I'll pick up a pre-constructed deck at the store and play it a few times.  I miss out on building custom decks, but the precons are fun anyway.  You don't _have_ to go the whole "collector" route.  Sometimes I'll go mooch a game in the trial area of Magic Online, where you can always play one of the current five one-color 40-card "theme decks" for free.  
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
This game would be a 10 if it had come in fixed sets. The problem is its collectible nature.
 
1. He who has the most money has an advantage over players of equal skill. 

2. It is difficult to build any deck you want without resorting to proxy cards or going into the outside market.

A second problem is WotC's banning of cards from tournament play rather than issuing errata for them. This often means that the most desirable cards from a given expansion often drop from tournament play before the rest of the set does. Often the problem is conflict with a new card having unanticipated uses. Rather than banning the new card which is relatively easily available they will banish the old one which tournament players have gone to great effort and/or expense to obtain.

2 points off for collectible and 1 for the banning of establish cards in favor of the new.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
Yes, this game is hideously expensive to try and collect or play competitively.  However, I can recognize great design when I see it, and this is truly the pinnacle of CCG design.  Open, flexible, with lots to explore.  When you build a deck, unlike other CCGs you are given a clean slate.  How do YOU want to win?  Then build it.  One of THE greats in game design, hands down.

RATING: 4

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
[b][i]Magic[/i][/b] is a 2-player card duel that is crazy prominent (and, along with miniature games, is probably the reason we still have FLGSs). In my opinion the gameplay of Magic pales to similar games (e.g., Android: Netrunner, Game of Thrones, Blue Moon, Summoner Wars, ...). The extreme breadth of cards gives Magic a wealth of deck-building options, but competitive decks are easily found online. Worst of all, Magic uses a blind-buy distribution model (although I do understand that many enjoy the draft play that's possible with such a model).

However, these things aside, I like Magic as a quick game to play with a wide range of close and distant friends; this is only possible because of Magic's prominence, simple-ish game play, enjoyable theme/artwork, and constant development. The good times this has brought single-handedly makes Magic a game I would recommend if you had a group of like-minded friends. Here's the recipe: Buy a few pre-made decks (to negate the moronic distribution model), grab some friends, and have a night of relaxed gaming fun.

◊s◊

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
One of the best game mechanics ever designed - simple rules, functional yet very appealing components including some of the very best fantasy art available, and very easy to set up - all you need is a deck of 60 cards plus a few "life point" counters. Game play is very tactical and the deck building and instant card effects adds "fog of war". The game is however a "collectible" card game and players need to realise and accept that collecting cards (which means spending a lot of money on an ongoing basis) and deck design is an integral part of the game. The collectible nature of the game is a game in itself - a wonderful part and a major negative as well given the ongoing cost but does not change the fact that this is a very good game.   
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 6.5
I'm not sure what happened to this once-great game. Maybe WotC got too big or too greedy, or maybe I graduated middle school and learned to talk to girls.

In any case, the mechanics and balance were both mostly great until about Mirage. If you can find or print old cards and play casually, it's still a good game.

If you're attempting to stay current, you'll find a game that's no longer possible to balance, and as expensive as a crack habit.

RATING: 10
What a great idea.....When it came out in 1993, it was perfect timing to put the board games away because of all the babies around at home and at friends.  Fast to play, fun to build the decks. I remember laughing out loud at all the poor saps that were bringing suitcases of cards to GenCon and Origins the years after it&#039;s introduction.  If you want to blow a huge amount of money on a game that is unbalanced (if not, then why would there be any need for thousands of cards and a huge cash outlay to get them?) then get into this game.

I&#039;ll hand it to Richard Garfield for catching all the kiddies at the perfect time as all the other collectible markets were in the dumpster he picked or lucked upon the PERFECT moment in time. But then again he has a mountain of cash that he can laugh right back at me with.

The much better game that he was trying to get marketed before Magic was (RoboRally).

I&#039;ll also thank Richard for allowing me to cash in on the collectible card games fad while it lasted... I bought plenty of Alpha and Beta first edition cards for this while I could and sold most of them for far more than they should ever have been worth.
