RATING: 1
If you spend an insane amount of money to remain competitive in a game which rotates now every 2 years (wow), "playing" this is about building your deck and then playing rock, paper, scissors, lizard, Spock.
If you don't spend an insane amount of money is just playing rock against paper.
I guess playing casual it's ok, but even then most of the hands play themselves, so what's the point: there are hundreds of better games out there in which there's actual strategy involved. Mediocre game by today's standards; just to name a few issues (besides it's a CCG and I'm no longer 12 to spend time trading cards): broken combos, myriad of banned and errated cards, obscene advantage for the first player, flawed engine relying on land draws...

Besides, most Magic players I've met are blind fanatics who refuse playing anything other than Magic (few of them know about other games), so I guess this Magic thing, as famous as it is, it's actually doing more harm to the gaming community than benefit in the long run. This is more a business than a game.

Android Netrunner is the spiritual phoenix of this ultra-nerd-fest bonfire of the vanities, so go check out that game and leave Magic to the ravenous fanboys who only want to get you involved so they can hook you into an expensive ponzi-scheme of card collecting. When you realize there are combinations of cards that ultimately break the game, and that your "buddies" already have those cards built into their killer decks, you'll feel like an idiot. A broke idiot. But only after you've gone too far down a gilded rabbit hole that leads to shut-in, self absorbed "I win" deck building.
AVOID.

RATING: 7
Only really enjoyed the competitive side of MtG. Mostly Legacy or '1.5' format. Training to stay competitive took too much time though and I decided to give up the collection in favour of other games.

The strict rules and judge system of MtG competitive gaming is the best out of all card games - maybe of all games period. Especially taking into account the high complexity of the rules.

Of all collectible card games MtG is still on the top and I don't expect that to change very soon. But to stay competitive, this cardboard heroin will take all your time and money - probably social relationships too.

RATING: 2
Beat to Death!
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
Some ungodly number of plays, seven years so far.

This game is what epitomises a 10 for me, I will be playing this game for the rest of my life, from casual play with younger children to competitive tournament play. The gameplay is excellent, honed over 23 years I have no point upon which I think it could be improved. What I do recommend is that if you are any degree of a serious gamer, play a constructed format rather than the very underpowered preconstructed decks you can buy. Precon's are fun for play with young children or people who like a more simple game, but it lacks the full depth or interesting mechanical interactions. 

Highly advise buying a pauper format deck online or in paper. $1-70 for a deck online and generally less for a deck in paper, avoids the expensive rares needed for other formats and still provides a high level of interaction and ample opportunity for deck brewing.

Finally, there is an ethos and community to the game that I can barely begin to describe, I've met many friends and lived many unique experiences through Magic. Going to Tuesday Night Magic is something I could have fun with even if I lose every match just because of how much I love the community.

I will be playing this game for the rest of my able life. 
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
I use to really love this game but whyen my rare collection of magic cards got stolen it pushed me away from this game.  Also when this happened I wasn't really playing much anymore.  CCG games still sound fun but I would sooner try a living card game from FFG or  get Dominion.  Collectible card games no longer appeal to me at all.

Update: I recently played the Xbox 360 version of Magic and this rekindled my interest in the game and therefore I raised my rating.  Part of me feels like getting involved again but I remember how much money I drowned into this last time so I'm holding back.  Living card game seem neat but the amount of packs that come out is intimidating since i'm a completionist.

RATING: 7
One of the best of its generation.  It dragged me screaming and kicking into a world of fantasy gaming that I had previously 'cocked a snook' at.  In my decaying mind it is forever associated with the warm summer weekends of '93. The relative simplicity and the range of possibilities, strategic and tactical, really absorbed me and my pals for countless hours.  

But it suffers from the same problems all CCGs are destined to suffer from; luck of the draw (although there are ways to overcome this somewhat) and convolution, driven by a need to sell new sets of cards.  Oh for those simple days of yesteryear.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 9
It's a good game, but with thousands upon thousands of cards, very complex rules (if you play at a tournament level), and an incredibly high startup cost, it's something you've got to devote a large chunk of your life to.  I probably spent about a thousand hours and a thousand dollars over a period of a few years on this game (many people commit much, much more), and I still was a low-tier player -- I could neither anticipate my opponent's strategies because they could be using cards I had never seen before, and my less expensive cards simply could not compete.  As far as creativity goes, Magic gets a high rating from me -- the mechanics of the game are very well-done, and the CCG format was an extremely innovative idea copied by many, many game designers.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
I played this game when it first came out and I was quite young.  Then, my Magic cards sat in a box for almost 15 years.  When I rediscovered board/card games I knew I didn't want to get back into the CCG thing because I know what kind of a financial stress the addiction can cause.    I considered this game too sloppy, that it depended on the player to put in all the work to organize the cards and the player who had the "best" cards and who spent the most time organizing his deck would almost always win.
However, the allure of the Duel Decks was pretty irresistible.  Here were two decks, gorgeously organized, playtested for a perfectly balanced game and it cost as little as a standard cheaper board game.  I picked up Phyrexia vs. The Coalition and loved it.  I thought, here is Magic really shining.  I've also purchased the most recent pair, Elspeth vs. Tezzeret and have found it to be a lot of fun too.  For me, this is the new way to continue enjoying what is a great game.
---
More recent explorations in Magic include the DeckBuilder's Toolkit.  I thought I had found my new niche for this game with the duel decks, but I forgot how much fun it is to build a deck.  Even (especially?) with the limited cards from the toolkit, you can build a large variety of decks and if your opponent is working from the same resource, I think it's a fair battle.
---
I've rated M:tG a 9 because I do love to play and I love constructing decks (from my modest supply), but Magic is not without its flaws.  In fact, several games have done a lot to fix the problems people have with Magic like getting too many or too few land cards (usually eliminating random mana draws) and card balancing.  However, Magic just has a certain charm to it that no other game captures.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
The only modern game design I'm aware of that legitimately deserves to be described as a work of "genius."  I don't play anymore -- in fact, I haven't for years -- but I continue to hold it in extremely high regard.

RATING: 5
The game itself in its basic form I like very much. Deckbuilding is a very deep strategic challenge. When playing, the sometimes very difficult decisions that need to be made are fun and challenging. And the art is unparalleled.

However, because it's constantly being expanded, the investment to stay current is astronomical. $500 USD per year is a lowball (as of 2013). Think of all the *other* gaming you could do with $500. Add in the vagaries of the rules and the irate tantrums of some of the players, and you end up with a game that is a fun strategic challenge that I will probably never want to play except occasionally, with people who have outdated decks as well.

RATING: 5
I normally don't mind randomness in games, but in this game it was down right annoying.  From a game where no land could be drawn, to a game where land was being drawn but only the most powerful cards (which needed even more land get drawn) to a third game where almost all draws where land.  Just down right annoying.

That coupled with as soon as the packs that came with the precondtucted decks were open, the decks become unbalanced.

As I see it, there should be a second deck with just land that you can draw from and deck construction should be based on a point system like miniature games.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Pros: The game design is impressive. This fact cannot be denied. It is also relatively easy to play once the game structure is understood. There are turn structure cheat sheets on BBG which help beginners.
There is a great deal of cards. Again, that cannot be denied. Wizards of the coast releases a new set every 3 month. It adds an incredible replay value. Imagine your favorite board game getting an expansion every 3 months. Madness and fun.
Cons: The rarity system which changes the card dollar value. Some cards are worth $10-30 because they are rare. This is the basis of a collectible card game obviously, but it does hamper enjoyment for the casual player. There are some cards I would like to buy but won't because of their cost.
With that, comes the obvious level unfairness between players. Some players will have amazing expensive cards which there will be little you can do against. Great players can win even with a poor deck but for the rest of us, we get trounced in 3 turns. Not awesome.
Finally, the seriousness of the players. There are fun casual formats like cube or pauper, but very few players will play them. These format level the field by either allowing players to pick from the same deck of cards or by using only common cards. This means that the advantage the money spent on rare cards can afford, is not available to the player, and therefore, many players will not play casual formats. A shame since I feel the game itself is great.
A final note. The artwork is fantastic. No other game offer such a visual treat.
Edit: With the release of the Theros block, we now have solo decks available. This improves the game for casual gamers considerably.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
I started playing Magic when Ice Age came out, stopped for a few years and continued with Weatherlight (or was it Stronghold?) all the way through to Urza`s Legacy, after which I decided I wouldn`t buy any more new cards. In retrospect my collection was tiny, comprising of about three-four hundred cards only, but I still got around to build decent decks through active trading.

In my opinion Magic always had good, logical mechanics (even with the timing problems, which we always managed to solve easily). I never took it too seriously playing laid back games with my regular opponents on a regular basis. We used to play differently themed decks, eg. goblins, soldiers, the undead, and when one became a nuisance we moved on to the next. The games were gentlemanly, there were no antes and one of my opponents, clearly better in Magic than I was, always used to scale down his decks to have a decent game. It was a nice fun game among other good games.

I never quite understood the mania around Magic, with entirely sane people shoveling huge portions of their financial resources into bits of coloured cardboard. Most of them ended up selling their entire collections and losing a lot of money in the process.

I stopped collecting Magic when it started to become a little dull, and the new cards seemed only to be redesigned versions of old ones. Apparently the game itself has not seen that much a fall in its popularity, judging by the rate they still churn out new expansions.

I still have my cards and pull them out once or twice a year when I want to relive some of the magic of old days. It's a good and well designed game.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 8

RATING: 8
Real good game, maybe one of the greatest of all time, at least as far as card games go.  Too bad there are $$$ problems (pay to play) and the player base of retarded 15 year olds.  Do you know how you confuse the average magic player?  You draw a triangle with a duck in the middle of it.  Seriously, he'll just stare at it trying to figure out what you just did.

If I had unlimited money, time, and opponents, it would likely be a 9 or 10.  As it is, with its limitations, its probably a 6 or 7...  the Xbox version ranks somewhere in the middle.  

Anyway, If the cost wasn't so high I could see myself getting back into this.  I like CCGs and this was/is one of the best.  The money-fication of the CCG world is one of the great tragedies of tabletop gaming, and MTG is the posterboy.

Update:  The xbox live arcade version somewhat captures the fun of this for only ten bucks.  All there in game tactics are there, you can tweak the decks a little bit (not completely but enough to be fun) and it scratches the magic itch.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8.75

Magic the gathering video game
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
Collection: My Cube

A well-crafted game. Nicely illustrated. Ridiculously expensive. Even to play casually with a group of friends and a bunch of random cards can get a bit pricey. This game avoids erratas and confusion much better than most CCG's especially given the sheer amount of cards in the system. The best things about this game are the ubiquitousness (making it easy to find events and opponents), generally easy to grasp rules, and the ease of deckbuilding. Unlike many other CCGs, it doesn't take a ton of cards to build a decent deck. With fewer than 1000 cards, you can easily build 8-10 fun and different decks. Probably the distinguishing characteristic is how few cards you get each turn. Hand management and resource management are paramount here. It is much more tense and unforgiving than some other CCGs are.

Over time, I have come to appreciate more and more how much this is not just a game, but a system. A relatively simple rule set creates so many different ways to play that there is something for everyone. I think this is by far the most well-designed and most-playtested game in modern times. It's a testament to what devoted gamers can do with a limitless budget and full team of creative people. So much focus is put into making this game be something for everyone, that it can hardly help but succeed. There is something here for you, and you do a disservice to yourself by not playing. 
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
I love the combos and the deck building aspect is fun if time consuming.  However, games are often one-sided, mana screwage is a big negative and it can get really expensive to keep up with every new expansions.

Here is why I'm done with Magic the Gathering and other games sharing similar gameplay mechanics. In my view, the game often boils down to the following sequence :
-Draw/Play card.
-Check how many defender you need to block the opponent's attack next turn.
-Attack with any left-over card if advisable.
-Realize you can't do much.
-Repeat ad nauseam until a player draw a card that can break the stalemate.

Also, those games have hundreds of different cards, each having their own unique effect.  Unless you invest a lot of time in playing the game, you spend a lot of time asking your opponent (or being asked) the stats/effect of each creature/hero being played.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 4
Magic the Gathering. I played this game from the Legends set (where everyone was talking about the new "gold" cards) up until Shields of Alara (sp?). I even played some Commander past that, but eventually my group got too competitive at it and I stopped.

Nowadays the gameplay has become pretty unbearable, and I just prefer to not play anymore. I could probably be coerced into playing (thus the 4) but I'd really rather not.

RATING: 10

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
I caught the tail end of the initial surge in popularity. Unfortunately, I was too late, in a matter like it is like collecting baseball cards. By the time I played it, my friends had amassed small libraries of these cards, and I wasn't about to spend money to catch up. This was a groundbreaking design. It was fun to construct your own deck, as much as it was about playing. In a matter of speaking, it scratches the same itch as the classic "Robot War" on the Apple II, and the TV show "Battle Bots". People love making/building/programming up stuff, and putting it to the test in a gladiator-style arena. Will my design survive? Will it win? It is the same with Magic. Can I "program" the ultimate deck? Thus, starts the addictive cycle of program/build, test/battle, debug/tweak, and retest/battle until you have the winning-est design/program/deck.

Unfortunately, the business model drives the game model, such that successively better, more powerful cards are constantly being introduced. It's great for the game company, but lousy for the gamer. My friends eventually caught onto this, and ditched their libraries for a small fortune. As a game played in isolation, it was wonderful. But when it became about who could buy/locate the next powerful card, and then sell it to the highest bidder, then it seemed like the original spirit of the game had been compromised. This is the same addiction cycle that I believe Dominion is trying to exploit. I sensed it, and stopped at Seaside.

This game seems like it is no longer something you can casually buy and play with a friend--I wish there was something very basic and self-contained (and thus my initial enthusiasm for Dominion), and there probably is something like it. It is more like a life-style, requiring lots of money and time to get good at. Like chess, I am not willing to make that investment.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
One word, 'Great!'.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
[center][size=6][COLOR=#878787]LIFETIME GAME [microbadge=28495]:star:[microbadge=28496] "PLAY FOREVER"[/COLOR][/size][/center]

[i]The best hobby game ever made.  Period.[/i]

My favorite thing about [i]Magic[/i] is that it is a game with literally thousands of pieces, all capable of interacting with each other in amazing and surprising ways; this fact allows a player to truly "play their personality" like no other game does.  [i]Magic[/i] does an incredible job of evoking its theme—wizards duelling with magic spells—by having you first craft a library of spells (your deck) and then "remembering" them (drawing cards during a game).  There is a big HOWEVER, however:  the game is best when played in a controlled environment where all players have access to the same number of cards, e.g., limiting card purchases to a predetermined number of decks and boosters.  [i]Magic[/i] breaks down horribly when the arms race spirals out of control and then the rich kid wins.  The very assets that make the game like no other are also the problems that plague and break it...  And yet I've played it constantly since '94, and will continue to do so.

PS.  This is the only Collectible Card Game that actually makes sense as a CCG, that is, the mechanical act of drawing and playing cards is akin to flipping through the pages of a spellbook.

PPS.  The hands-down best way to play if you don't want to get into the collecting aspect is to buy a couple of pre-constructed decks.

[microbadge=6108]

[b][thread=812649][/thread][/b]

[b][thread=1374704][/thread][/b]

RATING: 2

RATING: N/A
We play MtG at lunch time when running our school holiday program, Kraftworks for Kids. The program is for kids aged 9 - 14. The kids love this game. We have more than a dozen decks with each deck labelled according to its mana colours. The kids soon find a favourite deck. We pair up the beginners with one of the Leaders while those who have played a few games are able to play without assistance. While the game doesn't quite appeal to all kids (as Killer Bunnies does) those that like to play like it a lot. It is easy for adults to play with kids too.

RATING: 10
[b]LEARNING THE GAME, GETTING THE CARDS, BUILDING YOUR DECKS; THAT’S THE EASY PART. WHAT’S REALLY HARD IS QUITTING THE GAME AND NOT RELAPSING[/b]

*Note: Unlike other reviews of mine, this one will focus on MTG as a financial and social phenomenon, and not much in the game itself.

I don’t think there is anyone on this planet who prides him or herself a gamer or geek and has not heard of Magic: The Gathering (“[i]MTG[/i]” from now on). It is not uncommon to find board gamers and other breed of geeks that have a shoe box (Or more than one) filled with these cards somewhere in their closets, cellars or attics. The same goes to role-players, of which some have told me that in the beginning there was some sort of competition between which game was better: MTG or RPGs. Irrelevant, they’re both interesting and fun. And that’s hardly the point of my review.

As the fore father of all contemporary trading, collectible or living card games (TCG, CCG and LCG, respectively), the brain child of Richard Garfield is maybe one of the most beloved games of all times, and it has been since its creation in 1993. Back then of course, rules were simple, card abilities were very few and most easily to understand and learn how to combine them and tournament rules and games were mere reunions between friends curious about who had the best deck, the best cards or just who the best player was. Nowadays, there are over 30 different abilities, more than 7 different “colors” or “factions” (If you will…) and over 30 different editions, each with their own rules, abilities, card types and whatnot. The game has definitely thrived, but because of this, it has also turned into some sort of addiction amongst the geek community world wide.

Amazingly enough, there are cards (Mere pieces of paper with a few words and a cool drawing on them) that are worth $500 (five hundred) dollars or more and certain cards depicting the artwork of specific artists (Rebecca Guay, Jesper Ejsing, John Howe, etc) are collector’s items. The whole MTG universe is just not for the game itself, but also for art dealers, finance aficionados and other people with particular interests. A person wanting to buy a deck or booster packs in these days must know that they’re actually investing in something bigger than the small pack of cards they’re paying for.

Now, let’s make a brief comparison between being a MTG player back in 1995 and being one in 2011: The former player is (most likely) just interested in playing a fun game with some friends and likes to collect cards, all beautifully designed and illustrated by some guys with serious talent for the arts; The latter is not only buying a product manufactured by one of the most rich multinational gaming companies of all time, but also, he or she is investing in the long or short term in items (I.e., cards) that could very well be worth separately twice the price paid for the deck or booster pack just bought. Maybe he’s not into playing the game, but only in accumulating paper wealth and art.

 Call me old-fashioned, but I don’t think I like being a (retired) MTG player in 2011. I think I would still love the game if it were 1995. But all in all, the game still rocks, it is still amazing and maybe, JUST MAYBE, it’s completely worth the money paid for those precious little pieces of hard paper. Also, maybe I’m just bluffing and I will eventually relapse into this immortal game/investment.

[b][i]I. Criteria[/b][/i]

Mechanics: :d10-1::d10-0:
Design & Art:  :d10-1::d10-0:
Packaging & Presentation: :d10-1::d10-0:
Theme: :d10-1::d10-0:
BGG Factor: :d10-8:

[b][i]II. Sliders[/i][/b]

Abstract [b]________[COLOR=#FF0000][9][/COLOR]_[/b] Themed: Because of the incredible amount of editions in existence, it would be stupid to think the game needs no them to work. Most of the CCG obsessed gamers in the world will agree that theme is as vital (And sometimes more vital) as the mechanics and systems used by the game itself. Also, let’s not forget the infinite merchandise this game spawned, which is all about the adventures and themes within the Multiverse.
 
Simple [b]_________[COLOR=#FF0000][10][/COLOR][/b] Complex: Complexity in MTG is a very vague and abstract term. The deck building system each player in the world brings to the game table an endless array of possibilities and strategic ideas, but the complexity of the game itself, that is, how you play, how you put cards in play, how you pay for them, it’s as simple as tying your shoelaces. It is the player who decides how hard he will play or how intricate his strategy will work.

Strategic [b]__________[/b] Tactical: I believe it is unfair to firmly say that MTG is a purely strategic or tactical game, because players might decide to use their decks in such a way that strategies work depending on certain previous movements and decision, or maybe, players will decide if they want faster and more nimbler decks, filled with one-shots, each powerful enough to cause serious damage on the enemy’s game. 
 
Luck [b]_______[COLOR=#FF0000][8][/COLOR]__[/b] Skill: If we were to think of beginners and veteran players as the same breed, certainly the skill factor would come to be on top of the luck element, but sometimes your deck won’t be very well flushed or sometimes the one card you need is taking a bit too long to appear. I have seen amazingly built decks fall to its knees before simpler and much weaker decks, only because the weaker deck was faster and the player got lucky. However, as I said before, it is all up to the player’s deck building system.

Fiddly [b]______[COLOR=#FF0000][7][/COLOR]___[/b] Elegant: Because of the outrageous amount of news rules and abilities each edition block comes out with, the necessity for a player to know how things work is essential to the game. Sometimes you may not really know how a certain card works, but most likely than not, the guy next to you or the salesperson of the shop you bought the card at might know what it does. Of course, exceptions always exist, but a quick question to an experienced player is sometimes all you need.
 
Indirect interaction [b]_________[COLOR=#FF0000][10][/COLOR][/b] Direct interaction: I won’t even address this particular slider. It is an obvious 10-Direct Interaction kind of game. 

Cutthroat [b][COLOR=#FF0000][1][/COLOR]_________[/b] Friendly: Considering the fact that winning is only achieved once you kill your opponent or make him bleed his deck out, friendly playing is not really a good idea in this game.

Heavy use of language [b]____[COLOR=#FF0000][5][/COLOR]_____[/b] No language needed: Given the fact that the game is released monthly in over 13 languages, language plays a very important role, but it’s not like you won’t be able to play if you don’t know English or whatever language the card is written in.

[b][i]III. Number of players recommended[/i][/b]: 2.

[b]CHEERS![/b]

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
There is no game that has had as much an effect on me as Magic: The Gathering.

This is not an uncritical endorsement. There are many parts of MtG that are deeply flawed. Randomized packs. The predatory rotation cycle. Deep undercurrents of sexism in the community. All of these are very severe flaws that would damn another game for me.

That being the case, please understand that it is with an awareness of these flaws that I still rate MtG a ten.

I played since I was around 9 or 10 years old, starting out with my sister crushing me over and over with a faeries deck that I could not figure out how to beat. I played casually for years after that, before starting out a streak of competitive play around 2012/2013. This took off around 2014/2015, and it got to the point that on any given evening, I was more likely than not at a tournament of some sort.

My specialty was drafting, and I dare say I got to be a player that was (at least locally) considered pretty good. I could consistently 4-0 or 3-0 online pods and local tournaments.

Eventually, I realized I had to give it up. The time I was sinking in had led to me jumping significantly in skill, but the next step would have been committing whole hog. I'd have to drop other games, play competitively online, and likely get into a local testing group to really jump to the next level. I had a wife, friends who really didn't care about Magic, and a demanding job. I let the dream go, and gradually began spinning off my collection.

Magic taught me a lot in my time with it. I never thought that I could have gotten as far as I did, and it gave me a lot of confidence in my ability to learn and improve. The regimented method of always looking for holes in my game, and the ability to suppress my emotions to continue playing for my best shot to win has carried over into my life. I feel that I have become better at assessing my own performance, not just in games, but also in day to day life. I'm patient with my own mistakes (or at least, more than I used to be), and I am much better at hearing criticism than I used to be. All these things came from my time playing competitive Magic, along with countless other gifts and lessons I haven't listed here.

Magic is a deeply flawed game in many respects. There are countless barriers to entry, and there are very serious questions about the ethics of its business model. It is still impossible for me to not rank it a 10. If something that was so formative for me and that I played for so long through so much of my life isn't a ten, what is?

Edit:
After reconsidering, I'm going to drop this to a 6, which more accurately represents my willingness to play the game nowadays. I still deeply appreciate the joy and learning MtG brought me, but if I'm rating according to BGG's scale, I rarely want to play anymore.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8.25
LOVE THIS GAME.
Ran into this game in summer of 2013. And I must say, I am so sad that I hadn't started playing sooner. I love the concept! From the land tapping, to the wicked combos and abilities, to that moment when your opponent brings out a huge creature... and you counter it with one card. *sigh* It's priceless.
Now I'm still new and I do have to ask some stupid sounding questions from time to time (at least, they sound stupid to me). But from my experience, the Magic community is just that: a community. They have been patient with my questions, my odd deck ideas, my witty humor.  
The only cons I have of this game... is the price. BUT, that isn't going to change. Black Lotus will always be the king of card prices (unless they decide to reprint... which would be hilarious and WRONG). But you don't have to dump a lot of money into the game to have fun. Either pick up a starter deck and some boosters ($20 + about $4 per booster), or go to a card shop and talk to the employees. I had them build me a deck that cost less that $15 (and it seems to be doing fairly well too).

Bottom line, if you like card games you have to try this. If you like fantasy, you have to try this. If you want to play a game with a huge community of players, you need to try this game. And if you are a geek... you must try this. Seriously, I think it's a requirement to being a geek.

RATING: 10
Its complex interactions, pre-game deck building and ever changing environment (not to mention great art) keeps me coming back year after year.  I discovered the game back when Alpha & Beta had just sold out.  I tend to get bored fairly quickly, this game made me a fan of CCG's despite there higher cost of entry.

It's crazy that a few weeks before I encountered MTG, a friend and I had come up with a concept of making a card game that would be based on the theme of two wizards dueling/fighting.  Cards would consist of spells and artifacts, so as soon as I read a small article about MTG, I had to check it out.

RATING: 8.1
Good game system, but not a game I enjoy near as much as many others.  Would take a huge time investment to become familiar enough with the game to enjoy it more.

Raised the rating after doing a booster draft with the current set (Return to Ravnica).  Had a good experience and would like to do more booster drafting.

Drafted Gatecrash at a Friday night magic in Alameda with Ashton, then went to the Dragon's Maze pre-release sealed event at Channel Fireball.  Enjoyed both.  Limited is definitely the way I'll enjoy this game.  Also holding on to cards to re-make budget packs, so the limited fun can continue at home.

I really enjoy limited Magic, but won't be playing it much since it requires going to a magic shop.  I just don't enjoy the vast majority of the people there.  I'll keep my eye out for chances to draft in other settings with friends.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 4
Magic: The Gathering is a decent and fast playing, hand management card game, but there are so many better card games out there (Race for the Galaxy and Yomi are two of my favorite). 

The main problem I have with M:tG is that given two decks there is very little replayability. The replayability is derived almost entirely from the novelty  of seeing what decks you can design and testing them against each other. The game requires a constant influx of new cards to keep it interesting.
That being said, I am fairly confident that a good game designer could design a couple of decks that would be interesting to play against each other 100s of times (WotC sells "Duel Decks" but they just aren't really very good). If this were to happen I would probably buy a set.

There is also a huge learning curve if you want to play the game correctly as many keywords and abilities do not work how you would expect. For example:
A creature can be indestructible; this means that the creature cannot take damage or be "destroyed" BUT if the creature has enough -1 counters placed on it to reduce it's toughness to 0 it can still die. 
The game is full of little things like this that make it very hard to learn.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 9
As a casual game using similar and/or limited card pools this game is better than almost everything on the geek in my opinion, and I would rate it a solid 10.   It is a game of tactics (during play) and strategic imagination (deckbuilding).

However, played in the tournament environment it devolves into a game of who owns the best cards and plays the best net deck.  Played this way I give it a solid 4.  Since I have moved I have no casual players to play with so I am stuck with tournament play. (Ugggh) 
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
[b]Favorite game of 1993/all time[/b]

It requires strategy, tactics, and skill. All while simultaneously being a conflict, puzzle, and a race, and is successful in each of those aspects. The most innovative game of its era that spawned a bunch of mediocre knockoffs and inspired designers for generations to come. One of the few games that can also be an investment.

FFGs Living Card Game model fixes the uneven playing field inherent in a random distribution model and all but eliminates the secondary market, which is positive or negative depending on your perspective. I sold my collection, and all I got was a lousy nest egg and a downpayment on a house. 

The only way I play anymore is with proxied block decks and [url=http://www.cubetutor.com/draft/90166][b]My Cube [/b][/url], which I'm slowly de-powering in order to add one card from every regular set, and as many unique, playable keywords as possible. Sorry banding...

My rating is biased due to nostalgia, but despite the game's [url=https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/B._F._Skinner]Skinnerian[/url] distribution model, it is technically still a game, and if you rate it a 1, [url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=LXWhQ2cY5sE]we can't be friends.[/url]

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 7.5
Got piles of cards. Really a great easily approachable head to head duel with good tactical and some strategic play, luck is quite present as well though as in when the cards come to you. There is some strategy to be sure and more so if you set up your deck, knowing your opponents cards to set up against them helps here and we don't fuss too much with this as we have out set decks that we like. 

We usually play this as a late night filler and it is still quite fun to play after many years, however the collectibility aspect of it went way too far. Great replayability in this game with even 100 or 200 cards each, which would be cheap purchased the right way. I also have lots of Middle Earth cards as well and after reading the rules(haven't played yet) ME does look to be a better, more involved, more strategic but also far more complex game I'm looking forward to with a fantastic theme of course!

RATING: 6
Moderately fun game but I always had bad luck with mana. The same deck would go mana starved one game and then flooded the next. It's a frustrating mechanic and honestly I think it hurts the game more than it lets it do interesting things. Maybe I need to learn to shuffle better. Plus the fact that constructed formats make the game a huge money sink. Even doing drafts isn't super cheap. And I don't find the fun added by doing a draft to make up for the loss of deck quality versus constructed. Though again that deck quality comes at the expense of affordability. Plus the fact that to do well you really need to know all the cards, which change out constantly, making this much more of a time sink than I'm interested in.

RATING: 8
Great game, pretty easy to learn, fun to play with someone with the same level of experience. Plenty of strategy and easily found for sale at retail stores. I stopped collecting because I was tired of being broke all the time.

RATING: 7

Why oh why the eight million different rules, each with a card somewhere that breaks it?  Sigh...there needs to be a nice, self contained, NON-collectible spin-off of magic, one that has good cards and fun mechanics right out of the box.

I feel the game has gotten too complex for its own good.  Right now I am LOVING the downloadable Xbox 360 version of this game....$10 bucks for multiple decks with tons of cards, no expansions needed.  It's what I want from Magic.

RATING: N/A
I played heavily from The Dark through Tempest.  I played "Type I" before that distinction existed, and mainly stuck to that format for the ~10 years that I played.  Super complicated rules (at the tournament level at least), and the collectible aspect should have been deterrents, but the game was absolutely fascinating to me.  I have since stopped playing, and have sold out of most of my old power / beta cards, however this game will always be important to me as it was ultimately my gateway into BGG-style gaming.

Were it not for M:TG, I wouldn't have been introduced to Settlers the night before Gen Con in 1996.  And really, I probably wouldn't have been there at all.  And true to its name, "The Gathering," I can trace almost every one of my current friends and gaming partners back to M:TG in one way or another.  It was the thing that initially brought us together in college and beyond.

I have a friend who is trying to pull me back in via the Elder Dragon Legend Highlander format.  Fun without worrying about keeping up with the tournament scene.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
This is where the BGG rating system breaks down.  Is this a 3 because I'll never play it again?  Not at all.  It is both a moneymaking machine and a mechanical masterpiece, with more replayability than any other game I've played...by an order of magnitude.  I don't think it's an overstatement to say I've played 1000 times and still have the desire to trot out my crappy mono-Green Gorilla deck from time to time, the only deck I still own.

Two issues ultimately make this a 9 for me instead of a 10:  complexity and game balance/expense.  The complexity is at the heart of what makes Magic so great.  At the same time, having to learn new keyworded abilities, as well as keep current on rules revisions, makes playing a proper game of Magic a chore.  A rewarding chore, but still at times a chore.  The game balance issue is between players who invest different amounts of money in the game -- between players of equal or near-equal skill, the player who invests more has a decided edge.  The alternative is limited play, which can cost upwards of a hundred dollars a sitting for a group of eight players, and as much as I love the game that's ultimately an investment that precludes frequent play.  Even Civ + Advanced Civ at eBay prices beats this value after only two sittings.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8

RATING: 6

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
This one taught me the meaning of addiction. The biggest problem, of course, is its tendency to favor people with money. The problem that bothers me the most (and the one that eventually led me to leave the game behind) is how later releases re-issued powerful cards from previous editions at a more common rate. It was frustrating to have spent a long time in the game only to play a new player with money who had new versions of cards that were, originally, very hard to get.

I'd not suggest this one to too many people (as it's really addictive) but I still participate with friends who haven't changed their decks (and don't collect anymore) in a few years.

Edit: rating reflects the current game and not, so much, the game I "retired from." I recently played a friend who still plays with a deck from 7 or 8 years ago. My great deck had turned into a mediocre deck because of the incredible cards that were FAR more common in his deck. He had cards that read like jokes we had made when I played.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
An incredibly elegant framework that's open just enough to allow for seemingly endless combinations of mind-challenging card interplays.

Yes, it's collectible. I'm not sure why that's a problem, though. One of the definitions of "hobby" would be something that one is willing to spend money and time on. Typically a game group (of any type) tends to run at most 15 people. So why there can't be a LOT of fun had with MTG among those 4-15 people escapes me. I think people whine about expensive cards because they honestly expect to play at the Pro Tours.

The game grows and evolves and then goes back to revisit old themes and reprint some cards. There's nostalgia. There's excitement. There are tense, "who's going to win" situations. And a certain amount of luck always plays a part in the game. The best deck could lose to a craptastic deck once in a while based on card draws. That's all card games.

It's just a beautiful, beautiful game that won't be getting old during our lifetimes.

It might be the only game that I am ALWAYS willing to play. I definitely consider myself, first and foremost, a Eurogamer, but this game is just so elegant, you can't escape it's brilliance.

It's the best game in my collection... And I've got A LOT of games. I don't even want to start putting them all on BGG. I just keep my own spreadsheet. (And in the comments column, Magic is the only one that says "Best Game Ever."... I suppose it SHOULD be the only one that says that... that's what a superlative implies...)

You'll lose a LOT of games at first, but be patient. It is extremely worth the effort and bruises to break into understanding the possibilities.

Did I mention it's just a really darn good game?
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
An enduring game.  I was told about this game in 1993 by a friend who told me that a new game came out that was good for two players.  I rushed out to find it and have been playing it ever since.  The game has infinite levels of complexity so ten year olds can play with each other and adults who have spent years playing can play each other.  However, the game does not do well when people of different skill levels play each other.  The more skilled player will win over and over again and one can devote years to becoming more skilled.

RATING: 8
Magic is a sprawling game, beautiful and flawed at the same time.  It's probably best thought of as a game system, as opposed to a single game.  While the game I've probably played the most in my life, it's not perfect.  However, it's easy to find a game if I want to play, and a number of innovations, such as the way it uses drafting, have made a big impact on game design.  I would say Magic is the most important and influential game of the past 20 years, and is up there with Dungeons and Dragons vying for most influential "designed" game (as opposed to "traditional") of all time.

RATING: 8
Started the whole CCG genre and I was there from Alpha. It's best when played from a draft or sealed deck tourney. My most played game ever. The game provided me hours and hours of fun and for a while I was the Champion at local tournaments, this is why it's one of my all-time favorites and still gets played with pre-arranged decks. I sold my set of power cards for over $5,000 and paid for cards then and now. I also sold sets I collected for another $2,000. 

UPDATE 2011: was insulted for what I was offered at Origins so I got Dave and Ogden into playing again. We played for a solid year and now it's trailed off again after we all spent more money then intended.

UPDATE 2015: EVERYTHING is sold. Drove to Buffalo and put 5 G's in my pocket. This was the only game that paid me to play it.  
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
The grand daddy of all the card collecting games in the world. Three to four sets popping out every year for 15+ years. More money made from this CCG then all the other CCGs combined.
The first game with card combos. A fantasy game with great art, and abilities are every card.
Take 60 cards, some with resources (22) and the rest with up to four copies of an individual card. Cards come in three types when I played: Common, Uncommon and Rare.
People would go out and buy the best of the best cards and play in tournaments.
Making up strange decks to play with leads to fun fun and disaster when against finely tuned decks.
This game will drain your wallet and bank account. Highly addictive. 
I switched over the online play and bought virtual cards. Seldom did I buy expensive cards, all I wanted was to make simple decks that were fun to play with. I no longer play with cards, just online about once a year, or I will get in trouble with the wife.

---original comment---
Fun, I love putting together unique decks.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
Magic: The Gathering offers so much to love. The infinite possibilities of colors, strategies, card combos, etc. make for a uniquely enjoyable experience. Aside from the brilliance in the tactical subtleties in the timing and execution of attacks, when and how to defend, etc., where MTG truly shines is its customizable aspect. Deck construction itself is a rich, enjoyable process with layers of strategic decisions to be made. The possibilities are truly endless, and your imagination can be unleashed in the process of "creating" the game. Some critics of the game deride the mana shortage/flood issues that can occur, but astute deck construction minimizes this potential pitfall. It is also very easy to teach and introduce to new players. Magic is easily the most creative, original, and enjoyable contribution to the card game genre in the modern era.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
I used to play this game a lot when I were younger. In many ways it appealed to me ... appart from collecting the cards I liked to just sort them, construct decks and trade with my friends. I had fun scanning the pictures and manipulating them or find funny pictures which I glued on the cards ... people actually found some of them so funny they wanted to trade with me.

Now however I find that I havent' got either the time or the money for this game.

It has several "flaws" ... like the banned and restricted lists ... or the competitions where you need to have a lot of really expensive cards to make a difference ... or people getting hustled by their not so nice trading "buddies" ... or that it is so popular that people actually makes fake cards.

RATING: 10
This was THE gateway game for us... then Carcassonne and Catan.

Addictive game.  (Yes, I'm ashamed to admit, that during a sudden moment of weakness, about 20 years ago, over the internet, I was perfectly willing to trade my very good conditioned, however, slightly used husband for a mint conditioned 'Icy Manipulator'... I just couldn't afford the postage on him (165 lbs) at the time and the deal eventually fell through after 4 days of humorous e-mails...)  

We still have our 25  'kick-ass' constructed theme decks in card sleeves, (and yes, I still have Bruce) and occasionally play a game with our sons who have both since gone through their own 'Magic' phases.  Still today our refrigerator is graced with homemade magnets from useless 'Atog' cards.  The collectability and constant rule revisions eventually lessened the appeal for us.  An exilerating ride while it lasted though.

With 20/20 hindsight... money well spent, IMO.

I also use Deck Builder HD on my iPad

RATING: 2
The original money pit! If at first opponents buying/trading for rare cards that you couldn't counter wasn't annoying enough, Wizards Of The Coast introduced a two wave/base set limit on tournaments that forced players to keep sinking money into their collection on a regular basis (with reprints dropping the value of cards dramatically).

PLUS: easy to learn, involves players
MINUS: large collection required
HUGE MINUS: tournament structure
MEGA-SUPER MINUS: money pit!!!!

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
Regardless of whether or not you like collectible games, the mechanisms in this game are tops. People that talk about how they argue about game rules simply don't know the rules of this game. The rules exist, its not a mystery. If you don't want to look up rules, then at least don't complain about the game being unplayable because the player who spends most wins. The player who knows the rules and makes the best decisions wins. I have played in many high level tournaments and can assure you, winning is not based on money. I will admit that this game can be extremely expensive, but it doesn't have to be. This game also takes significant amounts of studying to master. I have played for over 10 years and understand the rules well, but new players may find them daunting. Overall the flavor, R&D, incredible freedom, and constant evolution of this game can not be beat.

RATING: 6.5
Like all former D&D addicts from my high school years, I got into M:tG for a short stint in the mid 90's - good thing I was still a student, or I would have spent (wasted) even more money on it.  I still think the game mechanics are excellent (the system of "distributed rules" on the cards, and the theming of the 5 magic colours, and the deck-building "meta-game" were real innovations for such a mainstream game), but the collectable aspects make it less enjoyable.

Knizia's Blue Moon was a gallant attempt at toning down the less fun aspects of M:tG while keeping the essence, but still to find something that really brings it all together ...

RATING: 9
One of the best card games I've played. The game's design is simple and elegant, completely diceless and resolved many problems that earlier card games had. Sadly, too many generations of new rules have destroyed this once beautiful game.

The deck-building aspect is brilliant because of the wide variety of cards and the different way they could be put together. I don't think any CCG comes close to blending simplicity with flexibility the way Magic has.

RATING: 6
BGG rating: 6
Rating just on game play/enjoyment: 6

Played two 3-player games with Archemeny rules.  Very chaotic seeming (I'm sure this gets better as you learn the cards and learn/build your deck) but fun.

Archemeny was brutal with only 2 players facing the archemeny.  It will be interesting to see how it goes against 3 others.

A couple more plays have lowered the rating for me.  Maybe it is that Archenemy isn't very good.  But it has happened too often that my hand gets reduced to 0-1 cards and then the games becomes completely devoid of choices and thus completely uninteresting to me.

I've played some games using the Commander decks, which I enjoy more than Archenemy. But at my level of play luck of the draw seems to be too big of a factor which is hurting my enjoyment of the game.

I only play it because a couple friends really like it.

RATING: 7
I have played MTG for nearly 10 years. Once upon a time this rating would have been a 10+, however, lately the game has lost some of its magic (pardon the pun). =-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Before M:tG I had been playing RPGs and some Games Workshop stuff, but this game made me a gamer in the summer of 1996. It is still the most addictive game I know and I've played thousands of matches between 1996 and 2003. At that point I had grown weary of the increasingly competitive nature of the community which wasn't that interested in casual play and toying with weird deck ideas. Also I didn't fancy the direction the game was going in. Originally players were the magicians, today they just play cards and there are these unneeded things called planeswalkers. Originally the art was interesting and varied, today it is just bland and generic fantasy art. M:tG has become become just seldom fun for me.

My all time favorite formats are T1, T1.5, Cube, Highlander and drafting from a commons box.

My all time favorite deck types to play have been WW, 5C No hand control (which was ruined somewhat by the removal of mana burn) that you could maybe call "Hellbent" with today's terms, G control with big hitters, G LD with lots of mana elves, U Snake Basket with varied artifact mana generation, Browse-Digger, RW Landkill, and 5C Counter madness utilizing Giant Fan.

Currently I have only a playable WW Highlander deck, ideas for new 5C Hellbent and various other cards from olden days.

RATING: 7
This is a brilliant game but its score is pulled down by the business model. Even if you have the money or skill to play it competitively it is just too time consuming for someone like me to keep up with card introduction and deck building, even if you only play limited formats. There are so many cards that if you don't play in tournaments (where judging the metagame is an important skill element) the winner will likely be determined by who has the right hoser cards to deal with the other player's specialized creation. Getting mana-screwed or land-flooded can be frustrating to some players although that was never a big issue for me. It is, however, a minor design flaw. If money and time were not an issue for me and I could play in tournaments frequently I would rate constructed Magic an 8 and limited Magic a 9.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Groundbreaking card game of magicking out dudes and flipping them turn-ways. Clever in several ways, though slightly wonky until the 6th Edition rules revision. Unfortunately, but perhaps unavoidably, the commercial context has undercut the game itself from the beginning. Still, it's very impressive.

From a design/play viewpoint, I dislike the fact that there exist more than ten thousand unique cards, many or most of which are messy, pointless, underpowered, overpowered etc., or have inelegant variations and permutations of block-specific abilities. If you could pick, say, the 1000-2000 "best" ones and play constructed with unlimited access to those, you would have a marvellous game. That's in part the theory behind cube drafting, I suppose.

I only own a few cards myself (received as gifts; the business model pretty much meant I would never get into buying cards), but have had a ton of fun playing with other people's cards, playing with proxies, playing and modding the Microprose computer game, and just checking out the new sets as they are released.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 1.5
Used to play this semi-professionally, put in many hours playing, deck building, traveling for DCI events and spent thousands of dollars on this game and then I burned out HARD (although a later audit of my winnings and the sale of my collection showed that I came out several thousand ahead, hooray!). Would be a 9.5  based on mechanics and did not have issues with collectability, printing, cost, greed and constant revision issues. Still willing to play with those 2-player battle decks, but not otherwise. 

For the people who keep randomly asking in PMs, -NO- I will not sell you my remaining collection, the last few cards I have either have sentimental value or are worth far more than you're willing to pay.

Update: I have been convinced to play the odd game of commander using someone else's deck and this format puts a great new spin on the game and I very much enjoy it. I am also glad to say that even being introduced to commander, I have no desire to start collecting again.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 2
I know I'm committing sacrilege by typing this, but I dislike MTG. I picked it up in '95 and played for about four years until I moved to Iowa. I found a game shop that had tournaments and whatnot, but every single person there was a complete and utter tool. Many of them were playing the old "rogue rules" of when you lost a card, you LOST the card. I avoided places like that, but as money started to become tight, had to stop. I eventually sold off my collection, so don't ask me what cards I had.

I never got started again because I felt it would draw me back in again and I would be spending too much money.

Today, seeing people in game shops get so fraking anal about rules and the condition of cards just makes me weep.

If you enjoy it, fine. More power to you.

RATING: 7.75
I will always remember my great experiences with this game. It changed my gaming culture, so to speak. It opened my eyes to the evolving gaming market.
There was NOTHING like opening up a pack of The Dark, and hoping to get the Maze of Ith!  lol!

Would rate higher if not for the monopoly Wizards puts on this genre.
Other fine games cannot survive because of the chokehold this company has on the market.
Also, tooo many expansions have kinda killed it for me.
I wont spend anymore money and Ill be just happy with the cards I have from 3rd edition to Planeshift or so...and tons of fond, fond memories of all the hours I have spent playing, building, discussing/debating and collecting this amazing all-time great!

****************update Jan 2012*******************

Well, some local friends have taken to this game and I have picked it back up.  Using some old decks (thanks to them for being considerate and understanding, hehe) and bought some new stuff even though I said I wouldn't anymore!
It's just such a great game...especially when there are other just as "into it" as you are!

**************update Mar 2012*********************

Well, unfortunately I truly HATE what Wizards has done with the game in their latest releases...
I'll stick to the M:TG I know...

RATING: 10
I give this game such a high rating because I have been playing it for more than 20 years (started with Revised) and am still going.  I still find time monthly to meet up with the same people I originally started playing with and we play a few hands of Magic between board games.  It is basically our permanent go-to filler game.  The one big negative I see with it is the cost... especially if you are seeking some of the older, rarer cards.  Thankfully, I (and my group) started playing back in the dark ages, so I got those cards in packs and don't have to now mortgage my home to get them.  My investment in the game now is very mellow compared to what it once was.  I am honestly amazed how long this game has kept going for us.  The huge variety and the depth that this game can have keeps us coming back for more.  The game I have played more than any other... ever.  (Not counting D&D.)  ;-)
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
A friend said to me, "if I teach you this, in 6 months don't come back to me saying its my fault when you are broke and can't afford more cards". =-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
If you feel the need to own all expansions for any game you own (like I do), DON'T GET INTO MAGIC.  This is an addictive game.  Don't get me wrong, I loved the way this game played, I've just found that it's an emotional, and money, pit in the long run.  I kept buying the cards, and buying the cards, and WOtC kept printing new ones (well duh, of course).  I also found that the competition was getting more stressful because of the nature of a majority of the people who play it.  I began to feel like I was among junkies looking for their next fix, whether to crush the competition with ultra-expensive decks, or to try to milk every last drop of a cards worth (or lack-of) in a trade, to justify the money spent on cards.  I hated the high emotions of the people I had to deal with who had so much "invested" in their habit and took it too personally.  The fun opponents I played with in the beginning became fewer and far between.  I was getting tired of the collecting grind, but I felt guilty giving up on my "investment" in cards.  Finally, my wife saved me by forcing me to sell the cards shortly after Ice Age(thank goodness).  And now I'm enjoying collecting complete-in-themselves games.  I feel much more satisfied with gaming now.  I look back at Magic now, and see all of the expansions, and still feel a little twinge of interest about it's evolution, but I also see how much money I would have wasted had I continued collecting.  In my opinion, there are many more satisfying games in this world.  Do yourself a favor, don't get addicted.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
My relatively low rating is from disliking the game, rather than feeling it's a poor game.  Ie. I just don't like it enough to keep playing it.  I imagine many of my core c complaints lessen with more plays and more money as you create your own custom decks, I just don't have the time or money to invest in playing this enough to make it very interesting (or the desire to do so).  The random elements of the game leave me feeling frustrated, as I've seen roughly half the games I'm in either won or lost because people couldn't draw enough lands, or drew too many.  And the pervasive feeling that no matter what I play, there's always the chance that they'll have some card that counters it (with virtually no way to either know of its existence, or counter-counter it), leaves me wondering, "Why bother."  Ultimately, to scratch this itch, I'd rather be playing Blue Moon.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 9
Update after 24 plays:  The collectable nature of the game has brought this down for me.  My son invested in some reasonably priced rare cards and tailored his deck to be very competitive.  I'll need to buy a few specific cards to keep up.

Update after 14 plays:  I'm hooked!  I have a fairly cheap deck, but by following some of the tips in the strategy forums here on the 'geek, I've been pretty competitive with my son so far.

Fun game!  Easy to learn and tremendous expansion possibilities.  My 12-year old son and his friends enjoy this game and he taught it to me.  I can see why this game has become a classic, and also why it can become a money pit if you get addicted!

RATING: 8
A great CCG, albeit one that costs an inordinate amount of money to play competitively at most Friday Night Magic events.  Add in the extremely quick pace for new set releases, the removal of certain core cards from standard play only to have the exact same card released with new art and a new name in a new set of cards, the frustration of randomized booster packs, and this is one of those games you love as much as you hate.  I thought the game was better before the Planeswalker card type was introduced, as games lasted longer and offered themselves up to more strategy, but it's still a great game.  The greatest CCG in my admittedly limited experience with the game-type.  Thank god there are limited environment console versions of the game now, so I can afford other things.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 10
This is my desert island game.

Haven't played lately, but had much fun when I did in college. I love games where you have to deal what what's been dealt.  And deck creation...oh man, it's a mind game itself and (to me) as fun as the game itself (of course you need lots of cards).

Have to give it some credit for revolutionizing a whole industry.

I still have all my cards, and I did spend a lot of money, but I don't regret it. I know this is kind of sappy, but there's nothing but good memories for me (Joe, Blaire, Quan and other guys I only know by first name...thanks for the friendship).

Though I really only played during 1996-1997, I wouldn't turn down a game to this day.  I recently played in 2003, and I thought it was funny how everyone gawked at my old school cards.  I got comments like "I haven't seen that in a while."

RATING: N/A

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
Okay, I admit a few years back my rating was a 10. Rating sank for several reasons. First, they have made numerous rules changes that have annoyed me. Some are pointless reversals, and others just suck the fun out of it for me. With rules changes and many of the newer cards, you can have your cake and eat it too. I.E. Now you can block, tap to use your special power, and still do damage anyway. And the number of cards that you get back when they're destroyed, or are indestructable, or just plain reusable. It's like they've removed decision-making and resource management from gameplay. Stupid, stupid, stupid.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7.2
I'm very rusty.  For years, I have not played very often.  But back in the day, hundreds/thousands of games!  All my cards are old.  When I do think about playing again, deck building is much tougher now - as I don't recall all the neat interlocking stuff like I used to.  Or I forget which set had the card that has a certain effect...

I own a lot of Betas, and have plenty of cards through Fallen Empires.  I also got a few cards through the Urza's Saga set, but after Fallen Empires I slowed down on collecting.  My collection is comprised of:  Alpha - very few.  Beta - lots of commons & uncommons, a few rares.  Arabiam Nights - Complete Set.  Legends - Missing several rares.  Dark - complete set.  Ice Age - might be missing some rares.  Fallen Empires - complete.  I've forgotten the name of the set with all the artifacts, but I think I have a complete set.  I always liked those Mishra lands that could attack.  All my cards are worn.  

I still think Interrupts make sense.  I'm an old player still willing to play, but I am resistant to buying new cards.

I'm also more interested in playing against other vintage decks.  I recently played against a new deck, and felt it had supercharged killing efficiency.  Perhaps the old cards just don't work against the new decks.

RATING: 7
CCG. The original edition with its limited availability was the best version.  Everyone had different cards and you played with what you had.  No one owned multiples of every card.  The game was new, fresh, interesting and exciting.  Loved this game when it came out.  The game stopped being fun to play after Arabian Nights.  The Unlimited edition was a mistake.  Now it's all about the card combos.  The game is boring and predictable.  Also, I object to the business model of collectible games and I'm turned  off by the never ending stream of expansions and planned obsolescence of older cards.

UPDATE: While I still dislike the tournament scene and competitive Magic, in general, I do enjoy playing "Casual Magic".  MtG really is a very good game as its longevity in a very fickle market attests.

02_07
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
Magic: The Gathering spawned the genre of collectible card games and it is still arguably the best game of this type. It is certainly not for everyone considering its complexity and the addictive expandable nature that can make it a costly hobby unto itself. However, for those willing to put in a little time and coin it is a very rewarding game experience. It is a game of infinite variety with plenty of strategic & tactical elements both before the game (in deck selection/building) and during play.

RATING: 9.5
Archenemy [1vX; 3-3] *****
Planechase ***
Toolkit/Cube draft *****
Challenge Deck [Hydra] **
---
Such a great game system... 

Mainly play with pre-constructed decks but also mix it up with a few other ideas.

The 'planechase' packs are VERY cool for some random, fun games

The 'archenemy' is another great option - nonsymmetrical games are always fun and this works very well (4 players seems to be the best spot)

Finally, the 'cube' style draft make for  very cool evening - it is certainly nice to build up a deck and then send it out to fight. Gives a good feeling of 'ownership' and making your own luck!

RATING: 10
This is probably the best game ever. The rules are very interesting and were very innovative back then. Almost no limitation on how you build your deck- thousands of cards, tons of great artwork. 
When they changed the layout for the eighth edition I stopped buying new cards. My friends did the same. I think they've released so many new expansions since then that the game is great for new players anyway- but mixing the older cards with new ones seems terrible and I'll always hate the idea of changing game's layout for new expansions- it kills the game- make good layout from the beginning. The older layout was much better by the way. 

The thing that has killed the gathering spirit was the whole price list for cards- game had been much more magical before I got to know that list.
Now the best option is to try decks virtually and then buy specific cards. Cause when you want to trade cards with others it's like- yeah but this card is rare- gold- you see? So I want three uncommons for that. Wait but these uncommons are more expsensive that your rare- see?- so you give me two of these rare cards and I'll give you one uncommon... blablabla. It should be just "Money The Gathering" now.
I still have my old cards and I'll never get rid of them though.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 1
Back in the 90's (4th edition / Ice Age era) it was fun for a moment, but then I realized what a money drain it is if you want to keep up with the constantly changing tournament sanctions. The mechanics aren't bad, but the actually good cards and good combos vs. useless crap -ratio contributes only to the marketing scheme. Playing with just the basic summons etc. is pretty boring, so the highly collectible cards that twist the rules more are quite essential for bringing out the game. Hence M:TG doesn't interest me at all any longer.

A re-implementation of this as an affordable LCG could be worth a look with for example:
- reworkings of cards from Alpha to circa Ice Age with better balance, especially alternatives to the power nine or something like that
- all the completely useless cards removed

I have circa 140 cards worth trading left (mostly from the 4th ed. to Mirage), GM me for details.

RATING: 7.5
Magic: The Gathering was the first collectible card game, launching a new genre of hobby games in which each card could change the game rules in some way. Players are wizards attempting to reduce their opponent's life total to zero (or run them out of cards) by casting spells and attacking them with various creatures. Cards can be lands, which usually generate mana of various colors, or spells, which require a certain amount of mana to be used.

Not interested in the sink hole that is CCG's, but enjoy the game. So I invested in the 2014 Commander Decks of each color. 

Own:

Commander 2014 Deck - Guided by Nature (Green) 
Commander 2014 Deck - Forged In Stone (White) 
Commander 2014 Deck - Sworn To Darkness (Purple) 
Commander 2014 Deck - Built From Scratch (RED) 
Commander 2014 Deck - Peer Through Time (Blue)

RATING: 6
The CCG standard bearer for years now. Magic: The Gathering allows for excellent games when played by well-matched players and decks. The expense required to play is a large drawback, and the preconstructed decks--although inexpensive--lack the flavor and ingenuity of personally designed decks. Deck construction/tuning can require a lot of time, but can be quite fun. The game's card drawing mechanic hurts the game when one player suffers from unlucky draws (by either drawing too many or too few "land" cards). This is a design flaw that had haunted the game since day one. Despite any drawbacks, however, this game should be played by all gamers at least dozen times to experience the grand-daddy of all CCGs. {6}

:star::star::star::nostar::nostar:

RATING: 7.5
While M:TG started out as a wonderful creation, it has grown into a ravaging behemoth of a game.  I collected the cards from the late Beta release up until just before Ice Age came out, and I just finally stuck the 5,000+ cards I had into a suitcase and put it in the garage.  Not only did my interest in the game flag after playing it for a long period of time, but my interest in coming up with new and unusual decks seriously waned.  I've heard that the more recent addons are good and create a lot of game balance, but I honestly have no real interest in sinking another bucketload of money into a game which, apparently, will continue growing forever.  Perhaps it's time for them to stop adding on to the current game and start creating other sideline games that work off the same system, but have different themes.

RATING: 3
The prolem with MTG is like monopoly. You cannot blame it too much because it was the first in the industry. Since it had to break the ice, it could not be perfect the first time. So MTG was good in 1995. Now, thechnology and design has evolved and wizards of the coast has even corrected their own bugs in their new card games (ex: Duel Masters corrected the land/mana bug and the lack of cards bugs ) but they never modified their MTG game to upgrade their game because of financial issues(too risky). Same thing as monopoly, you will never see monopoly 2 on the shelves of your store. So in both case, the company takes a conservative approach. Sorry but I will play a better evolved game.

---------------------------------------------

Another thing I have realized about magic is that it is the same thing as poker with a custom deck. The only strategy in this game is the deck building. Every thing else is the luck of the draw. Give different players the same hand of cards and they will almost play it the same way. So your card draw dictate your decisions.

In duel masters, it was different because each card had 2 functions. So the cards a player would be willing to sacrifice could be different from a player to another.

RATING: 9
The experience of play, research, and deck-building merits a 10.  There's never been a more customizable or brilliantly malleable game.  The game's "fatal flaw" -- its collectability and high cost -- is also the reason that WotC put out so many thousands of cards and kept the game alive with innovative ideas.  

I'll never buy a Magic card again, but it is now possible to play the game with full artwork and with every card at MTGPlay.com.  The evenings I've spent with that program this year alone convinced me that M:TG is one of the all-time great games.

If Magic weren't a CCG, and were instead released in complete, affordable sets for each expansion, it'd be my vote for Best Game Ever.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
As a wargamer, I have a love-hate relationship with Magic.  I love it can be played out in as short as 15 minutes or over 30.  Thus I play it daily (via online). It is a flexible game and in theory you have as many different games as you can if you can make up decks with all the different cards in five colors, with all kinds of possible combinations.  You aim to decrease your opponent life from 20 down to 0, the first one doing so wins the game.  Simple victory condition......  I hate it because it is still, bascially, a money game.  He who has the money has the power to build an invincible army or magic play.  Thus, different types of tournaments rules are set up to ban certain too "powerful" cards, an indication that the game has inherent "holes" that the game system can't contain people using cards that can sure win a game, if not totally in an abusive way. Play balance is therefore an issue in this game.  Besides, the rules for Magic the Gathering has been, at best, un-ambiguous for the first time reading.  You almost question everytime how to play new cards with vague description of special abilities, the timing of playing them, the "right way" of playing them etc.  Nonetheless, the PC online game version can serve as an instant referee to the above questions.  It also lets you to play faster and learn the game much more easily.  It is an open gaming system, combining creativity, logic, mathematics and all that. As a game, it is not bad.  As a meaningful of any sort, better look elsewhere.      
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 10
