http://www.cubetutor.com/viewcube/634
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
Based on Garruk vs Liliana, and Jace vs Chandra.

Lots of small rule points ("Madness"), that are not answered in the Basic Rulebook.
The Comprehensive Rules are a great reference that quite clearly describes the rules, and answered many of my questions.  But they're dry.

Mostly tactical, without much strategy, at least in the first few introductory games.  Feels like Blue Moon on this account, until now.

However, the flavor/theme, and the variety of abilities makes it a much more interesting game, for me (until I realize that Blue Moon is actually much more strategic and difficult than I think—I should try the Blue Moon AI…).

The game is full of theme: it is easy to imagine the players casting spells, and the creatures fighting with them or each other.  The various abilities and spells are quite easy to imagine graphically.  The whole game could be made into a movie that would related the whole fight (ala Yu-Gi-Oh).

Plus, their is a large panel of available abilities and effects.  This even makes this game much richer in flavor than a game like Space Hulk, which drips with theme.

Having too little or too much mana is not so uncommon, even with pre-constructed decks such as the Duel Decks.  It can really make you feel helpless (I never feel that way in other card games such as Race for the Galaxy, Jambo, or even Blue Moon).  This is mitigated by the fact that limiting the damage requires some clever play, which can be challenging, and also by the fact that games do not last long: it's easy to play another game if the previous one was unsatisfactory.  However, some games are so dependent on luck that it's important to be ready to not be frustrated, and to play an additional game to balance luck out.

More generally: limited possibilities: few cards from your hand can really be played: choices are quite limited.  Only slightly more complex than Dominion, in term of choice.  Much easier than Race for the Galaxy; easier than Jambo.

However, the number of relatively original tactical possibilities during a single game is very good.  Reminds me of Court of the Medici, with more flavor and richness.  Race for the Galaxy offers more choices, but they are more strategic, less opportunistic.

No setup time!  Better than Race or Jambo (small setup time).

The Cube.  I love building a deck.  I get the same feelings as when setting up troops in CoH:AtB (Conflict of Heroes), or Lotr:TMG (minis): you invent strategies, think about what your opponent might do, try to get ready for all the likely possibilities, etc.  A lot of delightful thinking goes into this phase, and I love it.

Love most of the artwork.

The cards have enough character by themselves that what they depict acquires some kind of reality; cards can be recognized, which can bring nice memories ("this Incinerate saved my life, the other day").
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
De cartas, el mejor.

RATING: 10
Simply the best CCG around.  Huge variety of cards to choose from to play with.  Overall good balance to card power in most recent sets.  Formats for play (e.g., standard, modern, vintage, commander, planechase, archenemy, draft, sealed, constructed, cube...and dozens of other 2-player and multiplayer variants) fit a variety of play styles.  Main downside is the cost for best cards, in relation to that, competitive decks for some formats.

RATING: 10

Pound for pound, dollar for dollar, I've probably had more fun with this than with any other game I've ever played. RATING: 7
A great game, I think of it as the perfect game for me, it fullfills all my strategic, theme, interaction, tactical, cravings. The collectible thing made it mostly unplayable for me, I was a tournament player (in the way of getting succesful...), then I realized the game just doesn't worth all my time and money. It [b]IS[/b] a great game, I played it everytime I could... I hardly missed any serious tournament until it became evident that the game is all about buying more and more cards. My favorite season was Extended.

I've started to play Casual games with my friends. If a different rating appears here (other than 7) it's because of the causal games, not the tournament "serious" game...

EDIT: I really got into the whole EDH/Commander thing since I am a really vintage MTG gamer. I LOVE to play more Casual games now, I play Cube Draft, Normal non-competitive draft and a LOT of 4 player Commander.

RATING: N/A
I should really like this game, but something seems missing. The problem for me is that that dueling is secondary to the real "game" -- deck-building. The dueling part is dictated by the cards in your deck and the luck of the draw. I see very little skill here. Instead the skill is in designing the deck to minimize the luck of the draw and to maximize damage to your opponent. Unfortunately I would rather spend my time playing (dueling) instead of preparing to play (deck-building).

RATING: 6
This was once cardboard crack for me, but eventually fell out of it. Standard is hit or miss, my favorite modern decks aren't always relevant, and I simply don't have the time to dive deep into it like I used to.

Also, the game design just feels old. Lands are a bad mechanic, and when you're playing for prize it feels bad to lose to an unbeatable draw or lose because you had to mulligan multiple times. I feel like the cards are fun, but the core game is aging. 

But without Magic I would probably not have been exposed to the wonderful world of modern board games.

RATING: 10
Comments entered on 10 Dec 2009.

I started playing Magic: The Gathering in 1999. Since that time I have acquired at least one of every theme deck from every release. I have also acquired almost every special release of casual preconstructed decks (including Battle Royale, Beatdown, and the various "versus" decks). For about six years from 2000-2005, I played in competitive tournaments and also became a judge in 2005.

I thoroughly enjoy Magic because the almost unlimited variability in decks. The game has some very basic rules that are fairly easy to grasp and teach. The massive amount of rules and keywords over the years, however make the game become one of the most complicated to play. The complication is derived from all the multitudes of card interactions and not necessarily from a complicated rules set.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 9.5
[microbadge=14][microbadge=670]

[size=18][b]Best of 1993[/b][/size]

My opinions of this game have gone up and down throughout the years.  Currently, I think it's more up than down. The multitude of formats allow a surprising variety of both gameplay and strategy for what is basically a simple rule set errata-ed by each individual card.  EDH alone I think revitalized the very possibilities of the game.

Favorite block: Innistrad
Favorite color: Black


EDH Decks:

Thassa, God of the Sea -- Blue Control / Combo
Raksha Golden Cub -- White Cat Tribal / Equipment
Karrthus, Tyrant of Jund -- Black/Green/Red Dragon Tribal
Ob Nixilis, the Fallen -- Black Landfall Midrange

Cubes for drafting:

Innistrad 4/2/1/1 set
Rise of the Eldrazi 4/2/1/1 set
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
High-Quality entertainment back in the early days of Magic:TG.  Every time a new expansion came out, something new was introduced to the game, usually for the good.  At least, for a few years.

After a while, the older magic cards went out of date and became useless compared to newer, more powerful, and less differentiated cards that were guaranteed to kick your rear.  Tournaments went from being fun honest contests to sales pitches.  The game was already a huge money-sink without making unique cards that you had to buy to remain competitive.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

I don't play any more, but I still follow it online. Quite possibly the best, most expensive game ever made. Glad to see it is still thriving after all these years.

RATING: 6.6
Type: 2 player competitive card-based game (I only have some pre-set decks and do not participate in the CCG portion of this game.)

Best with: 2
Weight: Medium/Heavy
Duration: 15-45 minutes
Notes:
extensive card-reading
head-to-head competitive
strategy gets better with card familiarity after 4-5 games with a deck
my decks may not be balanced, and is not quite the same sort of game as the full CCG customized decks

My collection only includes a few prescribed decks bought as head-to-head packs, and does not include the option to cutomize those decks.

Similar games in my collection: Android: Netrunner (competitive deck customization), Star Wars LCG (competitive deck customization), Blue Moon Legends (competitive deck customization)

RATING: 8
The best CCG ever made. Made me broke on several occasion, hence why I quit and gave away my decades long hobby and collection.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
Before playing any Euros, my wife and I picked up some 7th edition starter packs in 2003 and learned to play.  Since that time, I've played quite a few Euro-style 2 player games.  I've recently begun playing again and taught it to a coworker.  Without a doubt MTG holds up to any of the other 2 player card games I've played.  Magic has it all:  tactical play, take that! style plays, slowly building up a power base, agony over losing a creature that you'd become attached to, surprise finishes.  

Don't listen to the bitching and bellyaching about the collectability.  Grab some cheap core set cards or starter packs, share them with your favorite gaming partner, draft a couple of decks and have fun. You can play this game at any level you wish.  For a little bit of money, you get a LOT of replayability and a LOT of bang for your gaming buck.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 1
The only reason to rate this game  highly is if your name is Richard Garfield. Everyone else should rate it a 1 and ask themselves "What happened to all my friends, time and money since I started playing Magic?" 

MAGIC IS NOT A GAME!!! It is a brilliant marketing strategy. It is atrocious from a gameplayer's point of view. Your 'skill' in this 'game' is too heavily dependent on how much money you have spent. Want to play better? Drop another couple of hundred bucks. You'll beat all your friends until they go out and waste money, too.

I understand that it kept many game stores from going under. I understand that it exposed new people to gaming in general. I don't care. It's terrible what people do to themselves and the people around them whem all they care about is Magic. Allusions to this being crack in game form are completely valid.

RATING: 8
Solid rules that have been revised over and over, with all ambiguity hammered out. Game length is variable, from 5 minutes to 30min depending on your (and the opponent's) playstyle. Major flaw is that your opponent's wealth and tendency to buy cards (either single, or lots of boosters) will also determine to some extension his strenght. Friends and/or sealed deck games are your best bet (and also the most fun).

RATING: 6
My 1st CCG (And I assume it is everyones. )  I think I started playing when Legends came out and quit some time after fallen empires.  Still have a massive collection sitting in my closet.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
This is an old game but it is one of the best card games out there.  There is a reason that it sells as well as it does.  I suspect that the only game that ever has sold as well is Monopoly.  I have played this with my daughter since she was 9.  We don't play it nearly enough.  It is a medium weight card game with some fiddly rules, but the basic mechanics are great.  You play with your pre-made or drafted deck by putting out lands, summoning monsters, using sorceries and instants to defeat the other planes walker. First player to defeat the opponent by knocking out his or her 20 life wins.  
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
I was addicted when I was younger :-)
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
If you haven't heard of Magic the Gathering I'd be surprised.
Its a great game and with a few House rules can be one of the best games around.
The problem with MTG - New cards are released periodically which are usually more powerful in some way.
The tournament play also only accepts the current cards and forces you to purchase new cards if your wish to continue playing in the tournaments. Casual play suffers no such restrictions.

Oh, other big problem... Mana. your power/resources are dependent upon card drawing, and if you don't draw the required Land cards... you can become "Mana Screwed" and often will lose as a result.

Of course the awesome game play and card interactions are second to none, the amazing complexity that deters many newcomers is what truly keeps bringing back the hardcore fans. When the Rule book is written like a several hundred page legal document you know the game is complex.
I go off magic for awhile but I always come back more passionate than ever after realising just how wonderful this game truly is.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7.5
Great game! Lots of cards, awesome artwork, fun mechanics, length, re-playable, customization, strategy. It is true though that it is expensive and imbalanced most of the time.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
This is a great game. The rules over the years started from messed up to eventually become very defined and are now pretty solid. The pace is fine, the strategy and depth is enticing and the overall game is pretty fun. There are two flaws though, one is that players who spend more money will always pwn you and the other is certain cards allow for nightmarish combos. If you can avoid those experiences this is a good game though beware of tournaments are they will change you when you realize the whole new level of the game.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
I initially avoided this when beta was selling retail because I was put off by the marketing scheme.  Then I received a deck or two (beta) for free to try out.  Immediately was bitten by the MtG bug and liked this game a lot for the first few years.  Played in quite a few tournaments and leagues.  The trading and comraderie was fun.  It peaked for me during the Tempest/Visions/Weatherlight series and I stopped playing pretty much after the Urza's set.  Still would play sealed environment, but never really got into constructed decks too much.  This is difficult for me to rate as it was clearly a '9' or '10' when I was playing tournaments, but now might be a '4', since I'm unlikely to play again, except upon rare occasion.

RATING: 6
My first introduction to a physical game deeper than Risk.  Absolutely adored the theme (yes, I read some of the earlier books), the simple mechanics, and the combo-licious gameplay.  The game has changed so much from those early days, though, and I have not been able to get back into it.  I suppose I just have too many memories of the earlier, simpler sets and cards.  FFG's LCGs, Summoner Wars, and Mage Wars provide the same type of mental stimulation without the massive spending requirements and the feelings of lost nostalgia.

Would happily play (with my old cards and ruleset) again.  Not likely to pick up in any form in the future.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Rating is for a draft tournament (or similar egalitarian style of play). I would not play this if it required me to spend loads of cash buying rare cards to be competetive.

Magic continues to be the only truly worthwhile CCG, although playing it in the collectable format can be hazardous to your wallet. On the other hand, playing some form of draft variant where all players have equal chance to build a deck can make for a great evening of entertainment.

Card art is one of the strong points of M:tG, as is the ability of the game to constantly re-invent itself with new mechanics. A word of warning though: if playing a draft, stick to a core set (with possible a single booster cycle), and read up on the rules. Too many different mechanics could see this game quickly deteriorate into madness.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
I admit that I was a Magic addict at some point in live. But well it has all to please: Infinite number of combinations and good possibilities for strategical planning in deck building. Relatively short games with lots of tension and sudden reversals. I preferred the various multiplayer variants, since in those "cardmonger"-decks have less impact. I still play occasionally, but I haven't been following the sets anymore.

RATING: 8
[Played more than 100 times]

So many options (...its best feature!).

It may be played at various "levels" (casual play, local tourneaments, big tourneaments, etc.).

Fast paced (usually).

It has A LOT of rules, so it's atrocious to introduce to new players.

Due to its nature, the quality of the sets may vary wildly (some years it's a great game, some others it really isn't).

I strongly dislike the marketing policy of WotC to get always more money from it, but the game itself is a good.

RATING: 7

RATING: 1
How do I hate thee?  Let me count the ways.  I thought I had rid my game room of this nightmare, but then discovered a dust-covered box way back on a shelf.  Just the sight of those cards brought back bad memories and all the reasons my group quit playing it.  Tell you more?  Sure!  Every game became an argument when people interpreted cards differently.  Or how about, "My instant interrupts the instant you played on my interrupt that interrupted your interrupt on my instant."  AAAARGH!  Now add in the "too much way too fast" syndrome that only power buyers and little rich snots could keep up with, and you know why I utterly despise this game.  I only rated it as high as I did because it got me back into gaming back in the Alpha days.  Those cards I found?  I'm gonna burn 'em.  Then I'll sprinkle the ashes with holy water, dig a deep hole, pour gasoline on them and try to burn them some more.  Then I'll fill in the hole and tap dance on it.  Maybe that'll make me feel better about all those wasted hours I spent playing it.

RATING: N/A
020308, 4 plays:
I've been playing this for ten years now. I don't consider this that good, however, and I've tried for years to find a variant that would make this more fun.
290308, 6 plays:
Today I, Jani and Tommi played 'kill left', a variant in which you win when the player to your left dies. It was more fun than our typical games. So I raised my rating from 5 to 6.
270508, 17 plays:
When played with a rule borrowed from *gasp* Duel Masters, this game rises to at least a 7! It's a variant in which you don't have to put lands to your deck, you can play basic lands by removing cards of the required color from your hand.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9.5
Magic the Gathering can be played in many different ways; casual, tournament, commander, cube etc. 
My rating pertains to the Cube format specifically as I dislike the idea of tournament play where you have to 
constantly buy new cards for the current format and in a year those cards are no longer legal.
I also don't like the booster pack marketing model in any game. 

Cube however, is amazing. It scratches so many itches for me all in one experience. 
1.Drafting a deck 
2.Building, maintaining and updating the card pool from which those decks are drafted.
3.Creating the best deck with the cards you drafted. 
4.Dueling an opponent who has done the same as you and seeing how your two decks
 line up against each other in a highly strategic and deep game of Magic.

This is hardly a board game but I justify it because it's a contained experience I choose to pull
off my shelf and put back just like any board game. 
It's not comparable to most peoples list because it's such a niche experience that takes a large
time and money investment. 
However, if you enjoy playing Magic, drafting and deck construction but don't want to worry about 
buying packs or cards becoming irrelevant, this is an awesome way to play.

RATING: 9

The only reason for the 9 is that some of the later releases significantly watered down the game. In my opinion the game was perfect through LEGENDS and is arguably a 6 or 7 with all the expansions in consideration.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
There are two interesting aspects of this game: playing the game itself and building a deck.

When playing, there are lots of tactical and strategical choices to be made. Can I attack? How will I block an attack efficiently? Shall I play this 'instant' now? Shall I bring this creature on, or maybe wait until my opponent lost his fire potential? Shall I take damage or prevent it for now?

Deckbuilding is the other virtue of this game. After all these years, I can still enjoy spending many hours building a well-balanced deck and then see it perform against a number of others that are built according to the same set of rules.

This game, or actually the game scene, has its downside too. Some people spend way too much money on it. And new editions keep spilling into the market. I've stopped buying years ago. (edit: I've started buying again...)

Still, this game is outstanding. I always want to play and I expect this will never change... 
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 4
Let's be honest: This game is only popular because it was the first CCG and it relied on predatory business practices with continuous expansions.

It is understandable why this game worked in 1993.  Besides being the first game of its type, the mechanics of the game were far more interesting and playtested than many other of the tabletop games out there released during that erra.

However, nearly 25 years later, I can say that this game is simply not that good compared to what's out there.

Resources to summon your creatures or cast spells require luck of the draw, which is an already a red flag for a poorly designed game.  Games like WoW CCG or Hearthstone fixed this problem.

In regards to balance, because Magic the Gathering is reliant on expansions that continue on forever, expect some cards to be either outdated and outclassed due to constant power creeps.  Some cards are simply inferior to others.  This especially true for land cards, with some of them allowing two different colors instead of one.  It's a pay 2 win scheme with some of the worst tournament payouts compared to eSports games.

Magic the Gathering is an interesting relic but it is not a good game.  Many games like Netrunner, Hearthstone, and Codex have been proven to work on the foundations of Magic and improved on it greatly with far less expenses involved.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
The greatest card game there is.  But bloody expensive to keep up to date with and that proves to be it's greatest weakness; the sheer amount of card releases means players never really explore the depth of the game cards before a new set are out.  Best way to play this would be to buy the main expansion on the year you start and never buy any other cards.  Ever!
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
Been playing since 1983 -- Alpha release. Probably still my favorite game. But I have to say that I do not care very much for the full-bore "constructed" environments. I much prefer the limited environments. My friends and I play with randomly selected PreCon decks (the theme decks from WotC - over 60 different decks to date). This is an excellent way to play. Also enjoy playing in tightly constrained environments (example: 2 starters, 2 boosters from each of the 3 expansions of that block). Awesome game!

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 5
I rate CCGs and their expandable cousins (LCGs, etc.) on this basis: "I will likely never invest in one again, but assuming that someone else hands me a deck here's what I think of the game."

I stopped playing M:TG years ago; if I still played, it'd likely be a 9. It's a beautiful thing from a design standpoint, and I absolutely loved deck construction and the tension of competitive play (especially in a tournament environment), but the expansion grind and the time and money commitment involved to stay competitive was just insane.

I still remember individual turns from tournament games I played back in the late '90s -- especially the ones where I had a really good deck, understood the metagame of the moment, and could play like hell. If I had a zillion dollars, could count on a local community of competitive players, and had the time to keep up with the game, I'd start playing Magic again in a heartbeat.

That's not going to happen, so sadly this remains a 5. If you handed me a deck, I'd consider playing.

RATING: 9.5
Played it since I was 12. I've made tons of friends on this game, so it means a lot to me. You can always find people who play it. The game might seem intimidating at first, but with the right introduction (a good friend or Duels of the Planeswalkers) you get into it right away. The game is all about the community, so if you find the right play group, you will get sucked right in. I'm a casual player myself, so I try and make the community as accessible as possible where I live. And it doesn't have to be expensive. I only spend roughly 100$ on it annually.

RATING: 7
4 / 5 - Great.

Fun game, hateful economics. I really can't seperate them. However, the best way to play MtG is to do so without spending a ton of money. Luckily there's lots of ways to do this: play with like minded people, simulate a "sealed deck" environment with a stack of cards, proxy expensive cards. The tournament-style game is worthless IMO, how can it be right when your ability to compete is based more on your wallet than your skill? The more I've played this over the years the more I've come to realise that creative strategy, such as it is, is all about deck building and little to do with play - I'm not sure I like that.

RATING: 9.2

To add to it, there are many different viable strategies in the game and the ability for a player to construct his or her own deck before playing only adds to the distinctive individual flavor that every game has.

Cost of entry is a little high for this game but is definitely worth it for any aspiring gamer.

NEGATIVES: the game is showing its age a little bit in the extremely large ruleset and the restrictive resource mechanics. The random contents if boosterpacks makes this game expensive if you are a collector like me.

The downside is that it is very expensive to play, and is not very approachable to new players.  It can't handle more than 2 players.  Sometimes mana management is annoying.  For those who like the deckbuilding aspect and have money to spare, MtG is the king of this genre.

You have to give to the inventor that it is a GOOD game.

RATING: 9

RATING: 9
This is my favourite Trading Card Game.  Trading, Deck-Building, Opening Packs, Drafting, Cube, Multiplayer, Flavour-text...  I love all aspects, except for the time consuming nature, and having to know so many cards!  Understanding the rules in a deep enough fashion to give you an advantage is also time consuming, and requires a lot of play with experienced players.  It is a game I've been able to pick up and teach people, the basics, and then they continue to learn themselves.  I started a small club of about 30 people in highschool, 2 of members went Pro!  Lots of great memories with this.  The artwork is terrific, and the game balance shifts with every release, always keeping people on their toes.

Sadly to be an active and competitive magic player is quite expensive and requires commitment, so I decided to sell my remaining cards.

RATING: 10
Unbelievable money went into this game... and let's not forget about the time I have spent... ummm... ???

Honestly, I think I am addicted to the smell of the cards... they must use some sort of top secret ink which subconciously permeates my brain and forces me to stay addicted.

In terms of raw hours contemplating and playing games this is the second one I have spent the most time on.  The only thing that has held my interest for longer has been D&D/WFRP.  Warhammer Fantasy Battle would be third.

I recently started playing with my ten year old.  After twenty years, the thrill of opening a new deck is still there for me.
 
And if you have never tried this gem go down to your local hobby store and find someone to teach you.  The game itself is an absolute masterpiece.  Without a doubt it is my favorite of all time.

Notable cards which were in my collection: Ancestral Recall, Mox Pearl, Mox Emerald, Mox Sapphire, Time Walk, Time Twister, Time Vault, 4 Mana Drains, Library of Alexandria, 6 Force of Wills, Mishra's Workshop, Tabernacle at Pendrall Vale... 

But now it is just nostalgia mostly.

RATING: 7.5
If only money and distance were not a concern. Probably the best game ever made and fully deserves a 10. I have played this more than every other game I have played combined, by total time played, and games played.  However, those I used to play with are in other states and while I could find new groups the other thing stopping me is the amount of money it takes to keep current with the game.
Every gamer owes a debt of gratitude to Magic as it is the life blood of 99% of gaming stores today thanks to Amazon. Without Magic most FLGS would be no more.
This doesn't get a 10 for me anymore as I don't have the desire to spend so much on one game. I also like the board gaming community a lot better than the Magic community.  For me Magic was a great game for me in my teens and I will always remember it fondly.

RATING: 3
This game is among the hardest to rate. I loved Magic as a kid, until I grew up and realized it was a contest of corporate consumerism. Now I hate it and resent the people who support it. Ugh.

Magic sold based on a bait-and-switch scheme: a $500+ per year game dressed up as an $11 game. Moreover, Wizards of the Coast clearly cares more about making money than about running a decent game, which breeds disrespect so deep that cheating is rampant in the tournament scene. Garfield made a great game, but Wizards f*cked it up. 
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
This is a bit hard to comment on. For me, it has been a very important game, it was "The" game for so many years growing up - culminating with me qualifying and playing (and losing badly) in the Nationals in 2011.

But after that well... I've played a bit with my friends, who never really tried to keep up with the pro scene or draft, but who just played "kitchen table" magic and had a blast with that. Also, I force my Commander (EDH) decks on them occasionally and that's sort of fun. However, I find that I'd rather play other games, for every occassion. I'm too far removed from kitchen table magic, I spent to much time reading strategy articles, watching videos, keeping up with every new set and discussion. It was a hobby all of its own and now I don't bother with it but I can't really go back to a "lower" level either - so it's stuck, and that's ok.

As a game, it's cool, a bit unwieldy in the rules department, a nightmare to teach and even moreso to play well. If you're thinking about trying it out, I'm not sure I'd recommend it, I feel it's a game that just "happens" and if it doesn't then you probably aren't a good fit for it. I doubt that makes sense to people but that's my take on it.

A good game!
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

Magic: The Gathering was my gateway to the world of board games. I loved MtG and played it all the time, but quit when I discovered Dominion and other modern European board games. After getting into board games, I couldn't justify spending so much time, money, and energy on constructing MtG decks. However, after purchasing some duel decks to play with casually, I've gotten back into it in its casual format. I like casual. It's fun. It reminded me that Magic is good. :) Who knows!? Maybe I'll even start constructing decks again? :P

If I ever had to choose just one table top game I could play for the rest of my life Magic would be the easy choice.

RATING: 7.5
I love this game actually. I've played it more on-line than in person, but am constantly impressed by how games play out. I've had duels that I thought about for days afterwards, exciting back and forth matches that came down to skill and some good guesswork. I wish I had invented it! I purchased 1500 cards on-line for $25, got another 3000 from a BGG member who was extremely generous, and those should give me enough enjoyment to play with my kids when they get old enough. My rating loses points for the CCG aspect. It costs too darn much. I'll never be purchasing cards one at a time.

RATING: 9
rating is based SOLELY on cube draft / winston draft / 8 player sealed draft / sealed league formats.  i do not think i have much interest in playing any other way.  my cube is in the final stages of being assembled / acquired and i think this will be a great way to play going forward (it can also be used for winston drafts).

*****

I really enjoy cube drafting and have enjoyed putting together a starting cube.  Looking forward to trying it out many more times and then tweaking it here and there.  This is a really great way to play magic without getting caught up in the 'suitcase of cards' and just enjoy the phenomenal aspects of deck construction/hand management/actual play.

*****

Cube drafting / Winston drafting is just a fantastic format and a really well done game.  Dominion/Thunderstone/other clones, while entertaining in their own right, are inferior to Magic.  

Magic does what they do even better.  

Again, this rating and my desire for play is only for the limited format... I have zero interest in playing Magic on any other front.

*****

I have a great common/uncommon cube and think I am going to work on assembling a Ravanica 2-1-1 cube.

RATING: 7.5
I guess I have a strange perspective having played Pokemon first... so there's five types of energy in Pokemon, and five types of land in Magic, huh? who knew. So, it's far from obvious to me what the significant differences in gameplay are. It feels like having to attach energy to cards makes for more tough decisions. Maybe Magic is less swingy because it doesn't have so many cards allowing you to search through your deck and such... or maybe it isn't. And, it's not really the differences in gameplay that matter, is it? It's the deckbuilding. So I'll get back to you in a couple years...

RATING: 10
My only rated game without any recent plays... but I'm looking back to years and years of fond memories (both casual and competitive). The distribution model sucks, but the game is awesome.

Update: Finally played this again. Yay! My wife seems to like it quite a bit.

A word of advice: From my experience, if you are teaching new players then please use real decks, not bad crap decks. Sure, an overly complicated tournament combo/control deck might be too much. However, a solid beatdown deck (even tournament level) gives much more play satisfaction than using whatever cards you found behind the shelf...

RATING: 2
This game is a money-magnet, and provides very little joy as compared to the amount of money you have to put into it. The game mechanics are simplistic and random. Rules are short, but patches for loopholes can span hundreds of pages. 

While there are other games which also appeal to the addictive and collecting mentality, this one gives very little in return. There is an entire secondary market for the MTG cards where they can be traded for ridiculous amounts of money (REAL money) - you could buy an entire boardgame for the amount of money for which you can get a single stupid piece of paper with a picture and some text on it. 

I'm glad I saw the real face of this hobby in time and dodged this bullet...

RATING: 5.75
[played 50+ times]

A good game, with intriguing mechanichs. 
Like checks, you have to study and try to be a good player (and know how build a good deck). Unlike checks it's an expensive game: buying cards for a good deck can be expensive. 
Like other collectible games, who has a deck with more powerful cards and have much time to spend in building an testing his deck, is more likely to win. 
I play for fun, so I don't want spend too much time in testing magic's deck... I think there's other interesting things in life worth my time :-)
Anyway, I like playing once in a while

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 1
I was introduced to this game in highschool in the 90s by a friend.  I thought it was alright, but nothing I'd want to play regularly.  THEN he told me that the game could get more interesting if you go buy more cards to make better decks.  He didn't get it at first, but right away I saw the "he who spends the most money wins" greed of this game and I pretty much refused to play it after that.

Then I went off to college and met people in college who played it on Friday nights.  I always declined.  Inevitably, every game they played was a yelling match over who's card did what and how people interpretted the cards.  Sometimes I'd watch them play for my own amusement and I found just about every player interpretted cards differently each and every game depending on how it benefitted them.

Needless to say, this game is horrible.  Games are meant to be played to have fun and give everyone a somewhat fair shot.  Not be left open to miscellaneous interpretation and he who spends the most wins the most.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 4
A colossal money-drain that was initially dominated by gamers, enthusiasts, hobbyists and collectors. It quickly devolved into a land-grab of rules lawyers, fanboys and min-maxers not unlike a big group of pre-teens playing D&D. It still has a great mechanic, cool cards and artwork, wonderful collectibility and a pretty long shelf life, but the financial committment is just too steep.

RATING: 7
Don't make eye contact with it- it will suck you in! I played MTG for about ten years (from Unlimited through the Urza's cycle, relapsing briefly for Ravnica/Time Spiral) and had some small tournament success. Mostly, though, it was me and some friends spending the evening together, playing a casual game or banging out deck ideas. Lots of great memories here, but enough to outweigh the money and time spent or the compulsive behavior this model encourages? Maybe not. But for at least 8 of those 10 years this was what I did, and I loved it.

RATING: 8
What can you say about Magic? It's the greatest collectible card game (CCG) to have ever existed.

It is an expensive CCG, though. Wizards of the Coast are awesome at releasing regular updates for the game, but it can be overwhelming to get into. If you're interested, consider buying some of the pre-made decks to get a feel for the game. Or, but a few fat packs and spend an afternoon drafting cards with some friends. In any case, you're bound to have a good time.

RATING: 8
A great game; endlessly fun, easy to learn but hard to master.  Constant evolution of the game keeps it feeling fresh and interesting, but if you want to play with all the newest cards you will be spending a lot of money in the process.  Even with this caveat, this is very enjoyable game and if you are not competitive (and can resist amassing too many cards -- just tweaking one or two decks with the new sets) can actually be fairly inexpensive.

Very well done card art and elegant gameplay, although the rules have become so complex that WOTC began printing specific rules instructions for special abilities right on the cards.  Technically only meant for two players, multiplayer rules are easy to come by.

RATING: 10
I no longer play, but it will always hold a special place for me. I was a big MtG junkie for many many years, but friends move away and times change. The bulk of my collection has since been sold off. Recently I've been able to trade many of my old cards online to build my board game collection. I still have plenty of cards to build decks with if I ever wanted to play again.

I've waffled on the rating for this one. It's not something I play anymore and don't want to play all the time, so by the BGG definition it's probably a 6. However, I LOVED this game for years and have so many fond memories from it, I think I have to give it a 10, a sort of lifetime achievement award. That feels right.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
While there's a certain part of me that resists rating Magic a 10, at this point I can't deny its draw for me and feel compelled to give it my second-ever perfect score. My resistance comes down to the matches of Magic themselves, which in the narrowest sense is all Magic is as a "game." These matches can often be rather anticlimactic, feeling like they're over before they've even begun: one deck is clearly better than the other overall, the deck are evenly matched but it's a good matchup for one deck over the other (i.e., Aggro > Control > Midrange > Aggro), one player gets mana screwed/flooded, and so on. (I'm sure it's even worse in constructed formats, where more expensive decks will of course tend to do better, but thus far I have strictly played limited formats.) But once you've gotten a critical mass of games under your belt, these matches start to merge into one another. Yeah, you drew too many lands and lost the first match, but your managed to win the other two, so overall you're left feeling a bit more control. You can take what you learned from one best-of-three match and apply it to the next one, what you learned from one draft and apply to the next, from one format to another, and so on and so forth. There's a fluidity between discreet matches that lends to the game being greater than the sum of its parts.

This fluidity comes in part from the deckbuilding aspect of the game, which takes on many forms, depending upon the format you play. For limited players, it's about drafting and building a new deck every time you engage in a session of Magic. For constructed players, it's about building a deck ahead of time that can stand on its own in most matches while also successfully navigating a shifting metagame. For cube designers--which I consider a sort of "meta-deckbuilding"--it's about composing a "deck" from which others can draft their own decks and compete against each other in interesting and varied games of Magic. For whatever reason, I seem to have zoomed out yet another level, coming up with [url=http://games.mulrah.com/Magic%20the%20Gathering/]a series of cube design projects[/url] by which players can draft decks from various planes through out Magic's history. Of course, the more one zooms out, the less this "game" seems like an actual game, and the more it's a process of game design or--less romantically--perhaps simply collecting. It's at this level I seem to be entranced with Magic, having put in hours upon hours of design/collecting, backed nearly 500 actual matches of Magic. Despite this absurd amount of time already devoted to this game, I can honestly say I'm as happy to play it now as I was when I first tried it out, and that is [i]really[/i] saying something. A 10 it is!
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 3
[b]Ice Age[/b]

I can't say I enjoy much of the art or annoying mechanics like Cumulative Upkeep, but it's still Magic. Based on a single draft, I don't think it's all that horrible and would be willing to give it another go someday. GR was able to put together a passable Aggro deck that exerted early pressure but unfortunately ran out of steam against a dominant BU Control deck. So yeah, the standard strategies in Magic exist here, and the decks felt more functional than the stuff you'd get from a pile of crap cards (Believe me, I know).
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
[b]Core Cube[/b]

Using Magic 2014 as the foundation, but heavily edited to push it close to [url=https://www.boardgamegeek.com/thread/694888/core-set-cube]delirimouse's Core Cube[/url]. My initial play of this, when it was mostly Magic 2014 and lacking Rares, was decidedly underwhelming. But I rebuilt it around some clear themes, threw in some Rares, and retried it to great effect. Sure, it lacks the subtleties of some of Magic's finer sets, but at least you can make some solid, interesting decks that actually [i]do[/i] stuff. The singleton format add to the replayability of both the decks and the set as a whole. I highly recommend anyone interested in Magic, game design, and/or draft formats to give building a Core Cube a try.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
[b]Kamigawa[/b]

I originally had this as a rough simulation of Champions of Kamigawa, but I've since overhauled it to include the entire block. (Don't worry; the influence of Saviors is minimal.) The result is an interwoven web of possibilities, all hung together under a spectacular theme. They might not all be winners, but there are two to three [i]dozen[/i] decks in here. I consider a set "solid" if it has one for each of the ten color pairs, so this has the potential to be amazing. Even if some of these decks end up not being very strong, at least they're in there to try. This one's going to have a long lifespan in my collection.

Comments on Champions of Kamigawa Draft-Sim: I thought this was excellent. Unlike some drafts, where your deck builds itself from the cards you drafted, I felt like I could have built my deck a few different ways. Even the deck I ended up with had several interesting things going on. In other words, I would be willing to play that same deck again, rebuild from the same stack of cards I drafted, and draft the exact same color combination again. Multiply that times ten for every color pairing, and then some: that's your replayability for this set.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
[b]Mirrodin Cube[/b]
[i]Popular Planes Collection, Artifacts[/i]

Though many veteran players consider Mirrodin excellent for drafting, I didn't find it all that interesting. It seemed like you wanted to just play a fairly Aggro Creatures + Equipment strategy, and that was that. Kill Reviews in [url=blog.killgold.fish/2014/09/kill-reviews-mirrodin-block.html]wonders whether Artifacts theme can really work as the focus of a set[/url], as it seems to subdue too much of the color pie dynamic that makes Magic the game it is.

That said, Sealed Deck was an entirely different story for me. Without a draft, you can't default to a single strategy: sure you'll throw whatever Equipment you got into your deck, but you're forced to consider other strategies to make your card pool work. The preponderance of Artifacts adds to the flexibility and variety of options, making a number of decks viable with any given pool. This is a format I'd happily play again.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
[b]Theros Block Cube[/b]
[i]Distributed Planar Collection II (Brian)[/i]

I can see why some veterans found Theros bland. It's just solid down-the-middle Magic, not pushing the game too far in any one direction. In boardgamer parlance, it's almost like a "post-gateway" version of Magic, perfect after some starter decks or drafting a Core Set. The new mechanics are straightforward (though Bestow has caused a couple headaches), and the the flavor is through the roof, especially if you stick with the base set. The expansions add some more depth, opening up some "sideways" strategies that weren't all that prevalent in Theros alone. Invasion, which we played alongside Theros for a while, provided the perfect counterpoint: it was initially more mind-blowing, since we hadn't really drafted a multicolor set, and some of its old school tendencies proved tough to play around. But that wore off pretty quickly, whereas Theros has continued to deliver solid Magic every time I bring it to the table. We'll probably move on soon, but we definitely found the set entertaining and worthwhile.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
[b](Return to) Ravnica Cube[/b]
[i]Popular Planes Collection, Multicolor[/i]

My face-to-face plays with this set have been limited to homemade pre-constructed decks made mostly from Commons and Uncommons. The diversity in strategies between the guilds is excellent, but some guilds--at least the way I've built the decks--were definitely stronger than others. Add to this the rock-paper-scissors nature of Aggro-Midrange-Control, and it can feel like matches were determined before you played your first card. Ultimately, I think I got the balance at least as good as it is with Blue Moon Legends, which was my inspiration for taking the dive into Magic in the first place, but it's hard to feel like you ever got it "right" with such a customizable game.

I might go back to the pre-constructed decks, but for now I think I'm going to transition this set to a draft format, hopefully imbuing it with enough cards from the original set to recapture some of its legendary status as one of the greatest limited formats of all time. If that works, this rating could rise.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
[b]Rise of the Eldrazi[/b]
[i]Top Draft-Sim Collection, Top-Down Flavor[/i]

Wow, this was excellent, and it was just my hodge-podge adaptation of the set! This managed to mix positive aspects of several draft sets all into one. Like Theros, it's got great flavor: the Levelers give it a touch of the D&D feel, even if the "adventure world" theme from Zendikar is gone. Like Mirrodin, it feels different: those Eldrazi spawn provide a whole new aspect to the game that's fun to explore. Probably most importantly--like Champions of Kamigawa--there seem to be many ways to take your deck, though my first impression here is that it's not [i]quite[/i] as nuanced. As I was sifting through my drafted cards, several strategies emerged, so it felt like a more mindful draft could have taken the deck in a number of other directions. In addition, despite what I've read elsewhere, all the cards felt very playable. (Maybe the complaints aren't focused on the Commons and Uncommons that comprise the majority of the Limited environment.) So yeah, replayability seems through the roof, and I don't even have all the cards in here, having made a number of substitutions with cards from Magic 2014.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 2
[b]Leftovers Pauper Sphere[/b]

I definitely believe everything is relative in Magic: a weak card in one format can be a champ in another. I think that can expand to entire sets, so a properly designed set of weaker cards could be similar to a stronger set, just a couple turns slower. (You could probably just let everyone start with two lands in play, and it would be almost the same!) However, it is apparently possible to take it too far, and that's what happened here.

I took a bunch of Commons that got poor ratings on Gatherer and tried to make a "Crap Cube" ("[url=http://www.mtgsalvation.com/forums/the-game/the-cube-forum/cube-lists/192526-360-sphere-nofs-sphere]Sphere[/url]") out of them. I even tossed in some mediocre cards to serve as the set's "Rares" and tried to arrange things around various themes, but they were in some cases too horizontal (e.g., flyers in every color), so every color played the same. It seemed to draft okay, but the matches took forever, with decks just trading Creatures 1-for-1 until they had no more cards in hand, at which point you're just drawing a card every turn, hoping it can get a few points of damage in before it too is eliminated.

Anyway, I do think it's possible to create a set out of "crap" that works, but this wasn't it.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
[b]Onslaught[/b]

Onslaught reminds me of early games from prolific designers (specifically, I'm thinking of Martin Wallace). They possess many of the same features of their younger, more popular siblings, and they always have a contingent of rabid fans who claim so-and-so never managed to top this "underrated" early design. However, for most players, the more recent, more acclaimed games really are better.

In Onslaught's case, I've found my games to be hit-or-miss. A prolonged board stall (and reports of many more online), a couple games lost to mindless Creature overruns ("It's just Aggro."), and some weird tangential mini-games (Menacing Ogre) could individually be excused as the "character" of the set. But when taken together, they give the impression of a clunky design. Furthermore, I'm learning that I'm a player who appreciates synergy in his decks and the sets they come from, and in this regard Onslaught seems lacking. I did manage to pull off one mildly synergistic deck, but it felt more like a rickety Datsun pickup whose loosely fitting parts clicked together just barely enough to get it onto the highway. Oh, and it had a machine gun duct-taped to the top, which would be illegal today, but kicks ass when it's allowed.

As with all such designs, I'm sure there's an alternate reality in which I myself am one of the aforementioned rabid fans. But for now, I think it's basically a placeholder for Lorwyn, a [url=blog.killgold.fish/2014/11/kill-reviews-lorwyn-mini-block.html]reputedly more synergistic tribal set[/url].
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
[b][url=http://www.cubetutor.com/cubeblog/70317]Old School Cube[/url][/b]

This custom draft set includes only cards released prior to Weatherlight. Typically sets drawing from such a large card pool elicit a higher rating from me, because I feel like I'm able to work a lot of variety and intricacy into the set's design. While that's generally been the case with this set, I'm not as convinced it will actually play out this way. In addition, the archetypes here are pretty broad and generic (e.g., ramp, flyers, etc.) and in some cases either flimsy (enchantments) or "unfun" (land destruction). To make the set less about drafting a select few bombs and really force the exploration of the archetypes, I eschewed cube staples like Lightning Bolt and Swords to Plowshares, but that meant I really had to dig deep to get this just to 270 cards. Hopefully stuff like Caribou Range and Homarid Spawning Bed will at least get a chuckle from drafters, but I have limited expectations around those cards actually making it into decks.

That said, I am pretty pleased with how this turned out. The archetypes should vary depending on how you tackle them and offer a lot of flexibility since they're built across three colors. Some unique strategies and play styles you don't see anymore are built into this set, and I think it'll get its fair share of play with the right crowd. Unlike other Old School cubes that focus on recreating the deck brewing of the early days, this set asks the question, "How can overlooked old cards come together to create a draftable set?" Knights are a thing, and you can ping the board clear in Blue and White. Jokulhaups can drive unique enchantment strategies, and the tools for an old school Pestilence deck are in here too. At the same time, there are plenty of classics like Shivan Dragon, Savannah Lions, and so on in here, so the nostalgia should be flowing freely even in this low-powered environment.

Update: Actual play bears out my instincts. As with modern designs, most of the decks are fairly typical at their core, but have some kind of "spin" on them in accordance with the setting or theme. In this case, the spin tends to be old school. A recent successful Black-Red deck was unsurprisingly aggressive, but it also had a land destruction subtheme that kept the opponent at bay in an indirect way. The White-Blue deck of course had some flyers, but it kept opposing threats under control by constantly tapping them down or pinging them. Both of these spins on typical decks would probably be viewed as "unfun" by modern players, but I find them interesting variants worth exploring. I'm glad I put this together and hope to see it get some more plays.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
[b]Otaria Cube[/b]
[i]Popular Planes Collection, Tribal + Graveyard[/i]

This themed Cube combines the Odyssey and Onslaught blocks into a single set based in Otaria. I built it around archetypes for each color, color pair, and shard, and I kept the power level as flat as possible while still including many of the defining cards of the era. While that's all quite exciting from a functional deckbuilding standpoint, I must confess the flavor of this set is considerably lacking. Once I get into it more, maybe I'll be forgiving, but for now it's a barrier to wanting to engage with the set, so I'm docking it a point for theme.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
[b]Innistrad Draft-Sim[/b]
[i]Top Draft-Sim Collection, Tribal + Graveyard[/i]
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
[b]Khans of Tarkir Draft-Sim[/b]
[i]Top Draft-Sim Collection, Multicolor[/i]
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
[b]Dominaria (Invasion)[/b]
[i]Distributed Planar Collection I (Chris)[/i]

Having played [url=www.cubetutor.com/cubeblog/72249]my version of Invasion[/url] several times now, I feel better about drawing some conclusions about it. As the first multicolor set I drafted, I definitely appreciated the new challenge balancing your mana presents, but I suspect future multicolor sets will outshine this one. Grixis (UBR) seems to be the strongest color combination, since it has the best removal, and aggressive decks aren't very strong in this set. If other players aren't aware of this, then draft these colors and win. If other players are aware of this, then you're in for some tough, grindy games, where you eke out tiny advantages through careful combinations of the myriad activated abilities in this set (most of which require that mana balancing act I mentioned earlier). Kavu and Soldiers never really worked, but damn those Saprolings! Five-color decks are a thing, and there's probably something to be said for a self-bouncing ETB deck. But this seems like less variety than most modern sets, even if in play the decision-making is a little more gnarly. I'm happy to return to this set for the occasional challenge, but I look to others for the fun.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
[b][url=http://www.cubetutor.com/cubeblog/82138]Dragons of Tarkir Draft-Sim/Cube[/url][/b]
[i]Distributed Planar Collection III (Jeremy)[/i]

This set--based on the official Dragons of Tarkir limited format (DTK-DTK-FRF)--ended up being pretty solid. I pushed the Fate Reforged side of it and amped up the dragons, resulting in a bit more deck diversity than the original. In fact, our final session with this set saw two decks based on enemy colors (WB Warriors, RW Go Wide) go 2-1, while the allied decks went 1-2. The allied themes (e.g., Bolster in Green and White) play well as subthemes for the decks built around enemy colors. While there are some dominant cards, the set felt less top-heavy than, say, Invasion, despite Fate Reforged's reputation as a bomb-driven format.

Nonetheless, I was ready to move on from this set the instant we started playing it. The mechanical themes are either repetitive (e.g., +1/+1 counters in White and Green...again) or boring (e.g., caring about Power/Toughness), and there aren't any fun thematic (albeit crappy) cards like there were in Theros (e.g., Akroan Horse). In retrospect, this set might have been even better than Theros as an introductory set, but at this point I'm hoping for more interesting dynamics from these "expert" sets. This format wasn't bad, and I'd certainly play it again for some solid vanilla Magic, but there are many more interesting options out there.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
[b]Zendikar Cube[/b] (mostly Battle for Zendikar block)
[i]Distributed Planar Collection IV[/i]

I think I'm going to settle on a solid 7 for this set, which is based largely on the unpopular Battle for Zendikar. The design process was very interesting, as I tried to address the set's weaknesses by incorporating themes from Oath of the Gatewatch, original Zendikar, and Worldwake. I believe I was ultimately successful, which gives me an aura of pride when considering it, but ultimately all I managed to do was get this from being a weak set with few playable decks to hitting straight down the middle with about ten or so archetypes. That's about on par with Theros, which also settled in at a 7.

Design Impressions: In putting this set together, I had to learn all the inherent strategies to make sure I'm including them in the set in a balanced way. My experience echoed the opinions voiced on the Limited Resources podcast: this is a very complex set. Coming off Dragons of Tarkir, which was a cinch to put together, I am finding Battle for Zendikar satisfyingly challenging. I am cautiously hoping to upgrade green a bit, so it's not as nerfed at it was in the original, but just getting a baseline understanding of how the original ticked has been quite the puzzle. Despite the horrid reviews coming from some camps, I must say I am looking forward to playing this one!

Play Impressions: Having tried most of the color combinations in actual play, I can confirm this is a very solid set. It's not as thematically entertaining as Theros, but the decks are a bit more interesting, and I feel like I'm seeing a few more surprises. I'm about to embark on another tour through this set, which is more than can be said for Tarkir. (It's worth noting my appreciation thus far has been in direct proportion to the number of sets I stuffed into a given set. Tarkir = 2, Theros =3, Zendikar =4.)
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
[b]Innistrad Cube[/b] (mostly Shadows over Innistrad block)
[i]Distributed Planar Collection VII[/i]

RATING: 7
[b]Amonkhet Cube[/b]
[i]Distributed Planar Collection VIII[/i]
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
[b][url=www.cubetutor.com/cubeblog/96104]Ixalan Cube[/url][/b]
[i]Distributed Planar Collection VI[/i]
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
[b][url=http://www.cubetutor.com/cubeblog/97512]Alara Cube[/url][/b]
[i]Distributed Planar Collection IX[/i]

I can't say I'm too excited about this one. The promise of a multicolor set devolved into the usual routine of color-pair archetypes, and even then it's just the allied archetypes. A closer look reveals even these "pairs" are largely focused on a single color that just leans a little in one direction or another depending on the allied color in its deck. Thankfully, there are some subthemes in each color, but this structure is remarkably similar to the relatively uninteresting Dragons of Tarkir format, which I gave the same rating. All in all, it's still Magic--I'm sure I'll enjoy it--but I'll probably be ready to move on fairly quickly.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 4
[b]Leftovers Cube[/b]

It turns out that even a pile of leftover cards can turn into a decent draft, as long as you're intentional about it. My previous experiments with this had been nothing more than color-balanced, with no thought given to archetypes, so you were putting together decks that simply did nothing but get into a long slog of hopeless topdecking. Maybe I got lucky with this particular card pool, as it seemed to have some basic themes baked in already, but all I had to do was handpick a few more crappy cards, and suddenly I have another draftable set. It probably favors some archetypes over others, but a least you'll be able to make some slightly synergistic decks. For me, it's probably worth a play or two just to see how things shake out, and those plays--unlike with my prior experiments--won't be painful.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
[b][url=http://www.cubetutor.com/cubeblog/97697]Lorwyn-Shadowmoor Cube[/url][/b]
[i]Distributed Planar Collection X[/i]

I found this set to be quite interesting to put together. Although many of the strategies are "linear," the linearities are cross-cutting, so I don't think you're on rails too much. Baking in Shadowmoor was a challenge but should give the draft experience more variety while also enhancing Lorwyn's tribal synergies. There are at least 15 decks baked into this, with several based in 3-color shards. While that latter point opens up the possibility that there might be different "flavors" of, say, Wizards decks, depending upon how you pair up White, Blue, and Black, I'm not sure these builds will feel all that different, so I'm rating this set conservatively for now. If actual play reveals more variety between these decks or some surprise archetypes emerging, I can see myself upping my rating.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
[b]Rath[/b]
[i]Distributed Planar Collection V[/i]

This set is essentially a physical version of Tempest Remastered, which was a redesign of the Rath Cycle released by Wizards of the Coast for MTGO. The set is not designed around archetypes, and each color focuses on doing its own thing rather than carving out ways it can partner with other colors. As a result, drafts will probably focus grabbing the top cards and building the support to make them as effective as possible, as opposed to crafting a unique deck. The set has been described as "solid two-color Magic," which is evocative of some of my less favored sets.

One advantage for me is that I had very little to do with the design of this set: it's just 2x Commons, 1x Uncommons, and 45 Rares from Tempest Remastered. Therefore, I won't really know what I'm doing going into it and might be pleasantly surprised. I'm guessing I'll enjoy it for a few plays and then be ready to move on to the next set.

RATING: 10
MTG is at its best in its limited formats (drafting and sealed).  The most fun format I've experienced was drafting the cube.  You can read more about it at www.cubedrafting.com.  Constructed formats would rate around an 8 for me.

You can see my current cube list at http://cubetutor.com/viewcube/11000.

As of 2017, I am playing the game competitively, and am currently a bronze level pro.  The game is fantastic at all levels of play, from casual kitchen table and commander play to professional constructed tournament play.  It really is a unique experience, and is worth the cost.

Beyond that the business model of collectible games is deplorable.  It is a form of gambling targeted towards children.  It adds no benefit to the gameplay is done specifically to milk as much money from people as possible.

Some may say it's too random and the requirement to have mana cards in your deck is ruining the game, but for me it's more lively this way. You can get flooded or screwed with mana, of course, but this randomness makes the game a bit more challenging and replayable.

I would play for fun now--the cards are SO much cooler now than when I played--but not spend money on it again.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
Best CCG ever. Although this game appears to have as many detractors as fans, you cannot deny the impact this game has had on the industry.  Some (okay, more than some) will say that it has had a negative impact by spawning that evil, addictive, money-grubbing machine called CCG.  Overall, I believe that it has had a positive effect by opening the portal to new concepts in games; novel approaches to gaming and events; combining collecting and gaming in an unique fashion (which is just one of the many reasons we hang out on BGG anyway); not to mention the creative and evolving gaming engine at the core of the game.  And we have not even touched upon the fact it is still one of the most (if not the most) played game logged on BGG.   Even with its fleas, Magic the Gathering clearly deserves to be in the Top 100.  

Awards:  Origins Best Fantasy or Science Fiction Boardgame 1993; Mensa Select 1994; Origins Hall of Fame; GAMES Magazine Hall of Fame; Counter Magazine Hall of Fame (2003); InQuest Gamer Top100-#1 (2007).

Game Played: #27800.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
I first got into MTG when I was 14. Now I'm 28 and I  still play it occasionally. A very good game.

The usual problems with all card games is still present here; too much reliance on card draw, and it's too easy to make combos that are practically unbeatable.

But it also has a simple/endlessly addictive gameplay, coupled with beautiful artwork. I still enjoy casual collecting, deck building and playing.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
Played this a LOT in the mid 90s and cost me lots of $$$. 
The core action and combat system game is OK as light fare with nice graphics. Because the core game is so simple there is a lot of flexibility in the game format(eg team-based multiplayer, drafting, etc). The main thing that really puts me off, though, is the continual rule changes created by the endless (and expensive) stream of new cards. It also means that the rules ARE the cards, so you spend a lot of time time adjusting to the implications of new expansions. It all makes for an expensive way to keep the core game fresh. I'd rather play a game that has a core set of rules with expansions that everyone can access without spending hundreds of dollars on booster packs. I would never get back into this game with the aim of developing a collection, but it might be good as a filler/beer & pretzels game set around a draft cube.

RATING: N/A
Oh dear. I have a hate/ love relationship with this one. 

The game is not complicated, it is just complex: meaning that the turn structure is simple, but there are so many tiny little rules to pay attention to that I lost many games due to overlooking a word or a similar little detail. 

Still, I find myself semi-regularly going to small, friendly events, and get either mana flooded or chrushed by my superior opponents. The whole mana mechanic makes no sense, and yet I think it is part of the appeal to the game: much like poker, you can always blaim the cards. 

This is a very serious game if played at high levels but I have no desire to do that. I despise it, and yet i love it. Or maybe I am a victim of it? 

Nevertheless, gathering with a bunch of friends, opening packs, building decks and clashing is just plain fun.

RATING: 6
PiFFed.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
Magic is certainly an evocative game. It has a lot going for and against it. The depth and scope of the game is both an attribute and its downfall. I have played many, many games of this and exploring the deck-building aspect of the game was interesting but honestly I think I've done that to death. The game is arguably broken in casual play when you consider all the permutations and incredibly strong combinations that exist and how anyone with enough money and resources can basically design an unbeatable deck against someone with lesser resources and money. This aspect of the game is a turn off to me and what generally killed the game for me. 

Yes I know you can play with variants like drafting and cubes and EDH what not... but essentially I think I've been there, done that by now. Not in the sense that I'm the greatest Magic player around and I've explored every nuance of every type of deck.. but that I've done enough with the game to know that it's just another way to mix, combo, re-mix, re-combo... and it goes on endlessly. Decks and combos until the end of time.

Again, I feel that vast, open system is both a feature and a flaw. Yes I can still have a fun, casual game of Magic and play the game with a few friends, but that endless making of decks and playing the game to discover more and more nuances is essentially stale for me.

There are only so many times I want to build up a multitude of decks catered to take my opponent down from 20/40 life points. It all becomes repetitive and monotonous with the illusion that there is "real" variety and variability.

I still admire the concept of Magic and their ability to continually push out seemingly interesting and "fresh" ways to play the game (and continuing to make zillions of dollars off the new crops of addicts is remarkable as well)... but I've certainly gone past the point of being interested enough to actually continue playing regularly. 

Originally a great game as I discovered the possibilities... gradually dulled down to good game as I endlessly built and rebuilt decks and played the game sometimes endlessly... and now an ok game at best. Still admired but not enough to keep my rating up or have enough interest in it to actually seek out and play this repetitively. 
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

I don't count this as a board game.  But I have sunk many thousands of hours of my life into playing this game.  I discovered this game as it was released, and as a child in 1993, this game was simply brilliant compared to anything else that existed at the time.  Even though I no longer play it any more, it really has stood the test of time and adapted well (I can only assume it is the most profitable board/card game ever by a vary large margin).

RATING: 6.5
The game is good fun, unfortunately it's not so great if you play with people who shovel in all their extra money, or are consumed with only playing to beat every other player... then it's decidedly NOT fun.  This game also seems to attract the worst-of-the-worst sort of nerdlingers... the kind I'd be embarrassed for my wife to meet... and I'm often embarrassed myself just for being in their presence to overhear their nerd banter. Good game none-the-less though!

RATING: 10

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
(I'm not discussing the economic model. There are a lot of cheap ways to play the game, they're just not sanctioned for competition. You can for instance make yourself a 500 card draft set for the price of a Dominion box.)

So I'm breaking my pattern of only commenting on games I don't like enough to keep them, because I can't recommend Magic unless you are okay with the following points:

- Land cards cause a small amount of games to be boring because entirely decided by draw issues. I'm okay with that because the enjoyment I get from the good games really makes up for the dull ones. This also implies MTG is meant to be played several times in a row where you can determine a winner from multiple games.
- Though the core principles are quickly learnt, the comprehensive rules are mind-blowingly complex. Even after decades, I sometimes find a card interaction or a timing issue that requires me to put on my DCI Judge shirt and dive into the 200+ pages of the comprehensive ruleset.
- As with all CCGs, MTG's official constructed environments are designed to last until the optimal competitive decks are figured out, rather than with strong game balance and diversity in mind. And for the amount of time it takes, you'd rather design your own game than try to craft a really healthy and sustainable constructed format from the existing rules and card pool.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 7
Brilliant game. Famous for being the first CCG.

I loved the metagame in deckbuilding and collecting. The gameplay is fresh, fast, and furious. Multiplay in different formats increases the fun exponentially.

However, the game rewards excessive purchasing habits, no matter what "they" say. This game will hurt your wallet, bad. Also, I don't like the powerplay where players try to find the most devastating combo's to win in turn 3. Boring.

Play this with the right friends, and restrict your purchases and this is a winner.

RATING: 4
I was a MtG bitch back in the day (3rd/4th edition I think) but only ever bought 4 decks and a couple of expansion boosters.  One of these contained a rare Preacher card, who was pretty weak but very thematic and my favourite white card.  Eventually I was coerced into parting with it in exchange for about 150 cards and from there traded my collection up to a few thousand.  Lost many many hours of my school life to this game, but seeing some of my wealthier school friends literally spend thousands of pounds on it before burning out left a bitter taste in my mouth about collectible games of any kind.  Ingenious and devilish, I would have to be heavily persuaded to go in for a game, and my stashed away decks are even now still based on theme (Goblins vs. Elves) rather than killer combos.

RATING: 10
Most of my cards were from the Beta set, used Unlimited/Revised for fillers/lands and new additions.

Yes, I played before the Black Lotus was 1 per deck, and had 2.  Also had 1 Mox Ruby (but didn't play red).

My primary deck was a green/black weenie 40-card deck.  My other deck was a blue control deck.  We always played for ante, so I never had many of my rares in one deck, though I did build a deck around Ancestral Recall and Time Walk for if I ever played a non-ante tournament.

If I only knew then what I know now I would have done a better job at keeping my cards safe.

I do not think I'll ever play again, too much investment, and too many cards now.  But was my main game for a few years.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
Putting aside any feelings on collectability for the moment, there is no doubt in my mind that Magic is the best designed CCG out there.  Its basic mechanics are simple, but the depth that comes from the cards is amazing.  Add to that many, many different viable strategies, and you have a game with unequaled strategic depth.

The collectible aspect can be a problem for some, but I think WotC has done a really good job of making the game very playable for people that don't want to spend too much or want to jump in late in the game.  The game can get very expensive, and to be a competitive player the initial cost is very high, but this is one of the best games made.  If you want to try it out, play some draft or sealed deck, both of which are excellent formats.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 3
The first and foremost of trading card games.  Its major advantage is ubiquity--it's easy to find tournaments or casual opponents.  Over the game's lifespan, the design has become quite streamlined, although flaws from the initial design remain.

The major problems compared to other games are considerable financial cost and the possible difficulty in finding others who play the same tournament or casual format.
