=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 1
Well, my experience with MTG started when I was a kid in the mid 90s.  Overall, it was an addicting game and my experiences were good for the most part.  Fast forward to a couple of years ago where I decided to pick it up as a hobby again.  Now that I'm smarter and less naive (and more aware of the great selection of independent games out there), I've found this game to be lacking.

First: Even after years of development, this game is still poorly balanced.  Set after set, my jaw drops in disbelief that they could not possibly realize how broken their cards continue to be.  This problem is so severe that we see that all tournament winning decks (and by extension many more competing decks) all revolve around a small number of cards.  If broken enough, rare cards are easily more expensive than their new category of legendary or super rares.  This level of ineptitude for a company that has the financial resources and experience that it does should be unacceptable by today's standards where many smaller independent company's have developed beautifully balanced games involving asymmetrical warfare (sorry I couldn't come up with a better term off the top of my head).

Second: This point regards the costs.  Now, I don't have a problem with games costing money and I understand that collectible cards games are a fun way to put a lot of money (in smaller more acceptable increments) into a hobby.  My point here regards the competence of Wizards of the Coast yet again.  Put simply, the "pros" and more in-touch MTG players don't even bother with booster packs.  To illustrate, pros playing the game online would sooner sell the booster packs to save up more money for buying specific cards in the market place.  So, this game has such severe balancing issues and such a rigid hierarchy in the value of cards that the purchasing of booster packs, which is supposed to be the most typical way casual and most players collect these cards, is cost inefficient and left for the "suckers".  Further one this point of costs, Wizards of the Coast even go against their own incentives to inflate the costs of cards.  They still don't ban cards that were clear mistakes in their major tournament (cough lotus needs to die cough).  They used to reprint older sets in boosters.  I've seen them and bought them.  They were a little more expensive, but I was okay with it and understood why.

Third: Finally, MTG is just an overrated game and is a drain on the gaming community as a whole.  Like I've hinted at, I believe there is talent out there to design superior games than MTG.  But there isn't a market for the collectable card game from a smaller company as it requires substantial distribution and widespread demand.  Bot most kids who play MTG don't know about other options and once they burn out on MTG like some of the other 1 ratings you see here, they sure as heck don't want to move onto another collectible card.  In conclusion, MTG needs to pass on to the next life.  It's not that bad of a game, but the ineptitude of Wizards of the Coast and the fact that there's so much more potential out there is evidence enough that MTG detracts from rather than contributes to the gaming community.

As an afterword, this is all my opinion.  Though, I do try to justify my opinion as much as possible.  I hope this review contributes to a larger discussion (which should be had).  Thanks for reading
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 7.5
I've tried out many CCGs and while some have some kind of mechanic or theme that is different from MTG and provide a distinct flavor of fun, MTG continues to be the top CCG for me since I found out about it back in 2000.

UPDATE:
The concept of resources (lands) in your deck that slow down the acquisition of the cards you need and are also required to play cards, feels outdated today.

I'd much rather play Android: Netrunner or any modern asymmetrical deck-based card game.

Game play is strong in Magic, the key weakness being that you can get hosed if you don't draw the right opening hand (e.g. too little mana).   Got a little fiddily with the timing rules, but I forgive it given its origins.  I stopped collecting after about the first 20,000 expansions, so I don't really know the current state of the game.

RATING: 9
Wants: Unopened boosters, only. I only play booster drafts these days.

To this day (started in 1994), this is one of my favorite games. Highly replayable, fast, great creative thinking. I admit that I enjoy the game a lot more now that I have an income that can easily afford $50/mth on magic cards alone. But if you wish to avoid the "whoever spends the most, wins the most" issue, I highly recommend drafts and sealed deck leagues where everyone has the same number of cards. MTGO has its issues but I really like the access to a larger number of people to play against.

RATING: 10
[Shared copy]
Great mechanics and a diverse array of deck drafting possibilities continues to have an immense influence on gaming and is still a joy to play. Deck building is obviously limited by one's card pool, which can be costly to expand depending on what format you choose to play. Bulk commons are still an issue.  Finally, for a focused, 2-player game, the shuffled, blind draw of the deck feels a little antiquated, especially with games like Mage Wars.

RATING: 7
I like MtG, and I will play MtG, but I think overall that MtG is probably not a good thing.  MtG requires players to continuously pour money into new cards in order to be competitive.  In addition, the variations of the game that have fallen into fashion (EDH for instance) further exacerbate the problem by requiring the player to invest in a larger collection.  There also seems to be a culture problem with MtG.  At any given MtG table you are likely to find at least one loudmouth jerk, and a handful of people that have neglected personal hygiene.  Put together, these elements have resulted in my only playing occasionally.

RATING: 7
I was hooked on this game in three different phases of my life.  Every time I got sucked into it, I would start spending too much money just to think I had the best deck.  It becomes an addiction.  I think I would enjoy it more playing draft style of play, but than you need to go to all the meet-ups on Friday nights and play with all the unwashed hair kids.  To play casually would be my goal, however unattainable that is.  

Magic is a deck-building card game with thousands and thousands of cards to do that from.  The goal is to build a deck that kills and annoys your opponents the best.  Because they never stop making new editions to this game it becomes a never-ending time & money sink.

Very fun, if that is the only hobby you would like to concentrate on.

RATING: 3
I remember the day when Magic stopped being about the fun: when magazines started printing prices for cards.  People stopped ante-ing, even when they knew damned well they'd eventually get their cards back.  They just didn't want to risk anything anymore, even something as simple as a piece of cardboard.

If we're talking about a small group of people locked into a set amount of cards, preferably by drafting or an LCG format, this rating catapults up to 8.  It's a very fun game that's been killed by the cottage industry that has surrounded it.

But those Archenemy cards look pretty sweet.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 5
A good game to play once in a while.  I've created some good decks, but I can say that collectible card games do not rate above 5 because you're always behind.  I've stopped collecting.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
Make no mistake - this game is addictive. It is addictive in the same way that gambling is addictive: it offers randomized payouts with large variance, both in what cards you receive when buying packs before the game and in what cards you draw during the game.

While it is easy to confuse addictiveness with fun, the two are not the same. In this case, the addictive qualities serve to disguise a clumsy design. The mana system is enormously frustrating, and there are surprisingly few interesting decisions in the Standard format. Let's not even go into the byzantine rule set. 

Magic does deserve credit for its thematic cleverness and for its many innovations, which have had an enormous influence on the hobby. Still, my final verdict is this: save yourself some suffering and burn your money in a fireplace, not on this game.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 8.5
Remove the well advertised issue of funds being a major unbalancing factor (Like so much of life). And this is a fantastic game. 

I have a moderate size collection, but stopped around 5th edition as at this point it really kicked up a notch in terms of cycling through editions. I believe the focus very much went to the high end "professional" and league players and putting it out of reach or medium level occasional league players, who still wanted to be competitive, like myself.

But its still a great game.  Been cracking open a few old decks lately & playing with the boys and all of us have been having a blast.   It has the ability to scratch a lot of itches, great game play, deck building and collecting. 

Still the $ factor makes it a "keep away" for me, although we do own a few pre-built decks purchased in more recent years.

RATING: 10
I have not played for several years, but the scale and exhaustive design work put into this game makes it one of the best.

The common "priciest deck wins" criticism is easily averted by playing Limited (my favourite formats). However, I am becoming a bit disillusioned by the noticeably increasing power difference across rarities.

Drafting, or casual play, is the way to go here, and the signalling and wheeling aspects beats 7 Wonders hands down.

RATING: 8
I loved this game before it was destroyed by the sheer ammount of cards that were published (and other things). My rating doesn't values what it is now, but what it was.

It's  impossible to maintain the balance with that many cards.

I also did not like that the most powerful cards, instead of being eliminated from the game, were not published anymore (thus, becoming more rare and expensive) and declared limited (maximum 1 per deck). The existance of these cards allowed expensive mazes to be more competitive that other strategic mazes very well designed.

It was a very fun game to play with friends, but not so much at a competitive level.

RATING: 8

I still enjoy playing this game but only in draft formats.  The "Winston Cube" format, where you basically draft from a block of your favorite cards, is particularly fun for me these days.  But buy new cards?  Play in a tournament?  Nah, I'll pass.

RATING: 3
Collectible, annoying players, never ending errata, unstable play environment.  A true black hole to throw money into with no playable return.

A couple pluses that keep it from being a "1" - Richard Garfield invented a clever design that never should have been collectible;  managed to single-handedly keep game stores from going out of business in the '90's;  may act as a gateway to other games.

*Update - I like Planechase and the duel decks.  The duel decks provide a quick MTG game experience.  They don't mix and match well, though.  Planechase is right in line with my love of some chaotic elements in game environments.

RATING: 8.5
Competitive or Team, 2-4, Strategy, TCG

Rating is for "kitchen table" MTG. I don't care too much for collectible games or competitive scenes in general, but man if it isn't fun to grab a Duel Deck pack or throw together a couple quick decks and play with friends. 

As for the rules themselves, I like the mathiness of it all, and the bluffing element eliminates determinism. Facing certain defeat but somehow overcoming by pretending that last card in your hand is a counterspell is exhilarating. 

And with the release of the first "challenge deck", Magic has hit the table again in my house. I really hope they keep releasing these.

RATING: 3
I think this one gets high ratings because it was first.  I'm only giving it a 3 because I like some of the card art.  I played back in the '90s so that's what my comments are based on.  Weak to negligible storyline; for me I like the CCG to have a unifying theme.  In theory the simplicity of the general game engine and complexity of specific cards allowed for great flexibility, but in practice it just led to frustration.  It was no fun getting demolished by the latest killer combo, played by the guy at the table who'd spent the most money on boosters.  I bet I'd give this game a 7 or better rating if I'd only played sealed starter games.

RATING: 10
The one-and-only CCG, in my opinion. This game gets the only "10" rating I have awarded. No other CCG has come close to matching the elegance and complexity this game can deliver. The game has evolved into a cash cow with "endless" expansions.  Just when I think I have a firm handle on the game, I enter into casual game and encounter a whole new strategy and/or card combination that makes me want to go home and design a new deck. I not only love to play this CCG, but I have made enough money from card sales that I actually bought the wife a NEW CAR, had the roof repaired, bought a new hot water heater, and more! No lie. Buy by the case, build your sets and sell off the rest. I have been doing this from the start. "There are a lot of $$$'s in them thar pieces of cardboard!" The photo of the MINT Power 9 in this game listing is a small portion of the cards I have kept "for future investment"!

RATING: 7.5

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Too expensive, too time consuming, but so good. I own around 8.000 magic cards (never counted them) and love this game. But for me it suffers the same problem that the abstract game Go suffers. It's not a casual gamers game so you can't bust this one out at a gaming night with non-gamer friends.

One could theoretically keep it simple & cheap by just getting a couple of premade decks but one can also end up getting addicted to magic and spend more and more money on it. However it is THE most sophisticated ccg out there. So if you're going to waste money on little pieces of paper, waste them on Magic and not any other ccg that'll be gone after a couple of years. (Then again, that means you're free again whereas Magic will hold an eternal grip on your life...)

The deckbuilding aspect of the game with so many different cards makes this game so deep that playing with or against another deck is often like playing another game. Magic is not one  game but many different games really, which is why it stands up to repeated plays so well.

You can play zombies and try to swarm your opponent with the undead. You can be the sneaky blue mage who just messes with his opponents gameplan all the time by countering (nullyfying) his spells and manipulating his cards. Your deck can be agressive and attempt to overwhelm your opponent before he can put up a reasonable defense, or you can to hinder your opponent at whatever he is doing and then just bring down some monstrous creature or unleash a huge spell and overwhelm your opponent out of nowhere.

You can also just get whacky play any mix of colors, even all five colors, which is not just possible but can also make for powerful decks with a good and big enough cardpool. The sky (and your pocket money) is the limit in this game.

Magic is a great game if you have players of roughly equal skill to play against. The learning curve is very steep and some players will learn how to play the game but never grasp the deeper strategies. There is just so much rules to digest with keywords, abilities, phases, card types, timing, zones etc. that a beginner barely has time and brainpower left to figure out what is actually a good play in any given situation.

An experienced player can easily crush an inexperienced player even with an inferior deck, which is a good thing of course, since skill should be rewarded. But Magic is not a pick up and play game, where you just have to play a couple of rounds and expect to win against a seasoned veteran, despite magic relying so much on the luck of the draw.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
Infinitely replayable in a multitude of formats - your mileage may vary depending on how much money you want to spend.  That being said, there are many interesting formats such as Elder Dragon Highlander, or 2-Headed Giant that let you get the max value out of otherwise worthless cards.  You can take this game as far as you want and still be challenged.

RATING: N/A

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 5
I'm not a CCG'er and I wasn’t that impressed to tell the truth. Draw 1 card, ramp up the mana early, get out creatures as you can - all seem to be obvious plays dictated by what you draw. The game play seems to be in the combat decisions and working out the repercussions and that was fine - trading off defense now vs losing life and counter-attacking next turn. In the early game you never have enough mana. In the latter game the last thing you want is more mana cards as you can do virtually what you want, and therefore you’re dependent on what you draw.

I can see how the gameplay rewards the effort of deck construction though, so that and the combat decisions seems to be where the reward for good ‘play’ lie. Given I have no interest in deck construction though, and that the luck of the cards drawn seemed to override combat nous, I have no real urge to explore it further.

Where it was better than Doomtown and Lot5R was the obviousness of the cards (no masses of fine print on what they can do) which produced a faster game, but the downside was the simplicity led to a lack of depth.

RATING: 5

With a game like this you have to buy a lot of cards to get what you want and the rest is useless. I often see players that buy an entire display for a lot of money, only to find a few useful cards and throw away the rest. 

Even if it was a LCG instead of a CCG I would never have the time and effort to keep up with all the news and to figure out good combos and build decks. This is why I hardly ever play LCG's or CCG's, even if I own a few.

RATING: 5
3 plays - I'm definitely not a serious player, with only having played a few intro games with a friend. This game was fun in it's own right and would have scored higher had it been a more 'accessible' game. This game requires money and dedication (in terms of deck building to be competitive and keeping up with new card releases), much like the culture of a tabletop miniatures game. This therefore attracts a more 'gamer' crowd how will 'gaming focus' is much more on this single game. This ultimately makes it become much less like a 'casual game'. 

The business model of this type of game is also something that I can not support either, with continual releases of new products that make previous purchases obsolete. Very reminiscent of the Games Workshop days. All of this culture and context, makes the game way less fun to play for someone who only has a casual interest in playing MTG.

RATING: 7
First of all, I refuse to play Constructed Magic; it's pay-to-win, and the amount of money necessary would buy me a lot of other entire games rather than just four copies of a piece of cardboard.

That said, mechanically Magic is fairly interesting.  The mana curve is tedious and often controls the outcome of the game more than actual deckbuilding, which is depressing, hence the 7.  But playing the game with prebuilt decks (either Duel Decks or intro packs) is "boardgame-y" enough to be interesting.  It's still not a /great/ game, but it's good, and I'll play it.

RATING: 7

This is actually what I like most about Magic. Sure, you can be intensely competitive and spend hundreds of dollars a year crafting the best decks. But you can also spend $35 on a Deckbuilder's Toolkit box, and be perfectly happy to play casual games for months or even years.

RATING: 7
More depth than any other game, ever. The only thing keeping it from being a 10 in my book is the massive financial investment it calls for.

Update: Reactionary game filled with playing cards and hoping your opponent doesn't have counterspells. I somehow never noticed this before, but card design is largely uninspired, with only a few cards from each set that really stand out.

Other LCGs (Netrunner) and pseudo LCGS (Summoner Wars) have shown this game in an unfavorable backlight.

EDIT: Going back and playing this... man, having to fill your deck with land is boring. The mana struggle also makes dual lands so indispensable that they are just auto-includes. I don't want auto-includes, I want to put what I want in there.

RATING: 7
Magic.

Oh crap, I knew I shouldn't have got involved.

Now I own a lot of cards and have made all kinds of decks.  I was introduced to it very recently through a boardgame group that I meet with from time to time.  It was all easy fun at first, but I went out and bought cards and ended up playing with a good friend of mine many times.

If anything, I am really glad that I never got into this stuff when I was a teenager.  I would have spent all of my money on this game!  I've got enough cards now and the play has slowed down so I doubt I'll buy more, but it's a very enjoyable game to play for me.  Lots of great moves that I can appreciate both when I play them and when my opponent plays them against me.

I still think 'The Spoils' is a better game, though.  However - for a quick equivalent this hits the spot.

RATING: 8.5
Haven't played in ages, but it is certainly a seminal game. My wife and I used to play endlessly (back in early to mid 90s) and enjoyed it a great deal. =-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8.69
Shame about the collectible elements as this is a fantastic card game that really is worth trying.

Despite owning a complete collection of the Blue Moon card game (the closest thing to this that I'm aware of), there's just something about Magic that makes it more appealing. And the size of the cards in Blue Moon is an annoyance.

My suggestion if you're interest in playing this casually with friends - pick a set & acquire one of each intro deck. Play with those to learn the game and see if you like it. Then, to allow you to get into deck building, look to buy a bulk collection of commons & uncommons from the same set from eBay or similar. Then DO NOT get any more cards. There simply is no way you can own every card ever printed, nor any need to.

Don't worry about acquiring a complete set, don't chase down rares, don't think about constructing really powerful decks.

With a few hundred cards you'll have enough to be able to randomly deal out some commons & uncommons and build decks to play against each other with those. You may need to pick up a few extra land cards to allow this, but they're very inexpensive. You'll get to try out all kinds of combinations and never see the same deck twice.


OWN: All 5 x Magic 2010 Core Intro Packs, plus a number of boosters and inidivual card purchases (land cards & common/uncommon cards) from the same set.

NOTE: This makes for a (relatively!) modest yet varied collection with lots of commons & uncommons, a fair selection of rares for spice, and enough land cards to allow 2 people to play "limited" format against each other with artificial "booster packs" dealt from the collection.

REMINDER: DON'T NEED ANY MORE!

RATING: 5

If it's your game, I say go for it.  It's just not mine.

RATING: 4
I've tried 3 or 4 times to get into this game. I can understand it's appeal as the numerous tactical combinations are an interesting puzzle, but the text reading slows play. To make any informed decision requires knowledge of not only your deck but also your opponent's which is impossible, unless you want to spend time learning the 100's of cards out in circulation. But it's the attitude of the game that I can't get into. It is the equivalent of boxing. Yes it may be dramatic at times, but the the player spending the most time building a brutal deck will emerge the victor. Even the promotion of the game has other hair raising similarities to boxing.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 10
Magic is amazing amounts of fun every time I play it.  The strategy is so complex that even advanced players will occasionally make mistakes but simple enough that new players can enjoy themselves.  The game is always changing with fun new mechanics and cards that keep things fresh every couple of months.  

I play booster drafts which cost about $16 for an evening of fun and then I sell my cards and prizes recouping much of the expense.  This recurring expense is more expensive than normal board games but much cheaper than trying to keep up with the constructed metagame.

Playing in tournaments at my local game store is also a really social experience that puts me in contact with people I never would have met otherwise and led to me meeting most of my best friends.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
[floatleft][ImageID=821612][/floatleft]I stopped playing M:tG after high school in 2002 during the Odyssey block. I still have my old decks. I love Magic. M:tG is insanely addictive with massive replayability potential. I didn't stop playing because of lack of interest, Magic just fell to the way-side. Now getting back into Magic seems like a daunting task and none of my close gaming comrades play actively. I miss playing Magic. I recently looked at some of the new cards and I was impressed with what they have done with the game.

RATING: 7.5

Jason went off the deep end and constructed this insane deck and the game just lost it's fun after that. Now we'll play the pre-constructed decks every once in a while because they are more balanced. Under those conditions, it is still fun to play. My beefs are with the type of player my husband becomes playing this game--way too serious. Aside from this, really love the artwork too.

RATING: 10
A real-total-absurd money-drain. But also a real monster-game, an entire universe by its own.
For me more a collection than a game: I love the incredible artwork and I have all sets edited in Italy (in italian language), since the old first italian 'black bordered' 4th Edition, plus Antiquities and Fallen Empires (~60.000 cards in total, counting doubles... and yes, I'm not normal).

The game is great, original and clever: tactics, combos and deck building possibilities are endless... Best card-game ever for me and one of the best games I played in my life, also if the last sets are very different (and worst) from what Magic was in the beginning; now the game is more abstract & 'math' and less thematic.
But the great, real problem with Magic is that now it is more a business than a game. A real pity, 'cause the game is really great, perhaps too great and it just pays the price of his success, like many things in life...

RATING: 8
An awesome game: brilliant and extremely simple idea, fantastic artwork, deep as the best abstracts (the system is based on probabilities), plays very quick and is so much fun.
It was a milestone in the gaming history and has clearly influenced many other newer games.
Don't be afraid of its business aspect. Yes, it holds the gaming world record number of expansions, but you don't need to get them all or buy any expensive cards to enjoy it.
We've been playing it for 15 years without investing tons of time or money on it.
We have around 800 cards now (almost all of them commons and uncommons) and lately we always play a house variant of cube drafting.
And sure we will keep playing it for a long time to come.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9.75
The distribution model is terrible, but the actual game design is unquestionably brilliant. The only thing keeping this from being a 10 is the rules complexity, but that's somewhat unavoidable given the incalculable number of possible card interactions. A lot of people hate this game because of its price structure, which is one of the worst in gaming, but the game itself is strategic and amazing.

EDIT: If you are looking to get into Magic: the Gathering, but daunted by its price, THIS is the hands-down #1 way to do it: Go to ebay and find an auction for "4x common/uncommon set" of a set that starts with M and ends with a number ("M12", "M13", "M14", etc.) These can be found on ebay for under $20 (shipping included) if you're patient. Then buy 25-30 of each basic land (or go beg/borrow/steal them from your friends/local store) and you don't need to purchase another card in your life. Just make a bunch of decks and play a bunch of matches using only these cards. The strategy is WAY deeper than it appears on the surface. If you have Magic-playing friends, invite them over to play with you using your cards only; they'll probably grumble about how boring and basic your cards are, but I GUARANTEE they'll have a good time, even if they don't expect to. This is a great way to get a taste of the game without overwhelming yourself or your wallet.

Double edit: Use the above method to teach new players how to play, creating specially constructed (balanced) decks to use for the first few matches. It will reinvigorate your love of the game.

RATING: 8.4
Instant CCG classic. Great mechanics and an insane amount of combinations. The game itself is coming from a different era though - I don't think CCG games are that popular these days. Great thing for collectioners though, as the artwork and lore text is simply amazing.

As pretty much all CCG, it's created mostly just for tournament purposes. It's very hard to play casually with friends, if they don't have their own deck. I know that there are lots of tournament rules, some funky drafts, etc. etc., but it all feels like an awkward and lousy attempt to fix an unfixable problem. 

The solution, though, is to play an iOS version (also online multiplayer), which has limited and finite amount of decks - so you can configure and play the deck, decks are thematically arranged (denial, dmg, direct spells, etc), so you get the chance to taste all the different flavors and pick the one you enjoy the most.

RATING: 9
A rating of 9 only for casual players and fun play, since Type II turned the game into a blatant re-cycling money-making sinkhole of power creep for profit's sake.
But as a expandable, customizable card game it is an incredible accomplishment that revolutionized gaming. The deck-building aspect is a vital gaming concept, not to be dismissed or overlooked.
I got in right at the tailend of Unlimited, and got out after Homelands, though picked up a smattering of Weatherlight, Mirage, etc.
Still have quite a few classic old cards - no Mox/Lotus or Ancestral Recall, but most others (dual-lands, Time Walk, Time Twisters, Mirror Universes, Gauntlet of Might, Juzam Djinns, etc)

Have recently started playing the XBox Duels of the Planeswalkers game, and taught my son. We play casually, I've caught up on most of the casual cards in the 12 years I took off, and have played in a couple pre-release tourneys.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Expensive, but insane replay ability and depth.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 5
Fun game, but loses it's appeal with hardcore fans who can always outspend you. It can often degrade into whoever pays the most for cards, although it does have very deep strategies.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9.5
Count: 2 | Length: D | Complex: 3.2 | Play: Competitive
2 (2) 6

Colors Rated Favorite to Least: 1 Black, 2 Blue, 3 White, 4 Green, 5 Red.

I've been playing and collecting on and off again for more than 20 years (4th Ed). This was the game that captured my imagination, helped me understand the psychology of the meta game, and catalyzed my interest in game mechanisms.

My disinterest in tournaments means: (1) I'm saddened by the power creep over the last decade. (2) Single card combos are way too common and bring down average player IQ. (3) I refuse to play with/vs decks with Planeswalker cards because they require watering down a deck to use/counter them, yet provide no improvement to a skilled victory.

RATING: 7
I was a late comer to MTG and was skeptical when my brother-in-law first asked me to try it out, but I came to really love it.  Unfortunately it wore thin on me fairly quickly, as the constant investment in cards got to be a little much.  We also found that it came down to who had the most money to spend on a deck would be the winner.

If you're new and just getting into this, it's a great game, but I would get some friends, have a draft and play that way.  It makes it a much more accessible and affordable experience.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
portable and extremely varied game, rules can be intimidating and land screw can be frustrating

EDIT:

So I'm playing this a lot more and I think it's the game I'm obsessed with the most. The gameplay is alright, but the real joy of the game is deckbuilding. If you are creative and like to design things, this can be a game for you. I like trying new and innovative things.

The bad part about the game is that to get certain cards, the cost is really, really high. I mean $20 for a single card? There's cards that are worth tons more than that as well.

Even with that drawback, I want to be clear that it's really about what format you play more than anything. If you play tournament level, prepare to shell out some cash. If you play casual like me and 99% of the other Magic players out there, you don't have to spend that much to do okay.

The depth of deckbuilding is only matched by the amount of game analysis that there is. There are terms like tempo, midrange and boardwipe to remember. You have mana dorks, bombs and removal. There are a ton of card types and the interaction from all the cards is interesting.

I like the game because of the game analysis it has and has had for decades. It's also very nice that it has a huge player base, so you don't have to worry about not finding players, which is actually the case with 99% of my other games I have. The rules are quite a bit to swallow at first, but then become second nature. Also, the nature of it being random means that at times you'll have crap draws where you'll draw all lands or no lands. But despite all of this, it's a landmark game that is one of the top. If you don't like it, at least know of it.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 5
Urgh.  This is my brother's favorite game.  Since he is my main gaming partner, I hear a lot of "let's play magic."  Of course, he hears a lot of "I don't want to.  Let's get root canals instead."

There are too many small rules that I don't know that I need to know in order be competitive at MtG.  I have to have memorized a whole deck of cards and know the nuances of hundreds of cards (both mine and my opponents) and I just don't care to invest that much time and energy into the game.

As much as MtG is expensive in terms of money investment, it is also expensive in terms of time investment.  One must study the available cards, sift through dozens of booster packs, and create optimum decks from rares bought while staring into glass cases.  MtG is a lifestyle and it is not a lifestyle choice that I want to make.

That being said, I do understand that it's a game that has a lot to offer.  There are many choices for a player who would like to spend the time to create card combinations that are inventive and hard to combat.  I can understand why a person would love MtG--that person just isn't going to be me.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 10
I'm the proud owner of a Space the Convergence cube. Google it and bask in the awesomeness of this fan retheme. If you're in the area and want to check it out, let me know. Beyond that I also have various other "specialized" cubes including the Custom Cube Project v1.0, a Split Card Common/Uncommon Cube, and a fully proxied powered cube. 

For standard/real cards I have an unpowered "typical" cube, a copy of Adam Styborski's Pauper cube, RTR block Peasant 6 man cube, and a "Let's Learn Magic and/or Drafting" cube for new players. If you can't tell, drafting is my favorite way to play Magic.

I also enjoy Modern. My main deck is UW Tron, though I have a nice modern collection that allows me to create most non GBx based decks (missing Tarmogoyfs and Bob's).

Started playing this around the time of Revised. Given my extremely limited income at the time (I was a Freshman in HS), I managed to amass a respectable set, at least amongst my friends. Lots of great memories of playing this game at my parents house with 5-10 friends in massive free-for-all style games.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 3
I think it is a lot of fun to buy things because they keep local game stores in existence. I also like breaking into a new box or packet. The strategy of this game is a slightly expanded version of rock-paper-scissors. I personally believe that no one will ever surpass the fun potential and interest of a 52-card poker deck. When you buy Magic, you are committing a lot of money for a game that can only be played one way in a specific manner at a specific event. The single deck packages that are sold at Friday Night Magic events are filled with low-powered cards that rarely even include a planes walker card. This means you will either have to spend more money on an individual rare card or buy a deck-builder set for even more money. I do love the Magic novels and have helped me understand the game better but they are just advertising. I would not say that this game is "broken." I just don't have room anymore and it is more expensive than I can manage

RATING: 6
In terms of the pure game, it is very good. In terms of mix and balance of the cards, it is also very good. I came for the good art, and stayed for the game.

I left for two reasons: One, some articles in Duellist which explained the finer points of the rules. However, they were basically rewriting the rules in those articles, as they went off into things that you would NEVER infer from the book that comes with a deck. Two, Fourth Edition. Correcting problems in Alpha and Beta in the Revised Edition was fine, Fourth made it obvious that they were just going to trade 'official' cards out as often as they could get away with to force continual repurchasing of basic supplies.

Pity, too. The main game is quite good.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9.5
I find that the requirements for what makes a good game experience when playing most games are very strict.  A good game of chess, for example, requires exactly one other player, who must be of roughly similar level and willingness to think.  Magic is great in that it is not only an incredibly deep game with some of the most intricate strategy around, which accommodates those who like a lot of time to consider their actions (via the deckbuilding aspect) and those who play quickly, but it is also very flexible.  2, 3 (less so), 4, 5, and 6-player games all have excellent variants available, and the level of difficulty of the decks can be scaled to the players.  The existence of limited events, like sealed deck and booster draft options, makes high-level play available to someone who owns no cards, and only wants to spend $12.  Combine all that with greater ease finding players than any other game affords, and you have a real treat.  Magic isn't the jigsaw of my gaming toolset, but a whole toolkit with wide applicability.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 8
Great card game, requires some rules but most are explained on the cards. Biggest downfall are 2 things; the theme is always the same (except the comedy packs) and hasn't changed too much. If you buy a few decks you should be good for the most part. You can find decent deals on eBay for buying a collection all at once. Competitive it's a little different, certain cards are staples and you need to shell out money for them but if you play casually with friends it's not too bad.  
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 6.5
I played MTG for 6 months in 1999, but there was no one else to play with in my hick home town, so I gave up playing, though I kept collecting (mostly rare cards) for a few years.

I had all of Unglued, because I purchased boosters when it first came out, lol. Also I had all of the Vanguard cards, the big ones, from their first printing. 

My entire collection was lost in a bad event in 2001. There were a lot of Alpha and Beta cards, moxes, even a black lotus. The collection was huge, with total worth at between 3 and 5 thousand dollars, then.

I began playing MTG again from about 2005 to about 2010, with some friends from the Double Eagle.

It was a fun time and I loved building and testing new deck ideas more than anything.

I stopped playing MTG. Once I got into playing board and card games, MTG seemed like a bad investment. Here is why:

1) You have to keep buying new cards to keep your decks at a competitive level even for casual play. This is because the newer cards have better mechanics, more synergy, and compared to older cards are over-powered.

2) MTG is really only playable, even casually, by MTG players. It is not much fun to teach new ppl, and they rarely want to learn.

1+2=3) MTG is a bad investment. For the money put into it, and the time put into it, I could be buying new board games and card games that EVERYONE can play and that will be playable for the REST OF OUR LIVES!

So I stopped, though I will say: MTG was a great game.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
This is still my favorite go-to game. I love the strategy of deck building.

RATING: 10
I bought my first game with my cards. I started this when it was in beta and ended my serious Magic career at Fallen Empires. I sold my cards and bought a brand new car. =-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 4.9
I played this, and played this, and played this 10 years before I discovered Eurogames. I don't ever feel the urge to play anymore, even though I still own quite a few cards and decks. When discussing Magic, there are multiple paths to go down.  

First is the deckbuilding aspect of it. Some of my favorite memories of this game are of creating a deck, testing it, tuning it, testing it again and refining it some more. Finding just the right mix of cards and combos was extremely enjoyable.

The second thing to discuss is the actual gameplay. The thing to understand about Magic is that the rules are really there to create a basic framework to support a wide variety of different game styles and approaches, but that framework is actually pretty simple. Simple isn't necessarily bad, but there isn't a whole lot there to recommend it over other games and there are some issues with it that are quite annoying to deal with. These include issues like land-based resources, summoning sickness, paying all resources up front, card timing issues, etc... You can see a lot of more modern games which pull ideas from Magic come up with ways around these annoyances (thinking specifically of Battletech, World of Warcraft, and even Decipher's Star Wars had a much more elegant resource system), and most work better as games for it. Most of the interesting elements to this game are the way that different cards play off of each other. Gameplay is largely determined by the way a particular deck is built. Thus, the quality of gameplay really varies depending on your ability to build a good deck, or the ability to go buy the cards for the current best decks on the internet. Building good decks CAN make this a pretty engaging game. 

Finally, you have to address the collectible nature of the game. As with many CCG's this is an extremely expensive game if you want to play well. There are other game systems that are self contained that play so much better than the lowest common denominator of Magic, and are substantially cheaper, too. Magic is a strangely addictive experience, but most of the attraction is finding the right combo of cards to make a deck play well. To get to that point, you may as well play a complete game that already plays well out of the box.

To me the most compelling parts of this game are collecting and deckbuilding. Since I don't do anything with those now, I'm left with just playing the decks of Magic I still own. Using BGG's recommended ratings, that leaves me right between a 4 and a 5, closer to a 5. Not a terrible game, but when stripped of the CCG-ness, it's less compelling than most of the games on my shelf, including several dead CCG's.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 7
good game despite being a ccg.

They only have a good idea every 2-3 years, but put out 4-ish expansions per year, so the hit rate is rather low.  But taken in aggregate there is a lot of good content there.

The biggest issue is the number of games that are won/lost by mana draws being too low/high.  I thus greatly prefer sets with guild mana and suspend, both of which serve to smooth out randomness of mana costs as well as making for actual choices during gameplay.

RATING: 9
Started playing in 1994 or '95, then stopped in 1997 and recently (2007) started again.  I enjoy creating decks from various cards and playing.  I don't like when people engineer decks and buy exactly what they need... I prefer the element of chance and the limitations of what cards are available.  Adds a level of creativity to creating decks and levels the playing field, so I prefer to play in draft tournaments.  The major drawback is the necessity to buy new cards, and the fact that new sets are created and old ones cycled out prevents most players from using old cards, though it does add some nice variety - it can get expensive.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Oh boy, here we go. This is one of the first games I ever got into and it pains me to this day how much money I spent (and could spend even now) on this game. Like a High School love that I still wanna take on a date, but has expensive taste and I know it would turn into a long term commitment I'd eventually break off again anyway.

Visual Appeal: (4)
The cards look great. With every new set that comes out, I am amazed by the coherence and creativity that goes into the original artwork. Cards are neatly organized and they set and industry standard for dueling card game layouts and zones. All of it works very nicely. I only wish there was more full-card art.

Components: (4)
Cards are fine. Most people sleeve them for play anyway. What about packaging? The game has gone through a lot of revisions on packaging. I think the intro deck format is fairly solid. I still think I like the theme decks from Invasion block and surrounding times better, but that might just be nostalgia talking. When I was a kid (read: pre-having-money-to-buy-cards-regularly) I was happy with a theme deck vs. theme deck battle. It is a CCG's business to be packaged in exclusive ways, and I understand that. I just wish you could go to a FNM constructed event and stand a snowball's chance without spending $100+. 

Theme: (5)
This game has influenced so much that has come after, and I think the best contribution was the 5 color balanced spectrum. It might be the most balanced example of asymmetry in any game that exists. It was a theme that begged you to choose sides, have a favorite, or even create your own deck personality. New mythologies are created every few sets with new mechanisms and characters to go with it. It seems like they won't run short on ideas very soon.

Learning: (3)
There is a lot to learn about the game because of it's long legacy. I think if you start with the basics it is not very intimidating. You can always learn different sets, keywords, game modes etc. as needed. It is a game where making your own deck is both the most helpful and yet most difficult thing to do well. Trial and error might be the best option. That, or copying someone else in their successful deck.

Gameplay: (4)
This is primarily a 2p game, so direct interaction is everything. Players are literally trying to bash each other to pieces. The first few turns are a bit uneventful, and that has recently bothered me. Other newer CCG/LCG have used different starting setups to make sure you are right in the action on turn 1. L5R for example has a stronghold and starting provinces to kick up the economy. Magic starts you with nothing. Once things get going though, players are constantly slinging spells and the action doesn't stop until only one is left standing.

Overall Fun: (4) 
This is still a fun game for me that I will play on OCTGN or with a friend's deck, but I will not sink any more money into CCGs. I am even hesitant about LCGs. Looking at the cost to fun ratio, this game is easily on par with my favorite tabletops that have come in 1 box and cost me $40. This game, because the fun is in the competition, pressures you to stay up to date and get the best decks and can cost you $40 twice a year. I applaud those people that can settle down with old sets or play pauper rules with only commons. I just think that neuters the game a bit. 
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 3
Sorry, just not a CCG person.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
This game is so broken. It makes you constantly spend money to stay competitive and interested. Some of the old cards are too powerful so they're discontinued, then new card concepts come along that your old decks can't cope with. The rules are constantly being updated, so cards made years apart have inconsistent effect descriptions. Eventually you will get into a huge argument over the order of effects or what exactly some ambiguous text on a card means. And there are so many out-of-control combos, including ways to get infinite mana, creatures or even turns. Does anyone do quality control over there? Richard Garfield should be fed to the Minion of Leshrac for inflicting this atrocity on the world. Unbelievable...
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

A truely original game concept, the cost is to high and it seems to need always new cards to keep the excitement.  I like the idea of a CCG but I don't know if you can build one that doesn't need constant new cards.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
If you consider the game aside from the CCG marketing aspect, it's excellent. The latest edition has been playtested to death in the field for over ten years, and there are plenty of tournament formats and drafts if you want to fine tune the balance even further. The deck customisation means that the game can be as complex as you or your group can handle... there's a lot of the pleasure of computer programming here, in terms of planning, algorithms, fall-through cases etc. There are a few clunky bits that prevent me from rating the game a ten -- mana screw and the timing rules being foremost among them -- but on the whole the game is very satisfying and incredibly replayable.If you would like to try it out without falling afoul of the collectible game problems, you can pick up common but playable cards en masse from eBay, or just buy a pair of preconstructed decks. 

Tradewise I am seeking:
- two Tiaga multilands (Revised) 
- a Thrull Champion (Fallen Empires)
- three Tinder Walls (Ice Age)
- three Birds of Paradise (any)
as well as anything else that would help out a red/green speed deck.

RATING: 8
Magic a ni plus ni moins que marqué de manière indélébile mon entrée dans le monde du jeu, de 1995 (4e édition/Ice Age) jusqu'à Tempête (1997). J'étais au collège. Je suis tombé dans un monde passionnant, mais aussi un monde de requins. C'est quelque part dommage, parce que le jeu est à la fois simple, ludique, riche et attractif, mais la « rareté organisée » par l'éditeur, le prix élevé des boosters, et surtout l'aspect compétitif exacerbé (en partie par l'âge moyen des joueurs) a quand même entaché cette expérience « magique ». J'ai d'ailleurs arrêté après avoir été témoin et victime de trop nombreux vols, arnaques, tricheries et tournois transformés en concours internationaux de mauvaise foi.

J'y ai rejoué quelques années plus tard, au cours d'évènements-tournois hebdomadaires où la bonne ambiance était de mise, avec des decks prêtés par d'anciens partenaires de jeu qui n'avaient pas décroché. Sans doute mes meilleures expériences de jeu.

Je rachèterai probablement un jour une boite de boosters d'un bon stand-alone ou de l'édition en cours pour pouvoir jouer en draft, afin de transformer ce jeu de cartes à collectionner en jeu de cartes tout court.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 6
Card game about a confrontation between wizards, so it is basicly one of hand management and "take that".  The main attraction of the game is its richness:  many cards available, many ways to play and a lot of combinations can be made to form a deck according to your tastes and personality.  It is not a bad game, but it is certainly not as good as the mass phenomenom that it has become.  It could be rated even better, but the aggresive merchandise politics around it keep it down.  Buying a product without knowing what you get and changing its rules and even nulifying some cards without any compensation is simply illegal.  I don't understand why consumer associations around the world haven't done anything yet about this.

RATING: 10

A simple 10 doesn't seem to do it justice.

RATING: 10
One of the greatest games ever, of all time. There's simply no game that has the same amount of flexibility in the game. If you want a tense and tight game, playing a game of legacy mtg is there; if you want something casual, pauper standard or any limited format is the thing. co-ops, semi co-ops and everything exists as well! 

I don't think any game gives me the same sort of creative thinking as this game does. climbing out of a stax-lock, powering through a solidarity/high-tide through a chalice for one, resolving a double opalescence and flashing in a humility in a 4 player free-for-all. man, this game is simply the greatest. 
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
One of my favourites.
The basic rules are quite simlpe, but there are cards that brake all of the rules, and once you learn the basics you realize that timing is of outmost importance.
New players should not be intimidated by the sheer number of cards, since all you have to do besides learn the basic rules is to read what each card says. You do not have to know them all.
In tournaments, there is a tendency of "most expensive deck winns", but there are some tournaments, like pre-releases, that gives all players the same conditions.
It is easy to get stuck in the Magic-swamp, and if you do, you will never have money to spare again. But nevermind that- you will have your cards!!
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 3
When this first hit the shelves, my friends and I were hooked!  As my friends and I are VERY competitive, it soon became a money sucking addiction trying to outdo each other.  Our addiction grew, collecting binders full of cards in different colors.  I remember buying full boxes of cards as soon as the new expansions came out, we would divide up the new packs, then we would sit in a circle opening them like it was Christmas!  Soon we would be buying singles from our local game store to strengthen decks and get an edge on our competition.  The sickness grew...

In time, I noticed that we would bicker and challenge each other about the rules regarding decks and card combos, ruining games.  I couldn't afford to keep up with some of my friends and pay rent at the same time.  As a result, I was always loosing, I couldn't compete, I lost the war of attrition.  Finally, after about a year, I began to hate this game for what it was turning us into, addicted, bickering, and broke.  I sold off my entire collection, cheap, to another friend who just started playing.  Poor guy, I warned him!  He soon was walking the same path I had...

Soon after, I dumped all of my collecting games in what I like to call the great collecting game purge, and swore never to go back.  I now play Magic but only on the XBox once in awhile.  It really isn't a bad game and it has all the things I love in a game, it's competitive, small, portable, strategic, and at times, fun. I just can't recommend this to any group that is VERY competitive and poor!  I still look back at this game as an ex-magic junkie trying to score a fix from their local supplier.  The euphoria of opening new card packets, looking at the artwork, counting the rare cards, then needing MORE!  Now days I check games for the need of collecting, and if that's a requirement, I quickly put it back.  That sour taste returns, the horror...  Never again!  EVER!!!  

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
OK, perhaps I shouldn't really give it a '9' as I hardly ever play it any more.  But bugger it I'm gonna give it a 9 anyway because.....

The original concept of this game was brilliant - the simplest game in the world as all the rules are on the cards themselves.  MtG invented a whole new genre of games and for the whole revolutionary concept this game probably deserves a 10.

A brilliant game which I sunk many many hours and probably just about as many dollars and I feel that MtG probably also has a lot to answer for my Uni degree taking longer that it ought.

Obvious imbalances in some cards (especially earlier in the piece) leading to the restriction on their use in the Official Tourney environment.  The biggest problem is though that this imbalance not only affected the sanctioned Tournament environment, but even to stay competitive within your own circle or down at your local games store, to a certain extent you still needed to have a base stock of the standard 'good' cards and needed to keep on buying and buying and buying.  These impbalances made some cards simply redundant.

Of course I understand why with CCG's the publishers need to keep bringing out new versions.  But ultimately it was this that led me to needing to get out cold-turkey due to the cash-cow that this game became and I got a little annoyed with each new addition leading inevitably to more and more inconsistencies and more and more exceptions to the rules or official rulings being required.

But this doesn't mean you can't pull out an assortment of old cards with some friends and have a great time.

Nothing quite like building a ridiculously themed deck which hardly ever works, but when you get the right combination of cards up boy oh boy is it sweet sweet sweet like honey.

The volume of cards keeps the possibilities endless.

A great game, a whole lot of fun and let's not forget the Sedge Troll, my mostest favouritest creature ever.  The stench in the hovel was overpowering....
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 9
Does anyone really 'own' Magic: The Gathering?

I play casual; usually commander, but sometimes 1V1, 2HG, Archenemy, and Emperor. I'm more interested in interesting decks that are fun to play and play against than succeeding against some kind of local metagame. Even my 60 card decks rarely have more than 2 of a card.

Playing against others with a similar mindset is a great time. 

I've done some FNM and drafts, but am not willing to do the studying ahead of time or $$ investment to be competitive.

RATING: 10
The original trading card game, and still the industry standard. 10,000+ different cards and still going strong; that's a testament to the soundness and openness of the original design. If you don't like the marketing model (buying boosters with random cards or expensive singles in a kind of arms race against other players), you can play it casually by just building a modest card pool and trying different deck ideas.

Extraordinary quality in artwork and concept.

RATING: 8

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
A fantastic game, my #1 for many years.  The basic mechanics are relatively easy to learn, although the intricacies of play can become overwhelming to a newcomer.  Fortunately, you can play MtG at many different levels of complexity and comfort, to suit your personal needs.  I love the deck-building aspect of the game, and especially enjoy putting together thematic decks that carry some strategic heft (e.g. Goblin deck).  I've never been competitive about it, and only rarely got obsessed about collecting 4 copies of certain powerful cards.  

I don't mind the collectible aspect, since I enjoy deck construction (using what you have) and I'm a big fan of the card art.  Of course, I've probably spent over a $1000 on my collection - although I've never been brave enough to figure it out.  Keep in mind though:  I've collected on and off for almost 20 years now, so that's not a bad investment, really, and I plan to pass along these cards to my kids or grandkids. I stopped collecting several years ago but wish I had someone to play every now and then.  I just won't do the Online thing, since I'd have to buy "virtual" cards all over again.

Issues?  Oh, it's got a few.  Mana-screw sucks.  Maybe 1 in 5 games will be intense and competitive and a real back-and-forth.  The other 4 will be either over quick or long drawn-out affairs.  Building and tweaking decks is more enjoyable than actually playing (at least for me).  And yet, given all that, a really fun game when it all comes together.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6.5
Variable rating from 4 to 9 depending on the players. A good game to start with if you want to play a ccg. I'm not entirely happy with some of the game design though. The mechanic of playing lands can screw over a player completely and suck the fun out of any game. The power creep in this game is still reasonable, but the difference in power between rarities can occasionally really upset people. All in all, a fine game to play with matched opponents.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 2
Played it from the end of high school and into my student years. A fun group of friends was soon exchanged with a tournament oriented scene, full of testosterone filled teenagers. After Tempest block went out (I started with Mirage) I gave up on constructed formats and have only played the game on sealed tournaments up to Odyssey (when I ran out of money and shifted to DnD).

Looking back on it - now, being older, I understand deck building better than I did then, and it totally doesn't interest me as it's too gamey. I much prefer games where I'm allowed to think on the spot and make decisions during the game, with some tactical options as well as strategic ones. In ye olde times we did have some more original illustrators. Anyhow, I hope I can get rid of the cards (baggage).  

And oh yeah, CCG format sucks. 

[i]Trade note: 6000+ low value cards, 1200+ lands, 300+ singles worth of notice (0,7 eur and up). Majority from Mirage and Tempest blocks, otherwise from Mirage up to Invasion, with some older singles. [/i]

RATING: 10
Don't blame a game for its marketing strategy.

Even with just a thousand common cards, which costs about $10.00, you can have many hours of casual enjoyment from different sorts of drafts, painful deck building decisions, and interesting gameplay. Games are short, too, about 5-20 minutes long, so you are never stuck.

RATING: 6

RATING: 9.5
Truly sickening to think how much money I dumped into this in the 90's. I lost interest when they accelerated their release schedule and expansions started coming out every three months.

This game suffers from "Build Order-itis", meaning any one can be a highly competitive opponent just by researching the latest deck build and dropping down $100 on cards. Ultimately this is what turned me off from the game. I still buy sealed packs and play with friends once or so per year though. The sealed and drafting environment is still quite fun.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9.5
I've been playing a lot of commander (EDH) and this format is a ton of fun, with crazy board-states and interactions, and really brings back the nostalgia of the games my friends and I played when we first got into the game in the mid-nineties. 

I highly recommend both the commander format, but also the planechase variant with adds a lot of crazy interactions.

RATING: 8
2006: Played Magic for years in high school and spent more money than I would like to admit on this "cardboard crack".  Recently returned to the game after a 10 year hiatus.  I enjoy the deck building aspect of the game the most, figuring out new combos and tuning things, but the game is terribly addictive and you will get bored of your deck after awhile and will need to spend more money to get interested in it again.  Enter with caution; if you have any obsessive tendencies, stay away.

2013 UPDATE: Me and my gaming group hit a lull a few expansions back, but in the past year we've fallen in love with the Commander/EDH format, and it's become the staple method of playing Magic these days, and I don't expect it to change in the future.  Regular Magic is great for dueling, but the dynamics, complexities and deck-building challenges provided in Commander/EDH has really invigorated the game for us.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
2012 Further update: I took the time to re-read my original review (below), and although I will leave it alone (since it reflects my views at a certain point in time), I do not feel it is very accurate any more. The average age of Magic players is higher now, and playing at a large game store in a large city is an excellent experience. We've met some great people playing Magic. The scene is just totally different now. There is a large Grand Prix competition somewhere on the planet pretty much every weekend, and the efforts WotC has made to professionalize the game are starting to pay off. Also, the number of women playing has gone up and seems to now be around 5%...sometimes as high as 10% depending on where/when you play. It *used* to be about 1%. Yes, it's a game that attracts nerds, but the Magic playing venues I have gone to in the past year have all been quite pleasant. Nice people with just as good, if not better, personal hygiene than the general population. This wasn't always the case, but I haven't needed to smear Vick's under my nose since returning to the game.

WotC R&D have gotten better and better at what they do, and the game is now a pleasure to play. The Commander format has appeared to give casual players a fun multiplayer variant in which all cards are legal, and there is a thriving competitive scene for both constructed and limited formats. Magic possesses the psychological complexity of Poker (perhaps even more) and while the strategic depth may not be as deep as Chess, I don't think a comparison there is too off-base. Before 2000, drafting may have existed in Magic, but it just wasn't a "thing". Now you can do a booster draft at Friday Night Magic, and that is an awesome thing, as it's an absolute blast to draft. I once read about a Japanese gentleman who, upon retirement, decided to devote his time to mastering Go. I love Go, but there just isn't a thriving player base in my region. Magic, however, seems to be growing. So I think I'll make that nameless fellow my role model, but strive to master Magic instead.

2012 Update: With the Innistrad Block, I confess that Magic is once again fun for me. I'm just playing sealed deck with Innistrad and now Dark Ascension cards, but the block works so well as a stand alone set. Way to go, Wizards. I don't think it would be much fun to blend the current block with my old cards, but playing completely within Innistrad is pretty awesome. There are many interesting synergies, and every game is exciting!

2008 Update: You know, after years of exposure to the best designer games out there, returning to playing Magic was an interesting experience. I'm struck by how much luck is involved in winning. I still like how interactive the game is, I love the theme, and I think the art and so on is fantastic. But playing in a sealed deck type environment, or with a random set of cards (how we usually play), winning just requires tremendous luck in addition to skill. I am less interested now in collecting cards or playing the meta-game. I just want to play the game, and the game is showing its age. For years, this was the only designer/complex game we played. Now, I'm much less enthused about playing Magic.

Magic is a great game. We started playing before the Ice Age expansion, and kept playing after Ice Age was released. Then we got irritated with the constructed deck environment and stopped playing for many years. Then, in 1998 or so, we started playing again, and acquired a large collection of cards. Then we got fed up again with the game...until we developed our own way to play it. I would rate the game an 7 the way it is (what with the expensive cards and economy), but I would rate the way we play it a 8, so I'm going to give it 8.

We pooled all our cards together, separated them by color, and randomized them into 10 card units. Each unit has about 5 creature cards, and 5 other cards. Lands are not included. Then we use a random number generator to choose a selection of these 10 card units, spend 20 minutes building decks, and then play several games. Then we replace the cards, and pull new random selections. For example: let's say I chose to make a black-only deck. The random number generator would choose 4-5 sets of 10 cards from the 35 black units available, and then I'd polish those cards into a deck (with as many lands as I like).

Is this a lot of work to go to to play this game? Initially, yes. Is it worth it? Absolutely. With our system, we are able to quickly build fun and interesting new decks to play with. And you never know what surprises your opponent has in store when she has cards from the initial release of the game all the way up to those released in 2000!

Magic was/is a revolutionary game (Garfield you genius you!) - it spawned a spate of collectible card games. CCG have their detractors. I am often one of them, mostly because of how companies price and market the games. There is also the player base (shudder). Mrs. Sifu and I participated in a few tournaments (she always placed better than I!), and it seemed that many players of the game were people who didn't really have that much fun playing it. Whatever satisfaction they derived came solely from "beating" another person - which (if you've been to a tournament) shouldn't come as a shock. Most players are teenage boys who look and act as if they aren't "winning" much in other of life's arenas. This is not a knock on the game or its players, just an observation or caveat regarding many of its fans. If you intend to play in a public venue, brace yourself for offensive odors and boorish behavior. If you're a woman, dress like you're an Anabaptist. If you are a reasonably attractive woman, wear a potato sack and a bag on your head...unless you *like* being mobbed by the stereotypical Magic player.

Even though the early (fun) environment of Magic where people actually anted cards is gone, the game remains an engaging, exciting, and richly thematic. If there were a good way to play it multiplayer, I would rate it a 9.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
I have not played it in a long time, although I still remember the experience as if it was yesterday. Spent a considerable amount of my later school years playing this.

It probably requires a network of at least a few people to trade cards with, in order to be truly enjoyable. However, it can also be played in a "draft" format, which does not require people to actually own cards.

The design is ingenious, it spawned an entirely new genre, and ultimately the now very successful "Dominion".

It does deserve a much higher rating than 7.1, and obviously a higher one than "Dominion".

RATING: 10

After you really get into it, 
It should have a rating of 10 for anyone who has the time, energy and money for it, everyone else should leave it for later :)

I put it on hold when writing this review but itll always remain a 10 game even if i wont play it again.

RATING: 1
Shame. Seems like an ok game but I refuse to support anything using this business model.

I'd rather pay a few hundred dollars for everything in a box than never see an end in sight.
But the biggest factor is the possibility that what you buy today may be useless when you compete a couple of years from now. Utterly ridiculous in my opinion!!!

Perhaps if they did different editions so we at least knew what we were rocking up to
"Want to play some M:TG 7th Edition?"
"Nah, but I'm up for some 3rd edition if you're keen"
"Ok!"
Then, at least, we'd know we were on an even playing field (assuming you could win with what's inside a base box and expansions would only be there for variety and replayability).

There are too many other excellent dueling mage games with great bases and fair expansions that will not rip you off for me to get into this.

RATING: 9.5
I really love this game, but unfortunately I'm a recovering addict, so I can only play it if I don't spend any money on it.  Way back when (ca. Legends-The Dark-Ice Age) I played the hell out of this, invested a couple of hundred to a couple of thousand dollars in it and had a great time playing.  Then I went off to school, I didn't have play opponents, so it fell out of favor and I sold off all of my cards.  A couple of years ago I found Magic: The Gathering Online, and the cycle began anew, and I spent another grand on "virtual" cards.  I then decided that I could not return to my cardboard crack addiction, sold off what I had.... and then I found BoardGameGeek, and proceeded to plow all of the money I had into buying other games.  But M:TG is still one of my first loves ... but as I keep telling myself, I can't spend money on it anymore.  These days, I still play some using the old Microprose M:TG computer game, which is nice because it's all cards from the time that I played and enjoyed M:TG the most.

-----

I'm back on the train looking for cards, but since I've resolved not to spend money on the game again, I'm looking to acquire via trades and GG purchases.  I'm especially interested in the cards from when I originally played, e.g. revised, 4th edition, the Dark, Ice Age, Legends, et al.  I also liked the Mirrodin block from my online foray.

RATING: 3
MtG is more of a hobby unto itself than a board game. Interesting, but I prefer games I only have to buy once. If you have infinite time and money, you might enjoy this one. Most of the decisions come at deck-building time, and these are severely constrained by what you can afford to buy--the player who spent the most usually wins. And what you're deciding isn't all that interesting, either. The main source of excitement is not knowing which cards the other guy has at his disposal.

Played this a lot in the 90's. But only with friends in a some what closed environment. never went to any tournaments or open game nights. Still, it was a LOT of fun.

Now a days i play it with my 9 year old son. I've bought som duel decks and some introdecks and it's still fun. But there are not a lot of compos and quite few of our matches are decided when one player doesn't get enough lands to be competitive or one player getting a card that is unstoppable. I would like the matches to be more tight.

Would really like to play a cube with 8 players sometime. But i would prefer that they were on the same  level as I am (the casual gamer level :))

RATING: 9

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
The good: Unbelievably addictive deck construction. So many different strategies in deck design. Thousands of cards to play around with. 

It's fun to come across a really cool card, plan a deck around it, search for just the right cards, put it all together, and then pit it against other decks. It does crazy things to my mind.

The bad: Specifically, mana. I have yet to play in a tournament where there aren't complaints against mana screw or mana flood. It's a real problem with this game.

How do you get around it? Build a screaming fast deck. And that's the biggest problem of them all. To be competitive, It's like MTG wants to force you into one strategy: speed. That nullifies 98% of the super cool combo cards. It takes the fun from the good things listed above. So, you just built an awesome deck around a cool combo and want to see it in action? Sorry, you must keep up with the mana ramp. You haven't won by turn four? Go play with the amateurs.

Furthermore, you haven't spent the big bucks to acquire the speedy lands and low mana overpowered cards? Forget about it.

Still, my high score just highlights how insanely awesome deck construction is. Also, there are different types of play from standard to modern, vintage, commander, and draft.

MTG still deserves a high score on many levels, but it's just so sad to ponder and tinker for hours and fully realize your creation will not have a chance against a carbon copy speed deck.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
I stopped collecting as the 9th edition was coming out and all of my cards were stolen. I have since picked up enough cards to field a red/green, blue/black, and black/artifact deck.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
Complexity: Medium-Hard
Players: 2+

Ah, Magic the Gathering. I'm sure I've spent more money than I should have on cards over the years.  The basic rules are relatively simple to grasp, but with so many expansions, it'd take a lifetime to master.  I realize there is a certain advantage conferred to players who invest more money (and time) into the game, so I've been trying to devise ways to make it more accessible to others.

I've recently completed building a cube, and after drafting with it, that's really all I ever want to do in Magic anymore, so (hopefully) that frees up a bit of my gaming budget for other pursuits.

RATING: 8
Peasant/pauper formats are where it's AT!

Update: For under $50 (including shipping), I netted complete common sets for Lorwyn, Morningtide, Shadowmoor, and Eventide. In eliminating the collectible aspect and balance issues between sets by purchasing a whole block's worth of cards to use as a common card pool for all players, I've fallen head over heels for Magic again. I like the Lorwyn/Shadowmoor block best, too, with its storybook fantasy setting and the tribal nature of the cards - you get Faerie decks, Goblins, Giants, Treefolk, Merfolk, Elves, Elementals, etc., so the theme even feels a lot more cohesive. 

By the way, my black Rogues deck will destroy you.

RATING: 9.666
I use to play this game. At night I'd dream of combos with boxes of cards under my bed. I'd wake and tweak the cards till the sun peaked it's head. From lock-downs to life-gains, to Moxes and Duels. I'd purchase every card that crept its way into my dream world. Through the combos and possibilities, I'd ponder for days. Un-moving. Yet in the mind, the chains were pulling, the mountains erupting. The islands and plains burning, till I felt Ingulfed by sledge and the swamps. I sank. Happily. But alas from a glint and a corner. There was a spark, a light. Bright, glowing, from a foil of white. An angelic hand reached out to mine. And from the sledge and darkness, I was pulled awake. 
And I will never go back. 
JDM
