RATING: 8.5
This would get a higher rating if I hadn't played collectable card games I like better than this, such as the Warcraft one. Still, this is an amazing, fun, highly diverse game with some of the best artwork you will ever see in any genre. The manna system is really where it breaks down for me though, as it is too luck dependent and therefore, frustrating. Many users knock this game for being collectable - but I really don't see the relevance of this critisism at this point. If you love it, but hate the collectable part, just make some fun, balanced decks from the seven million cheap cards available, and voila! You have an awesome living card game. 

One fantastic application of this game is to do the above idea - creating a non-collectable game from really cheap cards, and then give it as a gift to a young person who loves fantasy. I have done this, and believe me, it was very well received to say the least.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
Simply the best game I've ever played!
It's highly strategic since you're the one who decides which cards will be in your deck. Still very tactical, how to play these cards is very important as well.
There is still luck of the draw, but this counts for both players. With the amount of work that goes into building your deck, you're probably playing with this deck more than a few times and luck will even out a bit over the course of multiple plays.
It's also very balanced. There are 5 colors that play very different and these can be combined too, but still there is no colour stronger than the other.
It's got a high sense of achievement when a deck does exactly what you intended it to do. This game gave me some of the most satisfying wins. And losses, too. A mark of a great game! 
This game creates lasting memories; like the times I won a game with just three Goldenglow Moths or when I had over 380 zombies in play or when William had a life total of 272 playing his Vampire deck but still lost to my Felidar Souvereign. Most recently I lost a game when my opponent trampled me for a total of 1294 damage!
Card combinations are truly endless. By now, I've gog about twelve totally different playing decks, which is more variety than I need. I don't get to play each deck as much as I want to! Still, there's always the itch to keep working on each deck or even try and build something new from scratch.
I started around Zendikar block and Innistrad block is the first block I really invested in. Both the theme, feel and mechanics of both sets are much to my liking. Return to Ravnica is another hit, even while I wasn't around for the original Ravnica. The guilds truly are a wonderful accomplishment.

Green, Black and White are favorite colors. Red is alright and I don't really care for blue, but I'm starting to warm up to its play style, playing around with counter spells. Creatures are a better fit with my play style so I do like copy effects and stealing stuff. 
I'm a big fan of creature combat and favor an agressive playstyle over a more controlling approach. Isn't it fantastic how you can tailor the way you want to play?!
Seeing how much time I spend building decks, reading articles about it and actually playing the game: Magic: the Gathering ia absolutely, without a doubt in my mind, the best game ever!
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

Sure there can be games that are not fun (ever been mana hosed?), but if your willing to try again the fun will way outpace the bad.

RATING: 9
The original CCG and still the best. Or not, but after getting hooked on this one I'm not likely to pursue others very vigorously. I used to love both deck building and playing, but it does take a lot of time. Fortunately, you can still get in on Sealed Deck play easily (open cards, make decks, play) and there are preconstructed decks that allow you to play immediately. The constantly evolving game is both a plus (oooo! cool card!) and annoying (I WANT that card! ... Must resist!), but I'm past the have-to-have-everything phase.

A great game that you can (usually) play quickly.

Finally dropping my rating a bit, to a 9: I just never get to play this any more, and am now daunted by the sheer vastness of the card set and the time required to make interesting decks. I also find myself preferring multiplayer games more these days. Still, this is a fantastic game.

RATING: 6
The first game that really got me into competitive gaming. The option to make a unique deck was intriguing to me. I played mostly with my brother, dividing all the bought decks where I kept the "green and yellow", he kept "black and red" and we divided the blue ones. It was a very interesting game, but somehow we got into a lot of "unbalance" over time. The packs sometimes had rare cards to benefit just one of us and we just dropped the game. Not to mention CCG is a bit costy hobby. But for what it's worth, it got me really into gaming, even though I wouldn't play it anymore. I don't like luck much in games and it comes doubly with CCGs.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
This is an awesome, infinitely replayable game, with a couple of caveats.  You do have to have opponents with access to the same cards or things are really unbalanced and not fun.  It is expensive if you want to stay competitive in the tournament environment; however, that is not necessary to enjoy the game.  

The things that are great about this game are the infinite variety of strategies, combos, and synergies; the fun of putting together a deck and seeing how it plays against other decks of different types.  

I used to play this somewhat competitively, but now I mostly play at home with my two boys (8 and 5).  I think it is even helping the younger one with his math and reading skills.

If you don't want to spend a ton of money, I suggest buying a bunch of commons on eBay or from your local store.  If you don't care about the deck building, there are a lot of fun preconstructed sets.  I recommend Garruk vs. Liliana, Elspeth vs. Tezzeret, or Phyrexia vs. the Coalition.  You can also find some older precon decks from retailers like Troll and Toad for five bucks or less.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: N/A
I first started playing Magic around the release of Tempest and it instantly had a stranglehold on me.  I had an uncle and a few other friends who gifted me some of the older cards and I spent every bit of money I made in middle school to buy more packs at the local comic store.

Unfortunately that trend continued until I was an adult and discovered eBay.  I was competitive for a number of years and had some respectable finishes in local and state tournaments but the cost and time investment was just too much.  I've stopped and started again several times since (the first time I sold off all my cards I bought my wife's engagement ring with the profits).

I'm stopped for good now (I think) but I will still do an occasional booster draft.  The game is incredible, best CCG ever created and probably ever will be.  The system is so deep, elegant, and fun.  The only limit to variety in the game is your wallet and social calendar.  I won't give it a rating though because I have not played in almost 3 years (I stopped for the final time around Rise of the Eldrazi's release) and the game is always changing and evolving so today the game is likely very different than it was the last time I played.

RATING: 2
To be fair, I'm not a big fan of CCGs.  Having said that, I was in college when this came out, in San Francisco, surrounded by fanatical MTG gamers who would twitch and speak in tongues at the mere hint that they might be able to obtain a missing Lotus or Mox card, many of whom were close friends of mine that I wanted to spend time with.  I tried to enjoy playing.  I couldn't.  I can't.  The very thought of playing MTG makes my brain feel like it's packed in gauze, and that's before I even contemplate the grotesque "limited edition" moneygrubbing that Wizards of the Coast engaged in by virtue of their control over both production and the rules.  Roger Ebert's review of "North" is right on the money here: "I hated this [game]. Hated hated hated hated hated this [game]. Hated it. Hated every simpering stupid vacant audience-insulting moment of it."  [I'm giving this a "2" instead of a "1" because it is not "clearly broken," although it is undeniably true that "You won't catch me dead playing this.]

RATING: 9

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Planechase is a great multiplayer variant of MtG (Magic: The Gathering) with four Wizards of the Coast constructed decks that are balanced for multiplayer, each assigned a distinct theme.  Each deck also has 10 plane cards.  These cards are new to MtG and have a random effect on the game state that usually impacts all players.

This is a cheap, pauper is still the cheapest, way to play MtG with friends.  It is a lower revenue product for Wizards of the Coast, and therefore does not receive regular expansions (none since 2009) like their core game, which is unfortunate.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

An overly bloated but very fun game

RATING: 3
It's just boring and complex to me.  I will not discount that it is a very good TCG, but I find the combat mechanics highly annoying.  Why does the defender get to assign blockers?  This makes it so that I often don't know when I should press my attack in the game and often end up losing.

Although I think Yu-Gi-Oh is a worse game, I am better at it and actually like it more because in that game attacks make more sense.  The attacker gets to select his targets.  I just cannot fathom how or WHY the defender would get to assign targets unless the creatures in the game are just so stupid as to only attack creatures who say, "Durr hurr, I'm blocking you!"

The fact that this game requires a heavy investment to even remain competitive gets me, too.  I have only played it with borrowed decks since I dislike the deckbuilding element.  Can be decent with a good deck, but you're always at a disadvantage because your opponent knows what to expect from his own deck, so it's a two-edged sword.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
Play modern format mostly.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
Very popular game.. I think it miss something in this game

RATING: 6
The M10 rule changes suck the fun and opportunities for clever play out of this game. I very much doubt I'll be playing this much in the future.
----------------------
I'm seriously annoyed with Wizard's decision to add Mythic rares. Combined with the terrible implementation of MTGO v3, I'm pretty much off magic. Which is a shame as I've enjoyed the game a lot in the past.
----------------------

If I had to pick only one game for the rest of my life, this would be it. While buying more all the time can suck, you can get by on the cheap and still have lots of fun.I've been playing since '94, still very enjoyable. Deck building can be as much fun as actually playing. I like seeing new cards and don't have any resentment towards Wizards about all the new releases.

Game play is very diverse. Between two decks many games will play out differently. Add in the fact that there are thousands of different deck possibilities and I can't think of another game that can match. Also the various formats, some of which place restricts on deck building, others add various special abilities (ala Vanguard) or seating arrangements (ex Color Wars or Emperor), can keep this interesting for years.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8.5
Nice game that I like to play from time to time.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Ppl tend to forget that it's just a game
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
The best game of all time?  Yes.  I can understand why people don't like buying new cards all the time, but the constant evolution of the game through new expansions is what I like most about it.

The designers do an incredible job keeping the game fresh by exploring new angles with each block.  The rules are complex but elegant.  The balance and variety of different deck types and strategies is very good.  Anybody who quit years ago has no idea what they're missing.

RATING: 10
My last game of Magic is now more than 10 years ago. But from 1994-2001, I played this game excessively and had a tremendous amount of fun with it. I've never played this competitively (only participated in a few prerealese tournaments), buth the increased competitiveness and the ever increasing amount of cards did suck out part of the charm and fun for me.

Still have those thousands of cars lying around somewhere, but it's hard to imagine really picking it up again. The real game is in the deckbuilding and with a job, family and other responsibilites, there's no way I could do that even half-serious now.

And yet, it itches, and I *would* like to play with my old cards occasionally again. The game really is quite good.

RATING: 7
The mother of all collectible card games.

Magic is a bit like Madonna. Reinvented a million times, and somehow still churning out hits.

Many people I know have played Magic at some point, drifted out of it, then been pulled back in again to discover a fresh version of the game they loved all those years ago.

Interesting variants like Commander have also helped reinvigorate it.

And no discussion of Magic would be complete without some appreciation for the artwork. It is the gold standard, not just for card games, but for fantasy artwork in any medium.

RATING: 6.5
Here's the quandary: I enjoy Magic a decent amount.  But I don't enjoy the parts of it that come with it being a CCG--the giant metagame of building the tiniest, most efficient killing machine of a deck ("Aha, and I now cast an infinite-damage Fireball while simultaneously gaining infinite life!"), which depends on having decently large resources of time and money in order to do so properly.  I think Magic is a fine game with some basic starter decks or a friendly draft from a common pool, but anything else is just getting too elitist and crappy for me.

RATING: 10
A great game that offers much more than just the collection hype that puts many people off.

I am sure if it weren't for the excellent gameplay value, the game would never have taken off in the first place - as is also proven by the many failures to copy Magic's success.

I started playing in February 1994, played some time on the Pro Tour from 1996 to 2001 (including participation at three world championships) and stopped in 2003, because I could just not invest as much time into this game anymore as it deserves.

Nowadays doing a draft on Magic Online once in a while.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Haven't played this a lot (yet) nor a lot of other CCGs (yet) but so far this some seems to have earned its popularity:  The deck building is fun not tedious, the game presents interesting choices, and the game plays fast enough that you can play best of two out of three in around an hour.  That's casual play, of course :)  But that is another reason for the game's popularity: you can play this on so many levels and with any size card collection you can afford.  Most CCGs die off at some point and they should take a cue from Magic regarding starter and theme decks (I have yet to see another game with ready-to-go theme decks that are not only interesting to play, but in fact are very playable).  Right now, I'm only making Casual Constructed decks (4 rares and 8 uncommons maximum including the sideboard) for use in some multiplayer games I'd like to try with my group (Free For All, Two-Headed Giant).  

A lot of the artwork is phenomenal.  Not sure what all the fuss is about with the "mana screw" since you get to build you deck -- just add more land and add more low-cost cards.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
Many hours of childhood joy came from this legendary game. Plus, you can bet I haven't fired off my last lightning bolt. I've returned before and I'll return again.

RATING: 10
Almost impossible for me to rate.  I have played it more than any other game, except maybe poker, but would always prefer to play other top games over it.  I love playing, but hate how much time I can spend on this game - not to mention money.  I think tournament play takes away your ability to enjoy this on a casual basis, but I am also skeptical about whether or not you can even be a casual player with so many cards, rules, changes, etc.  

All that said, there is no two player game I would rather play and no game I enjoy playing over and over as much.  The sheer variety to it is amazing.

RATING: 9
My rating is based on an unofficial rules variant I enjoy because it "fixes" some aspects of the game I don't enjoy. (Land flood/land screw, deck construction). All in all, this is, arguably, one of the greatest tableau/engine building and hand management games ever made. The sheer volume of viable strategies which have emerged over the last two and a half decades is staggering. The rules can be complex, the time and money investment can be large, but there are also ways to play which circumvent those issues. 

I started playing M:tG in '95 and have dabbled in many different formats over the years. Several times I have put the game down entirely for years on end, only to pick it up again when my interest rekindled. It's great that there are so many ways to play M:tG. If there's an aspect of the game you don't like, chances are there's a rules variant out there that will "fix it" for you - not to mention - others who like to play that way, too.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
Where has all my money gone ...

RATING: 8.5

The game stopped being fun when it became clear that hyper-tuned decks with fantastically expensive cards started to dominate every meet. Tournament rules regulating card generations may have moderated the problem, but it’s too late for me. I’ve still got binders full of cards and occasionally draft decks for fun, but I generally won’t play unless I know my opponents are casual players as well. The high rating is because it was a brilliant game and I got years of play out of it.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Magic is one of the best designed, developed and produced CCGs, ever. Unfortunately, the depth of gameplay comes mostly from deck construction and matchup, while playing the game itself is often (but not always) mechanical. 

Magic's greatest asset is its huge library of cards. However, the source of this variety - CCG economics - is also the source of Magic's greatest weakness. Not only is it be expensive, it is often hard to find players who are playing the same format that you are, and nearly impossible to match power levels between two players' decks. 

Recommended way to play: Find somewhere that sells playsets of all the commons in a set, then play casual sealed/draft with that. It will be cheap and fun, and lacking the horror involved in collection and construction. 
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 8
One of the best games of all time. It's only a big money pit so NEVER EVER get suckered into playing tournaments or keeping your deck 1.0 or 1.5 compliant. 

I think every Magic player will recognize the experience of building up your deck, becoming REALLY good in it, and just when you hit the top -BAM! A new edition comes out and everybody starts whining about 'banned/uncompliant/restricted' cards in your deck, forcing you to spend money and time to redesign it and just when it's about good, it happens again. BYE BYE Richard Garfield, I'll stick to what I have.

Just getting into it? One tip: shell out $100,- for a BIG buttload of commons + land and just play boosterdraft with your friends. You'll get all of the gameplay for a fraction of the cost and it'll keep fresh every time. And if you don't like it anymore you can always sell them with minimal loss of cash.

[EDIT] Never play this anymore as so many other games come around. Collection is too valuable to just 'dump it' and have too many cards to be able to find the time to sort them out. So they basically just remain in their box with their sleeves collecting dust. A while ago I tried to have a quick look at just the best Rares and Uncommon ones on a USA website buying this stuff and easily made >€500 bucks for my collection of 4000+ (mainly) Fourth edition cards (add in some Unlimited/Revised/Legends and a bunch of Dual Lands and Force of Wills as well). Sigh.

RATING: 9

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
It's extremely fun in a one-on-one setting. I love the card art and the gameplay mechanics, though the strategy comes into play almost entirely in the deck-building and preparation. Much of actual gameplay can feel overly deterministic, if still enjoyable. Against the wrong opponent, though, it can begin to feel too dependent on having the strongest cards, or the luckiest draw. I think it's best played regularly against a small number of opponents who don't always need to have the newest and most powerful cards. Blightsteel Golem (indestructible, knocks down half of standard life-points, and damages over time) for example is utterly uninteresting and can ruin an otherwise entertaining duel.

Compared to other CCGs I've played, Magic  maintains quality of cards, art, and balance quite well over time.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Objectively speaking a great game design, but what killed the game for me in later years is the ways WOTC designed the game to make people keep buying cards instead of relying on your old deck which in my case has grown completely redundant compared to newer, much stronger cards.
The deck building can be very heavy, and once you play against people who build their decks towards one really nasty killer strategy (that they probably found online), it just kills the fun for me.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
I'll start by saying that I very much enjoy Magic. HOWEVER, I cannot recommend the game to anyone for a simple reason: its business model. In a nutshell, the best and worst part of Magic is that it is designed to be systematically unbalanced -- nearly every card in the game has at least a handful of other cards that can be better than it. While this sounds great and some people would argue that this setup actually makes the game balanced, you have no way of guaranteeing that you'll have those cards unless you're willing to pay a lot of money. 

At the end of the day, you can get the same experience from "balanced" Magic at a fraction of the cost with any of the modern LCG/ECG card games (Any of the FFG LCGs, Doomtown, VS System, Ashes, Mage Wars Academy, etc.).
While there is a part of me that hopes that MtG will one day reestablish itself as an LCG/ECG/XCG, there are more than enough good (perhaps better) deck construction battling cards games that I don't think you'll miss Magic.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 5.9
I'm told that the real highlight of the game is tournament play, where you build your deck, play a round and then tweak it over the next two rounds.

I can see that, but I'm never going to play this game that frequently.

As a game itself, the beginner deck I used seemed very much to play itself and all my usual bug-bears were here: tiny icons (thankfully colour-coded) and tiny text that is upside down and across a table from me that I need to be constantly aware of, horrifically cliché artwork that takes up so much of the card that should be explaining to me what the card actually does, random terms that some cards have that impact things (Oh, God, I'm getting flashbacks to Blood Bowl)...

The interesting part seems to overwhelmingly be the part where you're not actually playing the game...

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: N/A
This famous TCG is not comparable to other games here.
Also, it is more of a family of games than a single game, because there are many deck formats and things you can do with the cards. You can even build own games/formats!

+ high quality game design
+ game theme and card tropes
+ great fantasy artworks(!)
+ elegant game mechanics
- games are often decided by mana shortage or mana flooding even without the opponent(s) interfering
- pay to win
- can be extremely expensive
- addictive in a unhealthy way

It is astonishing how much MTG is _both_ luck-dependent and skill-intensive at the same time. In competitive play it is not only luck-dependent what cards you draw, but also the dice roll at start of the match and against who (deck type, player) you're paired. But you always need to have a deep knowledge of all the cards, the mechanics, the rules, the meta game, your deck and more. And practice is also important. Despite the high luck-dependence skilled players have a significantly higher win percentage, even though they might loose against a newbie every now and then.


The community is very hype-driven, which I dislike. And the card hoarding and financial speculators are close to ruining the game. Also, WotC is flooding out new product in a pace where it becomes impossible to keep up.

Although the overall print quality is quite good, there are often cards that are off-center cut, which can be very annoying considering the high prices one pays for the cards.
And also, sleeving the cards, which is really necessary, quickly becomes expensive and tedious.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

Please shoot me now. Why did I start collecting this?  Oh, yeah I get to play it with a younger friend at work (who only has cards from the old sets).

RATING: 6.7
I wasted so much money on this in my youth but I respect their new "Prebuilt" deck concept.  It's grown up from the cash cow it once was.  That said, I haven't had any real ability to try it out in its modern form.  So these statements do not reflect my rating that much.  It did start the entire CCG industry and that stands for something.  My original rating stands for my feelings when I quit the game years ago.

Addendum: So I've tried the game recently with Dimir Intrigues (Ravnica) against Life Boost (Core set).  Appreciate the new decks constructions and theme, granted the smaller lifeboost deck destroyed the larger Dimir deck (Which oddly seems to be slanted towards burning through your opponents library.)  I wonder if sets are balanced within themselves.  While half the fun of magic was building decks I always longed as a young lad to have decks that were strong with theme rather then mechanic.  I tried time and time again to have a workable "angel and demon" deck, "Insects" deck and "Gryphon/Dragon" deck, all to fail to lack of mechanic/combos.  I do really enjoy the new theme heavy decks as starting points and have a renewed interest in the game now after just 3 plays.  Rating goes up for it being a cheap, simple yet strategic 2 plus player game with lots of options.

RATING: 6

Overall, I LOVE the mechanics of play, I hate the rip-off prices.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
Legendary game...  Only thing against it is the collectable aspect.

Used to build decks and play friends alot back in the day. (loved my grind, and flying creatures decks)

Cant be bothered with deck building now.. 

I have a fairly large amount of old cards.

We use a variant.  Its a great variant if you have a stack of old magic cards but dont deckbuild and want to still play it.  Not sure if this variant already exists but I have dubbed it "Wild Magic"

Each player has a deck of 50 non land cards (we just blindly grab 50 cards each out of my pile of cards.) 

There is a communal land deck (You decide distribution. We include the non basic land cards to mix it up a bit)

We then draw 7 cards, each draw can be from the land pile or standard pile. Play as normal. Very random, a flyer or landwalker can just win you the game, but games are normally fast and fun.  You just dont know what will appear. 

You will have to remove cards from the game that draw land cards out of your deck though as in this variant lands are not in your deck. 

Great fun, still a brilliant design, still playable like this in a casual format, simple and elegant.  A classic.

RATING: 9

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Magic is a very good card game. I played it intensely for two years in high school. I obsessed over deck-building strategies, and pined for certain rare cards. I still enjoy the game, but don't spend any time building decks (a shame). What I enjoyed most about Magic when compared with modern deck-building games like Dominion, is that I had the chance to customize my cards to work together before playing, as opposed to trying for the same effect on the fly. Magic emphasized skillful card play and deck building, as opposed to just deck building.

It's still a classic, and one I'll usually play when requested. Although nowadays, I typically reach for the excellent duel decks, which give me all the feel of Magic with almost none of the upfront effort. In fact, if all you purchased were a few duel deck packs, I think you'd have a top notch game, well worthy the price of entry, and with enough strategy to keep you busy for many, many hours. What keeps people away, I assume, is the reputation the game has for costing a bundle, both in time and money. It's a shame because the game itself is still solid.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
I love Magic.  I have played Magic on average more than once a month since 1997, and still love to play.  That is virtually unheard of for a game.  Magic gets a lot of negative comments because of its collectable nature and the perceived wackiness of the tournament players, but underneath all that it really is an amazing game.  It has a fantastic amount of depth, from deck building right down to which land to tap for mana.  Over the years, we have played in tournaments (pre-releases mostly), Standard (which uses only the most recent cards), Extended (which uses a huge pool of cards), Type One (which uses a huge huge pool of cards), Rochester Draft, Booster Draft, and Sealed Deck.  And we've played all those formats in two-player (duel) format, and in multi-player.  All are different from each other, all are amazing.  Magic is an incredibly flexible, deep, smart game.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 8.5
Cardboard crack.  I don't even want to think about how much money I blew on this but it is a great game that has aged quite well and offers something to both beginners and masters. =-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9.8
There is not much I can say that hasn't already been said by many in the hobby that have left Magic behind. Like those people, I still sit in awe. Magic is both exalted and ruined by it's collectible nature; it adds a rich dimension to it's meta game, but also makes it terribly expensive and unbalanced. Tournament play fixes this, but limits you to a highly competitive scene, which is still terribly expensive. Drafting fixes that problem to a degree, but can render your cards useless after one play. But it is still so, so much fun.

Trying to construct the most efficient deck amongst a combination of cleverly designed cards and abilities with even more cleverly conceived combinations is part of the draw to Magic for me, as well as the large pool of possible cards and options. It is a world waiting to be explored. I may have exhausted myself of much of the Magic 'scene', but I still adore and admire the game and Modern and draft will always have a special place in my heart. 
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 8
I've played this game on and off for almost twenty years and I've got to say that for the most part I love it. It has its ups and downs because of the sets not always being good but it's just not possible to sustain greatness at a high level for an indefinite amount of time in the gaming industry. Sometimes you're going to whiff. I love playing in the limited formats much more than constructed. The biggest (and maybe only) drawback to this game is simply the time and money commitment. If you want to be successful in tournaments you have to take it more seriously than "just a game" which can burn you out on it if you allow the enjoyment to be robbed from you through this process.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7.5
I have an immense amount of respect for Magic -- I think it's a solid design, and it deserves mountains of credit for sparking a new renaissance in gaming.  This game defines a large portion of my youth, and the memories it evokes for me are -- dare I say it? -- truly magical.  In those days before the ubiquity of the internet, the experience of opening a pack and seeing something new or playing someone and encountering a crazy combo was as close as I'll ever get to exploring another dimension.

That said, I've lost interest over the years.  The underlying game is still solid, but I think the overall design has become bloated with keywords and gimmicks.  Everything has gotten so attractively slick and focused on the tournament/FNM scene.  And a slow but steady power creep has rendered many of my old cards obsolete -- cards exist now that do the exact same thing at a fraction of the cost, and it irks me.

Though I have several friends who are still enthusiasts, I'm more or less done buying cards.  There are a lot of great ways to enjoy the game, including cube drafts and Pauper formats, that don't involve adopting the whole MtG lifestyle, so I still think it's a game worth playing.  But I'm no longer interested in collecting.  

Willing to entertain trades -- I have about ten thousand cards ranging from Revised edition to the present day, more or less.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 3
Read most of the comments of people who rated this a 1. Most of them share my reasoning for giving this a low rating. This is a shameless money grab of a game which rewards having money over having skill. Will never play again with a serious player unless they have a spare deck as I will not spend hundreds of dollars on this game. There is a good chance I won't play again at all though, as I think there are better games to play and things to do. I haven't played in years as is.
Past experiences have certainly soured me on this game as well, as many of the players devote large sums of money from each paycheck so to get expensive cards and be able to defeat and feel superior to their friends and other people. Many even resort to cheating. I have probably had some particularly bad luck with the regulars of this game, but many ccg's will attract this type of person.
Taking away the atrocious behavior of Magic players I've dealt with in the past, and taking away the unfair 'he with the most money wins' element, and ignoring the fact that people have spent ridiculous amounts of money on this game in an attempt to keep up with others or chase rare cards or make others feel inferior, I will say a few other things about the game. The art on the front of the cards is decent, the card quality is pathetically bad (but if it were good they wouldn't have as much reason to charge you extra for those protectors, right?), the game has helped keep hobby shops alive because of how much people spend on it, it has helped bring people together because of its popularity (although I've also heard of many fights and lost friendships over the game as well), the mechanics of the game itself were relatively simple from what I can remember, and I myself was never blown away by it. 
Honestly, ignoring everything but the gameplay, I would still say that there are many better games out there to devote your time and money to.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 6
I played MTG from Weatherlight until just before Urza's Saga. Originally, I felt the game was an excellent idea: two wizards dueling each-other with customized spell books. The game began to shift directions, however, and became more focused on people fighting each-other with the two player's in more of a god-like position.

I didn't care for the changes, but enjoyed the time I played.

RATING: 10
[b]Possibility Space Landscape (Exploration=Fun)[/b]
:star::star::star::nostar::nostar: Challenge (Depth) Fun derived from analyzing and predicting the optimal path to take through the possibility space landscape.
:star::star::star::star::star: Variety (Width) Fun derived from trying out a large variety of meaningful paths through the possibility space landscape.
:star::star::star::star::nostar: Atmosphere (Height) Fun derived from the experience or anticipation of encounters along a path through the possibility space landscape.

[b]Gaming Skills Employed[/b]
:star::star::nostar::nostar::nostar: Analysis
:star::star::star::star::star: Tactics
:star::star::star::star::star: Strategy
:star::nostar::nostar::nostar::nostar: Direct Player Manipulation (Diplomacy)
:star::nostar::nostar::nostar::nostar: Indirect Player Manipulation (Bluffing)
:star::star::nostar::nostar::nostar: Player Reading/Prediction
:star::star::star::nostar::nostar: Luck

[b]Misc.[/b]
:star::star::star::star::nostar: Theme Integration
:star::star::star::star::nostar: Rules Complexity
:nostar::nostar::nostar::nostar::nostar: Bookkeeping
:nostar::nostar::nostar::nostar::nostar: Downtime
:star::star::nostar::nostar::nostar: Scalability

[b]Presentation[/b]
:star::star::star::star::nostar: Components
:star::star::star::star::star: Artwork
:star::star::star::nostar::nostar: Rules

[b]Comments[/b]
This is a game that only truely shines if you are insane enough to sink a vast fortune into it...

If I had just a single pair of decent decks to play with for all eternity, I'd rate this game a 6.  (Cost $50-$100)

If I had a small collection of well tuned decks to choose from, I'd rate this game an 8.  (Cost $500-$1000)

My 10 rating only applies if you have a card library large enough to make deck design interesting, you have opponents with access to the same or a similarly extensive library, and both opponents know the cards and libraries well enough to produce solid/unique deck strategies. (Cost $5000+)

I have played this countless times in the past, but I have not played for a few years due to a lack of opponents.  Finding players with the time and passion to study a card library is not easy.  I'll play this game at any opportunity.  That day probably won't come soon, unless I can get one of my kids interested enough to devote their energy to learning the art of deck building.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9

Magic is doomed by it's own success and need for future success.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 1
Yes, Magic. Yes, that low of a rating. Why? Because it's just not that good. Really, it isn't. Yes, it was first. Yes, it sucked me in too. But as I began to play, I started to notice things. Rules. Terms. Styles. 
It's just not a well-made game. The rules have changed so much that no one remembers what "Mono Artifact" means, nor an "Interrupt."
And it's still a broken game.

Many more CCG's have come since this one. A lot were crap, but some were good and a few great. Many of those beat the tar out of Magic with good rules, well structured play and great mechanics. But, since they weren't first, they died or didn't make nearly the same success.
If you like CCG's, try something else. I can name a bunch right now:
Warlord, Game of Thrones, Legend of the Five Rings and more.

Don't be suckered!

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
I got really into Magic as a pre-teen and wish I hadn't traded all my cards back then. I know, I'm utterly unique in that regard.

Anyway, coming back to the game--it's such an incredible game. I am not someone who wants to play the same game over and over, but Magic has such great (infinite?) replay value that it does lend itself to that.

However, I'm not enough of a competitive player to really stand toe-to-toe with people who are really deep into the game to where they deck-build and already know many, if not most, of the cards by heart and have mental logs of scores of devastating card-combinations. If I had more time, I'd invest more of myself into studying the game in that way and playing more often, but right now I'm at a place where I really just like to play the occasional casual game or two and drawing cards that I've never seen before and trying to play them well on the spot in the context of a given game. Plus... the whole collectible aspect is something that no longer appeals to me (such a time and money sink).

But, I feel confident in saying this is easily one of the greatest and most innovative games of modern history.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Miss Rhodes Says: In this card game each player is a wizard and must try to destroy the other players by using a combination of enchantments and attacks with creatures that are under the wizard's control.  Each wizard takes his power from the land.  This game is a tactical one, and requires each player to work out how he can attack his opponent whilst defending himself.  This game becomes much more enjoyable once you have grasped the basics and is really good fun.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
If you can invest the ongoing attention and energy towards this, it's probably the greatest card game I've ever played.  I've played Magic on and off since 1994 and it is always interesting and exciting.  As for those who find it a money sink, it certainly can be if you don't set boundaries.  But playing casual or eternal formats and spending about $50 each year (less than keeping up with Dominion) you can stay pretty up to date and have fun.
Planescape is worth checking out too as a singular purchase to experience Chaos Magic.

RATING: 5
a ccg nálam inkább a vampire-ben merült ki
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
PROS: •One of the best card game systems ever created. I am over and over again impressed by the quality of the ruleset. Magic has grown to become a huge universe but still it manages to be consistent. It followed me throughout my youth and my interest in the game went through some waves, but I always admired it as one of the best card game systems ever created; • With an ever-growing range of cards abilities, replay value is monstrous; • Every card has a cool unique art (or several, depending on the set) and design - except the really old stuff; • Very strategic gameplay despise the luck-of-the-draw effect: several levels of strategy include deck building, reading you opponents, timing your choices, calculating battle outcomes beforehand and so on.

CONS: •Magic grew to become a game with both hardcore and casual fanbases. If you want to play the most common format of Magic, "constructed", be ready to read a lot, copy a lot of already thought decks, search through endless databases of cards and most important: Spend a TON of money. The CCG aspect made me give up on this game mora than once. •Balance issues: The most common way to play Magic is against a friend that also has Magic. So it's not a game that you open a box, split the components and play a balanced match with your friends. Decks will be worse than others despise the skill factor, tweaking will be constant and necessary. And expensive. If there were no alternatives to this, I would never come back to this game. Read more about it on the Conclusion below. •The luck aspect can kill your match (if you only draw lands / no lands at all) and, being limited to 1 draw per turn, sometimes in mid-late game you depend on what you draw. Draw a land and... improve your board 0%. Draw that powerhouse and the match is yours. Luck.

CONCLUSION: If you love the game system but hate the collectible aspect, i.e. you wanna play it as a casual game, grab some pre-made Duel Decks (these come in pairs and are THEORETICALLY balanced) and/or assemble a Pauper Cube (google how to do it), which is a collection of common cards specially balanced to draft with your friends. You build your decks on the go and play. I do it this way and now the game fits my budget and my interests as a casual gamer.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
People rag on this game largely because of the money-sink factor. I won't say that factor isn't there, because it is -- you can easily spend lots of $ on the game. But first, about the game itself: It is very intricate and has lots of depth of gameplay, both in deckbuilding and the actual play of the game. There are many, many effects that the cards have, and the interactivity is extreme. With the sheer number of cards, even in a base set, the replayability factor is sky-high; add cards from the ever-releasing expansion sets and it is higher than any other non-RPG I know of. If you're willing to abide by limits on cardpool, you and a group of friends can easily play hundreds of hours off, say, $50 worth of cards.  

Okay, that said, about the money factor: You can easily get sucked in and need to buy 'just one more booster (or worse, booster box)', or find yourself paying $20 (or more!) for a 3x5 cardboard piece that is 'just the right card for your deck'. If you have this sort of addictive personality, even if you would otherwise love it, run away unless you can afford to (and are willing to) spend hundreds of dollars every year on Magic cards. You'll love it every instant, but you'll end up broke. Wizards of the Coast wants you as a customer, and they will keep releasing expansions for you (yes, you) to buy.

On the flip side, Wizards has been careful (particularly recently) to make sure that rare does not always equal better, so if you equalize the 'money factor', by playing Limited formats (check out Winston draft to reuse cards) it can work very well. (N.B. rare seems to equal better mainly, I think, because the rare cards are usually narrower and therefore better than anything else at that narrow job, so if you need that effect, you want the rare. But rares in general aren't more useful overall than commons).

There is an online magic server run by Wizards where you can play preconstructed decks for free, and play other decks with 'digital cards' (which you do have to buy, natch, though access to the server per se is free). The server does an excellent job of enforcing the rules and I recommend it to people who can safely come into contact with the highly addictive substance that is Magic.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 9
I have a big soft spot for this one.  I still have 1000s of cards, but don't play.  I love the artwork, the concept, the themes, the collection aspect with cards and folders and boxes, the surprise of finding a cool card when you open a new pack, the amount of fun you can have just with a few cards a dice and a friend, the ability to build new decks that completely change the game, the tournaments, the sealed deck games, the tight specific rules (ok, so I'm pedantic). :P

RATING: 10
I have a complete love/hate relationship here.  I was crazy about this game when it came out, but have found myself less and less interested. I think the complicated expansions have dilluted a simply brilliant game.  Best time I ever had playing was 5 players, one as each color.

At the time I started playing it (3rd edition, right after Antiquities), I'd rate it an 8.

**Update - 12/14/09  Oh, come on now Joel, don't be so negative!  I started playing this again and have dusted off my collection.  So what if the new cards are bannanas?  Yes, yes, some of the new mechanics are definitely a little less friendly than others... but so what?  Magic is still a blast to play, and simple cards like 'Jump' and 'Unsummon' can still wreck someone's day.  

Bumping my rating to an 8, as I am perfectly willing to play with the right crowd in a casual setting at almost any time.  The new art on the cards is also pretty jaw-dropping... the quality has been steadily increasing over the past decade.

**Update - 1/9/2010  Back in big time!!!  Played in a formal Friday Night Magic event, and have been throwing myself full-bore into the hobby again.  How I ever left this game is a total mystery to me...  I love the mix of luck, skill, variance, play types... It is like 500 games in 1.

Cranked my rating up to a 10, writing the last decade off as a hiatus caused by life and a sudden change of scenery.  I can't imagine not wanting to play this game in one of its myriad formats.

**Update - 5/20/2010 The love affair has staying power.  Magic is easily being played on a 5-1 level vs other games currently.  With the various formats including Standard, Limited, teams, etc, this game has enormous legs.

**9/13/2011 - The past year has been good with great games, new releases, Planeswalker Points, and more.  Love this game.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 5
So... I'm a little bit late to the party on this one. But Bob had just bought a few hundred cards or something and decided he wanted to do a drafting game of Magic. I think that you're usually supposed to draft cards from packs which are guaranteed to be somewhat balanced. That's not what this was... it was random cards from random sets and it was not even remotely balanced. About half the cards that I saw were black, which isn't what I think you'd normally see.

So... having never played the game before, I think a two minute rules explanation was probably not enough preparation for the draft. I had no clue what I was doing during the draft and/or deck construction. Luckily they put me up against another person who had just learned the game. Even so, I still got my butt handed to me two out of three times.

I get the feeling that the main fun here is probably the drafting phase, where you're making interesting choices about how to build your deck. Once you create a deck, the play is fairly straightforward and comes down to dealing best with what you draw... something that probably doesn't take too long to pick up fairly well.

RATING: N/A
Desde el sitio web oficial: En el juego de magia, usted juega el papel de un caminante de planos, un poderoso hechicero que luchar contra otros caminantes por gloria, sabiduría, y la conquista. Su baraja de cartas representa a todas las armas en su arsenal. Contiene los hechizos que conoces y las criaturas que puedes invocar para luchar por ti.

Este es el abuelo del género de los juegos de cartas coleccionables (o CCG). Las tarjetas se clasifican como común, raro, raro, raro y mítica. Los jugadores acumulan cartas y construir cubiertas de su colección.

Los jugadores construyen una baraja de cartas y el duelo contra el mazo de un oponente. El primer jugador para reducir su oponente a 0 vidas (o conoce a otro conjunto condición de victoria), gana el juego.

construcción de la cubierta es importante parte del juego. Hay más de 17.000 tarjetas diferentes desde la que construir su cubierta!

Los jugadores sacan al azar hechizos para ver lo que consiguen y pueden jugar cada turno. Aunque esto limita sus opciones, hay un montón de estrategia en la forma de jugar los hechizos. Una lista robusta de la mecánica de juego, incluyendo reglas complejas para el juego tarjeta de reactivos llamados "la pila", prevé tácticas ricos y decisiones difíciles en cada turno.

Aunque tradicionalmente un duelo de dos jugadores, hay varios formatos casuales y del torneo a la magia que permiten a los jugadores jugar más.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 4.5
An extremely influential and well-designed game that has no play configuration that I enjoy:

* Deckbuilding -- too much of a money and time sink, plus a constant treadmill, so you can't just do it a bit.

* Drafting -- ok evening's entertainment, but too many of the "special" cards are ineffective in such small numbers and without the ability to really design a deck around them.

* Preconstructed -- close, but just not interesting enough, given the unwillingness of Wizards to put in enough special cards to make the decks really distinctive and interesting in terms of different play options.

Somewhere between Preconstructed and Drafting, a box that you could buy with, say, 1000 cards for 2-4 players with enough scope for some deck design but not so many cards that your head just spins, would be nice (and would boost my rating to at least 7 or 8).

RATING: 7.5
Good:
-New cards all the time
-Drafting (Magic at it's best)
-A quality format for 2, 4, 5, and 6 players
-Cool card interactions
-Combat ticks
-Bluffing
-Having the ability to draw nothing but mana

Bad:
-Drawing nothing but mana
-"The Stack" and complex interactions
-Too many phases
-A library of keywords
-Keeping up with meta game

Overall:
First things first, if you have be in a boost draft, you have not experience the best Magic has to offer.  If you are willing to commit to the game, you will find an incredibly rewarding experience that is as hard to master as it is to leave.  Eventually, you'll be cognizant of how much money you've spent, conflicted by amount of time the hobby is consuming, and struggling to store all the cards you've collected.  At this point, you should probably look into the Cube variant so you can continue enjoying this great game without any guilt.

RATING: N/A
I've never owned any Magic cards - though I did own the Microprose PC game a few years back, and I played that to death. I think the people marking the game down are either jealous of its impact on boardgames (and I'd rather play Magic than the immensely over-rated boardgames like Settlers of Catan or Memoir '44 or Puerto Rico etc.)or else are somehow in a moral panic that a collectible card game encourages people to - I can hardly bring myself to say it - collect cards. Shock. And since only 4 of each card are allowed in a deck you can't "buy victory". If the cards you choose for your deck are poor ones or don't interact or you just don't have a grasp of the strategy then you won't win.

My god, why am I getting all worked up about a game I don't even own?

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 4
I've played Magic for years and the logged number of plays doesn't reflect the amount of Magic I've played. I've played it all from competitive to casual EDH; cube to battlebox.

Battlebox is the best format I've ever played. Even better than cube!

What is Battlebox you ask? It's also called Wizard's Tower. It's a stack of cards made from all 5 colours including artifacts and multicoloured. Players have a land stack each of 1 of every basic land and 1 of each allied coloured tap-land. Both players start with a hand of 4 cards. On a player's turn, they can play a land from their land pile; otherwise it plays exactly like a normal game of magic. 

What makes this format interesting is the decision in playing the lands based on the cards in your hand. You have a maximum number of 10 lands, access to 3 of the same colour at most and for you to have access to 2 of the same colour, you have to play a tap land at some point.

The point of this format is to reduce the number of games where you simply lose to either mana flood or mana screw. Along with the relatively low power of the cards, it leads to games of attrition. It also awards players who can read their opponents making it one of the most skill intensive formats that exists in Magic.

I'm not sure if the hate for Magic is warranted here on the geek, but unfortunately it is there (though the complaints about it being expensive are warranted!). If people realised how much is taken from Magic, and how huge it's influence has been on so many games, I think people would see Magic in a different light. Think about it; the whole deck building genre was highly influenced by Magic and also the drafting mechanic.

Update: I've grown tired of the variance in Magic. Not only this, but none of the questions the game poses are particularly interesting and the majority of the decisions made in game aren't all that difficult. If you play competitively you're preparing for the fringe scenarios and making metagame calls (pick the right deck and hope to dodge all your bad matchups). Dropped this down from a 9 to a 7. I'm bored of Battlebox as well as there's too many games where it's up to the draw (I knew this going in, and I think the fact that there's no mana flood/screw, it amplifies the effect of the luck of the draw). Cube can be much the same, and drafting comes down to the battle of who takes the best blue cards as noone wants to draft the red deck. Boring.

Update 25/08/15 Rating dropped to a 4.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
There's no other game on the Geek more unfairly stereotyped than this one. You've heard it all before - money pit, richest man wins, no skill, whiny teenagers, etc. As with many stereotypes, there's a grain of truth to these - you [i]can[/i] spend thousands of dollars a year chasing the latest hot cardboard in order to win a few sweaty tourneys at the local shop. 

But that's your choice - the game itself is incredibly adaptable to different playstyles, opponents, interests, and budgets. If you want a great deck-building game for the cost of, say, Dominion plus expansions, you can do it with Magic and do it better. If you want sets of preconstructed decks a la Blue Moon, Magic has plenty of choices at less than $10/deck. If you need to stay on a budget, you can easily find simple deck restrictions (e.g. limit rares to two copies or commons/uncommons only) that drastically cut costs but still give you tremendous creative opportunities. If you want multiplayer mayhem (or maybe a more subtle game of shifting alliances), the game rules accomodate such variants with ease. Obviously, if you like collecting stuff Magic provides a limitless well there. But less obviously, you can easily find subsets of the game (e.g. specific blocks or creature types) that are fulfilling to collect without eating into your kids' college funds. And sure... if you want a serious, competitive, lifestyle game, you can invest substantial time and money into assembling tournament-caliber decks. But that's just one of the alternatives.

Regardless of how you play, you'll get to enjoy one of the finer games around. Even just playing with precons there's a non-trivial amount of skill required to play a deck well, and deckbuilding opens up a huge world of additional considerations. And it all plays out in what, by boardgame standards, is a very economical timeframe. You can sit down with an opponent and bang out a 2-out-of-3 match in 20-40 minutes, with no setup time and more interesting events and decisions per minute than any boardgame I've played that fits that timeframe. I wouldn't claim that Magic is the deepest game ever created. Even the decisions in an excellent match won't stack up to those in gaming titans like 18XX, ASL, or Go. But, compared to those, Magic is much more playable, accessible, and - in certain ways - just less work and more fun.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
The core game of Magic: the Gathering is brilliant.  It really is.  Magic and Netrunner alone are proof that Richard Garfield is perhaps the greatest game designer living today.

The problem comes in with the collectibility of it.  There are mountains of expansions out there and literally thousands of cards to acquire.  This presents the obvious financial problem, but there's also the preparation problem - assembling a playable deck out of those thousands and thousands of cards takes time.  A LOT of time if you want to do it well.

Obviously, restricting the format helps - you can only use cards from one set or a small handful of sets.  However, that still takes a ton of time because you begin to introduce a "metagame" - you have to gauge what others will be playing and plan against that (and they could be playing anything), and you also need to test.  Or else consign yourself to losing badly in tournaments.

For me, Magic is most enjoyable in a sealed environment - sealed deck or booster draft - since all you have to worry about are the cards at hand.  I also enjoy playing Magic with preconstructed decks, where you just grab decks out of your deck box and play.  

This obviously precludes me from pretty much all constructed Magic tournaments and thus prevents me from playing against the highest levels of competition.  However, it's still quite fun, a lot less expensive, and doesn't function as a black hole of time.

If you want to taste Magic in a very enjoyable and simple fashion, check out the Planechase decks.  Pick up two of them and play them with your friends.  For a great game, that's all you'll ever need.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 10
The only complaint I ever hear about Magic is that it is "Too expensive" but this complaint comes from players who are trying to build hyper competitive tournament decks. When it comes to casual kitchen table play, the game is actually very affordable compared to most LCG or Deckbuilding games, and tons of fun. There are seemingly limitless ways to enjoy playing Magic. My personal favorite is a cube that I have built so my friends and I can get together, draft, build decks, and play them any time and have a different experience each time, all for about a single $20 investment. If you haven't tried Magic, you should!

RATING: 10
people often only state the things they perceive as having been "done wrong" in Magic.  unfortunately, most CCG's missed the important things that were done right.

people complain that the cards have gotten too powerful-  and i say you build a deck with what you believe is the most overpowered recent set, let me build a deck with just the original set, moxes, black lotus, dual lands, swords to plowshares, timewalk, etc.  

people say that the game is too expensive. if you're good enough at the game, the only cost is tournament fees- you win more than enough product to keep you playing competitively.

What really happens is that people's perceptions change- and they are inaccurate... either misinformed or tainted with nostalgia.

RATING: 10
I will love this forever. It is not perfect - far from it - and I'm not buying cards anymore (stop trying to trick me, Wizards), but maybe I will come back to online playing or to homemade cube drafts. What this game has managed to achieve during the Scars of Mirrodin block is just what every gamer should dream - and probably has dreamt - of.

Also, anyone who is blaming a game for its monetary costs can just play it online, or with proxies, or limited (and limited is, in my opinion, the only format embodying the original "spirit" of Magic)

RATING: 8.5
I've had an on again, off again relationship with Magic. Years ago I would have rated this higher, as it is a very fun game, and tweaking decks is a real challenge. However, CCGs are just too expensive to stay in.

Update: After playing a few games again, I'd forgotten how much fun this game is, in particular, the deck building. Since discovering board games, I've had my nose turned up a little at CCGs, although I've been trying other CCGs on the cheap (WoW, Vs). However, the deck building seems more directed by 'class choice' in those games and the combos aren't as interesting. If only Magic didn't have the mana screw problem!

Update: I've put together a draft cube and had amazing fun playing a 7 player draft! It takes a long time but is certainly a great experience. I'm really enjoying getting back into a bit of Magic. If you treat the tournament as one long game, the mana screw problem seems like just part of the game.

RATING: 8
The best CCG I have played.  I like Magic: The Gathering a lot.  I think that it is a very well crafted concept-become-game.  Although not the first CCG, it is the biggest by far and longest (and strongest) running with no end in sight.  The colors work well as the basics for philosophic deckbuilding, and the brilliant card designs breathe life into combinations and machinations that you design.  Would be ranked much higher if it were NOT a CCG.  I hate spending money every year to replace cards that I already have just to stay current in the tournament block.  Will give massive bonus points to the person who originally thought of the idea of a trading card game with endless expansions that are almost mandatory in order to keep playing, whoever that may be.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Maybe not the best CCG, but damn close if it isn't.  It's easy to pooh-pooh Magic, but there's a neverending, nationwide community of dedicated players that plays every week, and has done so for more than 25 years.  I can name on two hands the number of other games that meet that criteria.

It can be a terrible money sink if you're not careful.  There was a six-month span of my teenage life where this had 90% of my disposable income, but to be fair, it also had close to 90% of my disposable time.  I eventually got frustrated when I realized that the cards were getting wildly more powerful, and an increasing percentage of my collection was becoming irrelevant in even casual play.  I got out of the game at that point and don't see myself ever getting seriously back into it.

That said, a lot has happened since I got out of this around the Invasion block in 2000.  The decks and cards that exist now are much more powerful than what I played with in the 90s.  Even a passable deck would shred any deck I made back in the day.  There's a lot more strategic space to explore in both tournament and casual play, especially with the reintroduction and effectiveness of multicolor strategies.  More rare cards have interesting effects that can drive a game in different directions, so it doesn't come down to "creature, counter, burn spell" as much any more.

If you hand me a deck, I'll play it again for nostalgia's sake.  Even better, if you give me an hour or so with your collection, I'll make a blue deck that probably doesn't work very well, but is a lot of fun to play.  And then I'll play you and regale you with the halcyon days when I used to play this, and about how the hobby is spoiled now.  Get off my lawn!
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
This game has such marvelous tactical nuance, it's a shame that I burned out trying to find players with the right level of skill and competitiveness.  Building decks is a tremendous imaginative exercise, and the tactical turn-by-turn play is intersting and deep, but the game ultimately goes to those with large collections, and the amount of time I really have available to comb through the collection and build decks has dwindled to approximately nothing since I became a dad.  I still love to play sealed deck or precons, but that's about it.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8.9

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
The first and biggest of the CCGs, and the only one I still play occasionally.  I don't really collect it much anymore though.  The set rotations, powercreep, and focus on the tournament scene pretty much killed me as a customer.  (Though, sure, I can't deny the tournament scene is probably a large part of what's kept the game selling for twenty years.)  The majority of cards I have are from the small horde I amassed during the game's first couple years, and I've added only a handful of newer cards to that in the last two decades.

Still, if you can avoid the tournament scene and the more cutthroat play, this can be a pretty decent game - fun, fast, easy to teach, easy to transport, and with some really cool art.

RATING: 8
The price is a huge barrier to entry if you want to play tournament constructed Magic. Fortunately, there are other ways to enjoy this tremendous game. You can play with friends on Magic Workstation for free, or you can spend 15$ a week drafting at an FNM. While 15$ a week sounds like a lot, if you can become good enough to consistently win prizes, the effective price is actually much lower once you sell back the cards you win.

Whatever the case, if you have infinite money this game is pretty much infinite fun. If you don't, it's still pretty freaking awesome.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
The grandaddy of them all, the origin of cardboard crack, the game that brought a million gamers out of their hidey holes. Nice cards with great art, clear reminder text, and yes, it's still collectible and the rares are both expensive and necessary to compete. Of course Wizards of the Coast gets a free pass here, as they both invented the CCG niche and stimulated it's growth through the Pro Tour scene.

Magic has always had strong mechanics. Games without them don't last more than a couple of printings, and Magic has been around for fifteen years. It's a great game, but it does suffer from being the first of its kind. Many systems it employs have been corrected and improved by newer games. For example, Magic's resource system keeps players from simply using all the best cards from all the colors. While that is certainly necessary for game balance, it also can lead to long stretches where a player cannot play any cards at all. The combat system also feels a little dated, as there is very little decision making. Simply decide who attacks, then send them all. There is nothing truly wrong with Magic, I just think that many modern card game systems tend to handle these issues a little better. It's still a great game, just no longer the best.

When Magic hysteria first broke onto the scene, there were absolutely no cards available anywhere. By the time cards were somewhat available again, I had somehow managed to stumble into the Star Wars CCG which had come out shortly after. I certainly couldn't afford to play two collectible games; so most of my Magic experience has been with borrowed decks, which is always difficult in a CCG. It never really grabbed me enough to buy in, and now I think other games have improved the formula so much that Magic just feels archaic. It's the three hundred pound gorilla though, so I do manage a game here and there. Magic the Gathering is almost as universal among gamers as D&D and Mountain Dew, so it pays to know how to play...
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 5
x2: noi, Dragos
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: N/A
Addictive, collection stuff.

Fun to ride the wave at the top (if you have the time, money and patience) and play the T2 mode AND fun to play with 60 really random same color common cards from the 90's, as long as both decks are balanced.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 5
I like the mechanics of this, but ultimately it's unsatisfying due to the arms race. The thing that bothers me most about a game like chess, for example, is that it's not really a contest if one player has invested significantly more time than the other. Magic is worse, because the key factor is often money instead of time. This is not to say the game is devoid of strategy, but the bottom line is it's extremely difficult to defeat a $200 deck with a $20 deck. There are ways around this, of course, and I really enjoy drafting in particular, but unless you have a group of people who are willing to stick to whatever budget you set, it will not work long term, and I would much rather buy a game that I can play a dozen times than booster draft 5-6 times.

Edit: All the stuff I said above still stands, but I dropped my rating to a 5 for a couple of reasons. First, I'm becoming increasingly annoyed that Wizards intentionally prints bad (or "weaker") cards in the sets to pad them out. I played 6 games in a Swiss draft last night, and lost 3 of them solely because of one card my opponent pulled (not a combo, just a single card that was better than anything I saw). Beyond that, playing Duels of the Planeswalkers made me realize that, not only is there no mechanism to mitigate a bad draw, but that the order your cards come up is more important than how you play them. That's not to say that deckbuilding is not key, but there are other CCGs where the mana system is less clunky (or non-existent).
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 5
I've only dabbled in MtG, but I mostly like it. Not even close to being worth the expense, though. Deck-building is *by far* the more interesting part of the game, with gameplay itself mostly done by rote: hey, neat, I drew the cards I'd hoped/planned to. Some other CCGs (INWO, MECCG, and esp. Netrunner) have in-game decisions as a far more significant factor.  (Note that after playing Dominion's "introductory" configuration, gameplay in Magic seems positively fascinating.  That is not a compliment to either game.)

Also, the Land concept is weak, as Garfield himself acknowledged.  Why have up to 40% of your deck devoted to something so uninteresting?  Add to that mana screw and it's just frustrating to imagine what might have been.

RATING: 8.8
I broke my cardboard crack habit long ago from this game but still enjoy it in the form of pre-con decks.  Unfortunately, Wizards has announced they are doing away with this format no doubt as it doesn't generate the money compared to the random packs.  The beauty of the pre-con decks are the fact that they are not (in a sense) collectible.  For the most part, they work well against each other and there's the fun of learning how to play each deck to its full potential.  Well I guess it's time to get my hands on a few more pre-con decks while they're still around.  Let's face it, MtG is still the single best CCG out there and IMHO will always be #1.  I just won't deal with the collectible aspect of it anymore.  As far as Wizards doing away with pre-con decks, too bad for them.  It's less of my money they'll get.  Hopefully they'll come out with something similar to them that's also just as fun and doesn't require chasing the holy grail rare cards.

RATING: 9
This started with the Elves vs. Goblins Duel deck I got for Christmas a few years back.  My wife and I tried playing a few times, and unfortunately those decks seemed to present very few choices during the actual game play (I need to revisit that deck).  What I recognized though is that 60% of the game is in constructing your deck.
After that I've gotten quite a few more cards to add to my collection.  I started playing at work using a co-workers cube that he constructed.  He has introduced me to drafts and I really enjoyed the game after!

Draft is the only way to go for me with this game.  I used to play drafts mainly at work, but I do a weekly constructed game with my brother-in-law once a week.  Draft is much more fun as, like I said, actually building the deck is 60% of the game.  So making it a part of the game with a draft enhances the game greatly for me.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
If you can look past its "randomized/collectible" element (which simultaneously the game's greatest strength and most crippling frustration), you'll find a surprisingly enjoyable and strategic dueling game. It is incredibly easy to learn, features almost limitless variety, often plays in under 30 minutes and yet features the potential for very deep strategy.

My advice: don't waste money on randomized booster packs (unless you like that sort of thing). You can buy complete sets of cards (especially if you focus on just the no-less-powerful common/uncommon cards) for a *FRACTION* of the cost and know that you are getting a huge variety (and value) from many web-retailers and eBay.

I don't like the fact that you have to spend more money to be stronger

the Consumerist & Hyper-Competitive -Culture- that is M:TG.

is Brilliant.

RATING: 9.5
The game that got the hobby started for me.  I played competitive Magic for about four and a half years.  I started my collection a couple years before that with boosters of Revised out of my allowance.  My meager play count on this site doesn’t reflect the thousands or tens of thousands of plays in my youth.  

I’m not sure what I can say that others haven’t.  It’s a novel concept for a product model that happened to also be a brilliant game.  I don’t regret a moment of my Magic days, though I rarely play anymore.  I met so many interesting and intelligent people playing tournament Magic many of whom I keep up with to this day.  I still can talk for hours on end about the evolution and development of the game.

RATING: 10
I got in on Magic just at the end of the Beta run, and had a ton of Unlimited (most of my good cards).  I collected Arabian Nights, Antiquities, The Dark, Legends, Ice Age, Fallen Empires and Homelands.  I used to play for ante, as was in the rules, and I recall winning 2 Moxes that way.  I also have the distinction of trading 10 Urza's Chalice for a Black Lotus.  At one point I had all of the Power Nine cards, multiple copies of some.  I still have enough cards to play if I ever wanted to but I sold off my valuable cards.  This was a revolutionary game, and I don't think there has been a CCG/TCG/LCG to come out with a better system.  There are way too many cards now, but it was great to be on the ground floor back in the day.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Avoid the collectible aspect as much as you can, avoid competitive play, and you're on the safe side - and ready for a vastly enjoyable experience.

Here's how I do it. I own 18 of the "Intro Packs" for the game published since 2009. These are premade decks, roughly balanced to each other. I meet with friends to play Magic, each of us picks one of these 18 sets, and then have a go at each other. Individual plays last 15 minutes at most, so you can fit in many plays in one session, and pick different 'packs' in each new play.

The key is - buy these Intro Packs, and don't ever adjust (aka 'pimp') them by buying high powered rare cards on Ebay. That way the decks stay balanced to each other, and brain (as opposed to: wallet) power is the decisive factor in scoring a victory.

Actually, what inspired me to go about the game in this way was
1. the warning I got from people who burned out on the game because of the collectible+tournament aspects
2. the LCG format introduced by FFG for its card games. Brought home to me that Magic may as well be *best* enjoyed as a 'game out of the box'.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
Probably the best game ever made. Constantly developing with very transparent developers. I've played this game for ten or so years by now, and I am still getting more and more enthusiastic about it. If you stick to buying cards second-hand and playing casual, it isn't too expensive. Considering the money spent per time unit, this is probably one of my cheapest games, even.

RATING: 10
Can be a 2-player abstract card trading game, or a multi-player game for 3 or more players. There are a few formats to be played with players you may or not known. Formats like Commander, Standard, Modern, Legacy, Vintage. This game can take you a long-period of time to understand the basic rules of the game, and it takes you more time to design a deck that best fit you for a game or two. Best recommend for deck building players who love deck building mechanics.
