=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6.2
Having played this game to a very high level of competition and very close its release, I believe I'm one of few people who can give a very good review of the game. I first started in 1994 and up until about 2002, I had spent about $20,000 on it, had participated in hundreds of drafts/sealeds and qualified for many pro tour events and national chamionships.

The short version is this, the game WAS fantastic and I would have ranked it about 9/10, the highest score I would have given anything. Now it deserves no more than 6, due to greed and dilution.

If you're just starting to play this game, I strongly suggest you play it for free over the internet or borrow someone else's cards. This is a rich man's hobby if you wish to even have a shot at anything competitive. I have no comment on what it's like as a casual game.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 4
Garfield is rightly famous for inventing the CCG system. It was a breakthrough when it was new, and WOTC has done an amazing job of keeping it interesting by inventing interesting new cards for the system.

That being said, most games I play end up annoying me. The main killer is the amount of luck in drawing the right amount of land and the right cards at the right time; so many games are decided by one player drawing too much or too little land. With slightly better mechanics this could be incredible, but as it stands I'd rather play something else.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
Ignoring external considerations and rating purely on the game, this is clearly a 10. Massively innovative, constantly evolving, maybe even world-changing. Every card is like a jigsaw piece, but it's a piece that can fit into a million different jigsaws. There are so many different ways to play, from competitive booster draft to crazy casual multiplayer games; if you've had enough of one aspect of the game you can try another. Even deckbuilding can be a game in itself. 

Whether you're drafting the perfect deck and trouncing each opponent 2-0 for prizes, patiently constructing your game-winning play using combinations of silly cards to the amusement of the table, or just enjoying the flavour of a lovingly-constructed theme deck, it's all good. My enthusiasm for Magic waxes and wanes, but it's something I'll always come back to.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 7.5
This game... Great game. Amazingly in depth and dozens and dozens of mechanics that make sure no two games are ever really the same. BUT, to play competitively requires a lot of study and money. You constantly have to buy the latest cards and research the best combos. Turned me off eventually. For a good old gaming night with friends and just using cards you already have it's still great though.

RATING: 10
MtG is the game I've played for the longest period of time, it's the only game I've stayed up all night playing and playing and never getting bored, it's the game I've played the most times, the game I've played the most times repeatedly in one session, the game I've played with the most people, and the game I've spent the most time thinking about. It's also the game I've spent the most money on. An absurd amount of money. It has came and went from my life a few times, mostly for financial reasons, but I'm at a place in my life now where I am comfortable with how much I spend and how much I play. It's no longer an addiction, it's something that I can pick up and play at any time with endless variety and continue to find new things to love about it. I've stopped playing standard and stick mostly to Commander and Modern with the occasional draft. I love building fun casual decks and dumb combos and all the aspects of deck building. I started back during Sixth Edition and still love Magic to this day. It will always be my favorite game.

RATING: 8.5
Extremely enjoyable gameplay, excellent production values, along with the broadspread market penetration and popularity of the game, matched by Wizards of the Coast's excellent support of the game has pushed it into the stratosphere and deservedly so, for years and years.  

The Mana Screw/Flood issue is really the only major gameplay flaw I can think of (if you want to call it a flaw) though some folks (myself included) find it hard to keep up with the high cost of owning the game and playing in the Standard game mode.  If only there was a cheaper version of the game or a cheaper way to still own all the cards!  One of my top 2 all-time favorite card games.  Truly a superb gaming experience in the right setting.

The only other negative would be that the community is pretty crap - full of pompous know-it-alls and quite insular, it's not something you'd ever really want or care to be a part of, imho.

RATING: 10
The original CCG, but also probably the best.  Although unbalanced in it's original form, rule changes and card restrictions have made it one of the best in this respect.  Easy enough for beginners, quick to play, and the added fun of building a deck that's unique make this the best game I've ever played.  The cost of playing copetitively are insane compared to non-CCGs, but aside from this, I can't think of anything negative to say about the game.  Considering the thousands of hours I spent playing this when I was younger, the replay value alone justifies a perfect rating.

RATING: 10
2p,4p; 60min
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Gave many hundreds if not thousands of $$ to Richard Garfield while in college.  This was during the time of UL - IA.  Once I got married, MtG fell out of favor; however, I have been collecting some cards to play casually with my wife as well as daubing in MtGOnline.

This is the grandfather of all CCG's and IMO, very well done.  This seems kind of obvious since even after 20  years, the game is still around while others have melted into obscurity.  The theme is great as are the myriad of cards - over 15000 to choose from, at least in casual play.

Concerns are the same with any collectable game - ultimately the game is unbalanced.  It must be  in order to drive new card sales.  Second, you can sink a ton of money into this game.  And third, you need to have a willing opponent to either use their own deck or one you have made.  Getting balanced decks takes playtime and playtesting.  Time which could be used playing other games.

RATING: 1
MTG Alpha to 4th Edition (10)
MTG Alliances to Prophecy (3)
MTG Prophecy to Invasion (10)
MTG 6th Edition to current (0)

Thanks for the memories. 

I recently had to update this entry due to the release of the Planeswalkers expansion. WTF? How does this not destroy the mechanics of the game? It basically puts Vanguard cards into the actual set. Mythic Rares? Are you serious?

Finally dropped this rating down to a 1. This game is basically broken beyond repair and I feel that the collectible aspects and tournament game play have finally driven the final nail into the coffin of this once great franchise. Let's face it, this game has been in a downward spiral since Garfield left the company. The emergence of net decking and Hasbro's acquisition of WoTC didn't help the matter. 

It's hard to describe to new players the way that this game was before. When I say before, I mean before the color hues were changed on the cards. This new product is not MtG, although some of the original aspects do remain. I would never sell my cards but playing this game again seems impossible.

I miss the days of the Duelist and Theme Decks. 

At least MtG opened my eyes to the world outside of MtG. I heavily recommend Warhammer: Invasion to any people who are into MtG or thinking about MtG. It is a much better game, more strategy driven than money driven and it almost plays the same. 

I hate rating this a one but it's like seeing your old crush from high school on Jerry Springer. The love was once there but it is time to grow up. 

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
[b]FREAKIN' AMAZING![/b]

Worshipped by millions, Magic justifiably resides on Mount Olympus with the other gaming supergods. Without a doubt, this is the greatest game you could ever hope to grace your table. Magic's genius-level game design is the architecture that spans over all other CCGs; they live in its long shadow.
Portable. Simple. Quick. Slow. Customisable. Beautiful. Intuitive. Elegant. Euro AND Ameritrashy. Rewarding of deep thought. Rewarding of fun, trashy play. As expensive or cheap as you make it. This is the ultimate game. Nothing comes close, sucks you in so deep, leaves you breathless, grips you vice-like, fills your brain endlessly, as Magic: The Gathering.

It took only one quick 3-minute demonstration, with a factory deck, by a venerable shopkeeper, to convince me to part with some hard-earned cash on this badass beast of a cardgame. I had no idea that this pile of card would drain my mind and life SO heavily for the next 3-4 years. Absolutely no idea.

I loved this game like a seductive large-breasted girl. Many an hour was spent honing decks and cardplay. The time investment was obviously worth it, because I won 15+ tournaments, until netdecks swept the rug from under my boots.
My favourite tourney was, without a doubt, Highlander (one of a kind card-limit).
 
I dreamed of playing this professionally. I started enjoying this game when Arabian Nights came out, and continued to play for many years after.

[b]Current Status: RETIRED.[/b]

PLEASE NOTE:
MTG is an incredible way to take the food out of your mouth and put another Ferrari on Richard Garfield's drive!

[i]To purge myself of this crack-like game I did two things - and I advise you to do the same:[/i]

STEP 1. Sell all your cards individually on eBay.
STEP 2. Buy the absolutely HUGE encyclopedia of MTG that has gazillions of cards from EVERY set. Look at this book only at midnight, and only when the pangs of deck-building start to strike.


I actually went hungry for a few days because of this game, back in the mists of time when the [i]Antiquities[/i] expansion was released, and I was broke.

I'll never put on a lifejacket again...
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
The game that started everything. Most of us wouldn't be here if not for Magic. Find reviews of the game here (Spanish):

http://www.seiscaras.com/juego/magic-the-gathering/

RATING: 9
Ok so the game is amazing, I've had fun playing it since 2009 and I only have two slight problems with it: first if you want to compete in tournaments or events near you, you'll need to invest alot of money since the most played format is standard, and to those who don't know what that is, it is a format where only the cards from the last 3-4 blocks are allowed, and a new block is released each 3-4 months (ish) which means that cards get out of the format really quickly, you always need to update your deck according to the cards in the rotation as well as according to the current meta. My second concern is that in general, even when you don't play standard, it can still cost you somewhat a lot for just playing casually with your friends (but then again, when playing casually it's entirely up to you, it is just that I, personally, decided to invest in these cards.) Any way, if you don't play the game yet, you ought to start soon!

RATING: 7
Magic, in my opinion, is an above average game, but there's just too much of it. Pretty much everyone knows what this game is, and while that's a good thing in some senses, I feel that it's just overplayed. The card pool is just too large, and is still growing and will probably continue to grow for the next 5 to 10 years, if not more. While the mechanics are good, I feel that by this point there are just too many of them. Plus, there are a lot of great card games out there, and ones with mechanics which feel a little stronger than the ones present here, or at least more focused. Magic is just okay. It's not bad, it's not amazing, it's just somewhere in the middle.

RATING: 8.5
MTG: Magic the Gathering was my gateway game into this great hobby and for this reason, it will always hold a special place.  

Although I do not play nearly as often as I used to, I still do enjoy the game play, strategizing and deck building.  

Back in the day, I loved this game and all it had to offer.  Before the introduction of the new look, I still collected cards/sets.  Now, I dispise the new updated version.  Not only do the cards look cheap, but Wizards of the Coast began releasing too many sets too often and ruined previous sets with the rerelease of old cards.  

How many of us are guilty in giving WotC too much of our hard earned money?  I am regretfully guilty of this too.  Since, I vowed not to go overboard with collectable games and I feel I have been somewhat successful in that.

RATING: 8
While you are into the game, willing to collect cards - be they physical or virtual - and studying its strategies and interactions, this game is completely fun and addictive.  Building decks will appeal strongly to your inventive side.  It's easy to go broke if you do both real and online cards.  You can't give up the real, because they're something you can physically use.  You can't give up the virtual because online, you can play any time, purchase any time, compete in tournaments any time - you get the idea.  Much of the illustrations are rather nice, as well, just to add to the sting.

Once its tendrils loosen their grip on your soul, however, you can pretty easily lose all motivation to play any more.

RATING: 9

- Drana, Kalastria Bloodchief (B) (creature removal, big mana, discard)
- Niv-Mizzet, Firemind (UR) (burns, draws, mind-controls, clones)
- Ashling the Pilgrim (R) (burns, dragons, equipment)
- Sharuum the Hegemon (WUB) (artifact recursion, sphinxes)
- Rafiq of the Many (GWU) (Voltron'ish good-stuff?)
- Momir Vig, Simic Visionary (GU) (janky toolbox)
- Kresh the Bloodbraided (BRG) (creature removal, big bodies)

Commander 2016
- Yidris, Maelstrom Wanderer (slightly upgraded)

Commander 2017 Set (slightly upgraded)
- Arahbo, Roar of the World (GW, Cat Tribal, equipment)
- Edgar Markov (WBR, Vampire Tribal, aggro, life-gain)
- Inalla, Archmage Ritualist (UBR, Wizard Tribal, shenanigans?)
- The Ur-Dragon (WUBRG, Dragon Tribal, stompy?)

No infinite combos that I know of, other than probably something with Momir Vig's Experiment Kraj. Not very tuned for competitive play; just fun kitchen table EDH decks!

>>> Rating Comments >>> (Only relates to Commander/Elder-Dragon-Highlander format, which is the format I play)

Tu labor es aprender, revisar, estudiar todo ese legado y como un orfebre tomar cada pieza y ponerla en su sitio. =-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
Played heavily between 1996-2006. 

I stopped because boardgames are more fun and don't cost that much. Also LCG have replaced Magic completely for me. 

Playing kitchen sink Magic does not appeal to me since the interesting cards that provide any kind of strategy in this game are the rare ones. To get them you need to rely on luck or buy them separately and that becomes costly very quickly. It is also a very addictive process. 

I feel that LCG have mechanically modernized. Magic still struggles with some old mechanisms: landdraw, relying on luck to get your cards or buy expensive  tutors. There is skill in magic : deckbuilding requires a vast amount of meta knowledge. Also timing the effects of the rarer cards, knowing when to play them is strategic. Yet there also always have been decks that are draw, pay, play without too much thinking, because it's more the cards and their interaction that deliver gameplay and not so much the mechanics of the game. 
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 7

Although it is still a fun and quick filler, with a theme that I love, it requires too much money to take seriously and the problems with getting mana screwed (where you draw either too many or too few mana cards to even be able to play) are a death sentence.

Sure, you could just play with the starter packs to avoid the cost issues, but that removes a big part of the experience.

RATING: 7
When it first came out, I thought "yes, this is the kind of game I've been looking for, something where the cards are your playing area and pieces." (Except I was thinking of a sci-fi game.) An inspiring design that started a whole gaming genre. Some of the most fun I had was with 5-player games where everyone played a different colour, despite possible balance issues. A well thought out design. Was at its best in its innocent, initial stages. I'd had enough after a year (its first year), but I clearly underestimated the addictive effect it would have on other people.
